'''ABC Codes''' are five-digit [[Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act]] (HIPAA) compliant alpha codes (e.g., AAAAA) used by licensed and non-licensed [[healthcare]] practitioners on standard healthcare claim forms (e.g., [[Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services|CMS]] 1500 Form) to describe services, remedies and/or supply items provided and/or used during patient visits. ABC codes contain both a short description and an expanded definition of the service, remedy and/or supply item. ABC codes were created and designed by ABC Coding Solutions [http://www.ABCcodes.com].
ABC codes fill gaps in healthcare coding and the [[National Health Information Network]] (NHIN) that older medical code sets do not cover by describing care provided by all healthcare practitioners. ABC codes can also be used in conjunction with two-digit, alpha-numeric practitioner identifiers (e.g., 1A) to identify the practitioner type (e.g., chiropractor) providing the service. Additionally, ABC codes are supported by state legislative references regarding scope of practice and training requirements on a code, state and practitioner-specific basis.
ABC codes are a proposed solution and approach to accurately document care provided during each patient encounter as mandated by HIPAA.

page.title: Aftermath of the 2011 Libyan Civil War

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:Seal of the National Transitional Council (Libya).svg|thumb|Seal of the National Transitional Council]] The '''aftermath of the Libyan Civil War''' has been characterized by marked change in the social and political order of [[Libya]] after the overthrow and [[Killing of Muammar Gaddafi|killing]] of [[Muammar Gaddafi]] in the [[2011 Libyan Civil War]]. The country has been subject to ongoing proliferation of weapons, Islamic insurgencies, sectarian violence, and lawlessness, with spillovers affecting neighboring countries including [[Mali]].
After the interim [[National Transitional Council]] (NTC) declared that the country had been liberated in October 2011, it began a process to form a new government, prepare for elections and prosecute former Gaddafi officials. In the absence of an organized military, armed militias of former rebels continued to assert their role as "guardians of the revolution" around the country, and there were reports of vigilante justice and sporadic clashes between rival militias. International organizations voiced concerns over the proliferation of weapons in the region, and the risk that they might fall into the hands of militant [[Islamist]]s.
[[Libyan General National Congress election, 2012|Elections]] were held in July 2012 to a [[General National Congress]] (GNC), which took power a month later, charged with organising a [[constituent assembly]] for authoring Libya's new constitution. The NTC was formally dissolved, and in November 2012 [[Ali Zeidan]] was sworn in as Prime Minister. In March 2014, Zeidan was ousted by the GNC, amid [[2014 Libyan conflict|escalating conflict in the country]]. On 4 August 2014, the GNC was replaced by a newly elected [[Council of Deputies]] (CoD), but on 25 August 2014, some members of the former GNC reconvened unilaterally and said they had elected [[Omar al-Hasi]] as Prime Minister, effectively leaving the country with two rival governments: the one proclaimed by the CoD in [[Tobruk]] and the one proclaimed by the [[General National Congress (2014)|claimant GNC]] in [[Tripoli]].
== Uprising and civil war == {{main article|2011 Libyan civil war}} The popular uprising against the government of Gaddafi began in January 2011 as non-violent protests, simultaneously with other protests in the [[Arab Spring]]. Within weeks, violence broke out in clashes between police and protesters.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libyans Protest over Delayed Subsidized Housing Units|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/297407|date=16 January 2011|work=Egypt Independent|accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Libya Protest over Housing Enters Its Third Day|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/2/8/4032/World/Region/Libya-protest-over-housing-enters-its-third-day.aspx|last=Abdel-Baky|first=Mohamed|date=16 January 2011|work=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> In February, the [[National Transitional Council]] (NTC) was formed in an effort to consolidate efforts for change in the rule of Libya.<ref name=NTCform>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/28/us-libya-protests-idUSTRE71G0A620110228| title=World raises pressure on Libya, battles for key towns|agency=Reuters |last=Golovnina|first=Maria| date=28 February 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Tripoli}}</ref> Gaddafi forces lost control of several cities in eastern Libya,<ref name=NTCform/> and a number of officials resigned or defected from his government.<ref name="BBCNews-pressure">{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12550719 |title=Pressure Mounts on Isolated Gaddafi|publisher=BBC News|date=23 February 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011}}</ref> In March, Gaddafi forces launched a counteroffensive, and regained many of the cities that had been lost to opposition forces.<ref>{{cite news|date=19 March 2011|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2011/03/201131934914112208.html|title=Gaddafi Forces Encroaching on Benghazi|publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> In mid-March, tanks of Gaddafi forces rolled into the main remaining bastion of the opposition forces, [[Benghazi]].<ref>{{cite news|date=19 March 2011|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12793919|title=Libya: Gaddafi Forces Attacking Rebel-Held Benghazi|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=19 March 2011}}</ref> At the same time, aircraft of the [[French Air Force]] entered Libyan airspace under the mandate of [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1973]], to prevent any attacks on the city.<ref name=aljazcommand>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-19 |title=Libya Live Blog – March 19 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |date=19 March 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xJ4lwmv0?url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/africa/libya-live-blog-march-19 |archivedate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> A multinational coalition launched a large scale air-based [[2011 military intervention in Libya|military intervention]] to disable the Gaddafi government's military capabilities and enforce the UN Security Council resolution.<ref name=aljazcommand/> By the end of March, command of the coalition operations had been assumed by [[NATO]] under [[Operation Unified Protector]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/deal-puts-nato-at-head-of-libyan-operation/story-e6frg6so-1226027088954 |title=Deal Puts NATO at Head of Libyan Operation |work=The Australian|last=Norington|first=Brad |date=23 March 2011|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref>
The following months were characterized by a stalemate on the ground, as opposition fighters were unable to retake cities in western Libya. The stalemate was broken in August as opposition forces advanced on the cities surrounding [[Tripoli]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle-east/libyan-rebels-converging-on-tripoli/2011/08/21/gIQAbF3RUJ_story.html|title=Gaddafi's rule crumbling as rebels enter heart of Tripoli | work=The Washington Post|location=Tripoli|first1=Thomas|last1=Erdbrink|first2=Liz|last2=Sly|accessdate=25 January 2012 | date=21 August 2011}}</ref> By the end of August, opposition fighters had captured Tripoli, with little resistance from Gaddafi forces. The opposition then launched a series of campaigns against the last pockets of resistance by Gaddafi loyalists, and in October, Gaddafi and several other leading figures in his government were captured and killed in Gaddafi's hometown of [[Sirte]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE79J09O20111020|title=Libya forces capture Sirte|agency=Reuters|work=Reuters Africa|date= 20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15389550|title=Muammar Gaddafi killed in Libya|publisher=BBC|date=20 October 2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref>
== Events after Gaddafi's death == [[File:El keib.jpg|thumb|Libyan interim Prime Minister [[Abdurrahim El-Keib]]]] On 23 October 2011, the [[National Transitional Council]] officially declared that Libya had been liberated.<ref name="declib">{{cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/10/23/libya-declaration-liberation-idUKL5E7LN0P620111023|title=UPDATE 4-Libya declares nation liberated after Gaddafi death|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|first1=Yasmine|last1=Saleh|first2=Brian|last2=Rohan|location=Benghazi|agency=Reuters UK}}</ref>
Libya's ''de facto'' Prime Minister, [[Mahmoud Jibril]] announced that consultations were under way to form an [[interim government]] within one month, followed by elections for a constitutional assembly within eight months and parliamentary and presidential elections to be held within a year after that.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Libya-to-Declare-Liberation-from-42-Year-Gadhafi-Rule-132403478.html|title=Libya Declares Liberation From 42-Year Gadhafi Rule|publisher=Voice of America|first=Al|last=Pessin|location=Tripoli|date=23 October 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> Jibril then stepped down to make place for elections and was succeeded as interim Prime Minister by [[Abdurrahim El-Keib]] after a brief period in which Jibril's deputy, [[Ali Tarhouni]], had assumed his duties. El-Keib was elected by members of the National Transitional Council, gaining 26 out of 51 votes.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-10-31/libya-s-ntc-elects-ex-alabama-professor-el-keib-as-interim-prime-minister.html|work=Bloomberg L.P.|title=Libya’s NTC Elects Ex-Alabama Professor El-Keib as Interim Prime Minister|date=1 November 2011|accessdate=2 November 2011|first1=Zaid|last1=Sabah|first2=Caroline|last2=Alexander}}</ref>
On 31 October 2011, the United Nations mandate authorizing international military action in Libya was lifted, and [[NATO]]'s [[Operation Unified Protector]] formally ended, in spite of requests by the NTC for military assistance to continue.<ref>{{cite news|title=Security fears as UN ends Libya military mandate|date=28 October 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|work=The Independent|first=Kim|last=Sengupta|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/security-fears-as-un-ends-libya-military-mandate-2376888.html|location=London}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Nato chief Rasmussen 'proud' as Libya mission ends|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|publisher=BBC|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15516795}}</ref>
=== Formation of a government === {{main article|National Transitional Council}} On 22 November 2011, the NTC named its interim government. [[Osama al-Juwaili]], a commander of the military council in [[Zintan]] whose forces were responsible for the capture of Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, was named [[defense minister]]. [[Fawzi Abdelali]], a militia leader from [[Misrata]], was named [[interior minister]]. [[Ashour Bin Hayal]], a diplomat originally from [[Derna, Libya|Derna]], was named [[foreign minister]]. [[Hassan Ziglam]], an oil industry executive, was named [[finance minister]]. [[Ali Hameda Ashour]] was named [[justice minister]]. [[Abdulrahman Ben Yezza]], a former executive with the Italian oil and gas company [[Eni]], was made oil minister.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/22/us-libya-idUSTRE7AL0JM20111122 | title=Libya's NTC unveils new government line-up | date=22 November 2011 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=11 December 2011 | last=Murphy | first=Francois}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2011/11/23/profiles-of-libyas-new-cabinet-ministers/ | title=Profiles of Libya’s New Cabinet Ministers| publisher=Voice of America | date=23 November 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref>
On 3 January 2012, [[Yousef al-Manqoush]], a retired general from [[Misrata]], was named head of the [[Libyan National Army]] by the NTC.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/commoditiesNews/idAFL6E8C32DU20120103| title=UPDATE 1-Libya names new head of armed forces | agency=Reuters Africa | date=3 January 2012 | accessdate=5 January 2012|location=Tripoli|first=Mahmoud|last=Habboush}}</ref>
On 26 April 2012, it was reported that majority of the NTC members approved a no-confidence motion against Prime Minister Abdurrahim el-Keib citing incompetence as the main reason.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2012/04/26/libya-cabinet-fired.html|title=Libya Cabinet Fired By National Transitional Council|work=[[CBC News]]|date=26 April 2012|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=27 April 2012|location=Tripoli|first=Rami|last=Al-Shaheibi}}</ref> However, the president of the NTC denied the news stating that the government would stay until the elections in June.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/29/us-libya-government-idUSBRE83S0CJ20120429|title=Libya leader says government to stay put until elections |date=29 April 2012|agency=Reuters|accessdate=2 May 2012|location=Tripoli}}</ref>
On 14 October 2012, [[Ali Zeidan]] was elected Prime Minister by a vote of 93 to 85, with two weeks to submit his proposed new government for approval by Congress. Zeidan's cabinet, formed by ministers from the NFA, the JCP, and independents, was approved by Congress on 31 October 2012 and sworn in on 14 November.
In March 2014, Zeidan was ousted by the GNC.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-26533594 | title=Libya PM Zeidan dismissed as oil tanker 'breaks blockade' | work=BBC News | date=11 March 2014 | accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/03/12/world/africa/libyas-prime-minister-ousted-in-chaos-over-tanker.html | title=Libya’s Prime Minister Ousted in Chaos Over Tanker | work=[[New York Times]] | date=11 March 2014 | accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref> On 4 August 2014, the GNC was replaced by a new [[Council of Deputies]]. On 25 August 2014, some members of the former GNC [[General National Congress (2014)|reconvened unilaterally]] in Tripoli and said they had elected [[Omar al-Hasi]] as Prime Minister.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/libya-outgoing-parliament-elects-pm-2014825134648296586.html | title=Libya's outgoing parliament elects PM | work=[[Al Jazeera]] | date=25 August 2014 | accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.voanews.com/content/libya-in-turmoil-with-second-premier-elected/2427613.html | title=Libyan Turmoil: 2 Assemblies, 2 Premiers | work=[[Voice of America]] | date=25 August 2014 | accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref>
=== First public elections === On 1 January 2012, the NTC released a 15-page draft law that would regulate the election of a national assembly charged with writing a new constitution and forming a second caretaker government. The proposed law laid out more than 20 classes of people who would be prohibited from standing as candidates in the elections, including Libyans who had ties to Muammar Gaddafi, former officials accused of torturing Libyans or embezzling public funds, active members of the Revolutionary Guard, opposition members who made peace with Gaddafi and academics who wrote about Gaddafi's [[The Green Book (Libya)|The Green Book]].<ref name="nolinkelections">{{cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE8010H920120102| title=Libyans linked to Gaddafi can't run in election - draft | agency=Reuters Africa | date=2 January 2012 | accessdate=5 January 2012|location=Tripoli|first=Mahmoud |last=Habboush}}</ref> The draft bill also stipulated that 10% of the 200 seats in the constituent assembly would be reserved for women.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2012/01/21/libyans-storm-transitional-govt-hq-in-benghazi/ | title=Libyans Storm Transitional Govt. HQ in Benghazi | publisher=Voice of America | date=21 January 2012| accessdate=25 January 2012}}</ref> The finalization of the election law would be followed by the appointment of an election commission to divide the country into constituencies and oversee the poll, to be held in June.<ref name="nolinkelections"/>
The Forum of National Parties, an association of 12 moderate Islamist parties, said it rejected the proposed election law because it encouraged voting along tribal lines and gave undue influence to the wealthy. According to [[Wasila al-Ashiq]], head of one of the parties represented in the organization, candidates would have to run as independents under the proposed law because Libya has no law regulating political parties. That would mean that those candidates capable of drawing on tribal power and affiliation would win the seats, she said, while minorities such as the [[Berber people|Berbers]] would be ignored.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL6E8CF09420120115|title=Libyan parties reject draft election law|date=15 January 2012|accessdate=17 January 2012|location=Tripoli|agency=Reuters Africa|first1=Taha|last1=Zargoun|first2=Oliver|last2=Holmes}}</ref>
On 28 January 2012, the NTC announced it had adopted a revised version of the electoral bill as law. The proposed 10 percent quota for female members of the constituent assembly was dropped; instead, the law required political parties to have equal numbers of men and women in their candidate lists. Furthermore, the law called for two-thirds of the 200 seats in the constituent assembly - the so-called General National Congress - to go to candidates of political parties, while the remaining seats would be held by independents.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gN5_8HWi3dScd2EJPyumFIQH8ttw?docId=CNG.4ffac2cc40606474bc6242c7407d8a26.e1|title=Libya's NTC adopts election law, drops women quota|date=28 January 2012|accessdate=29 January 2012|location=Tripoli|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Google News|first1=Imed |last1=Lamloum}}</ref>
A new law governing the formation of political organisations was passed on by the NTC on 24 April. Political parties based on regional, tribal or religious affiliation were prohibited. Furthermore, parties cannot be an extension of a political party abroad or receive foreign funding.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hCTuRbVtfd1O3_vRYxrkF9amsFcg?docId=CNG.a667c2f5c2ae88920e6404e109ae6992.c71|title=Religion-based parties banned under new Libya law|date=24 April 2012|accessdate=25 April 2012|location=Tripoli|agency=Agence France-Presse|publisher=Google News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/04/25/us-libya-election-idUSBRE83O0Y620120425|title=Libya bans religious, tribal or ethnic parties|date=25 April 2012|accessdate=26 April 2012|location=Tripoli|agency=Reuters}}</ref>
On 7 July 2012, Libyans voted in their first parliamentary elections since the end of the rule of Muammar Gaddafi. The election, in which more than 100 political parties had registered, formed an interim 200-member national assembly. The purpose of this assembly was to replace the unelected NTC, name a Prime Minister, and form a committee to draft a constitution. The vote was postponed several times to resolve logistical and technical problems, and to give more time to register to vote, and to vetting candidates.<ref>{{cite news|last=Epatko|first=Larisa|title=In Libya, Expectations High as Parliamentary Vote Approaches|publisher=PBS NewsHour}}</ref>
On 17 July 2012, the High National Election Commission announced provisional results. Jibril's [[National Forces Alliance]] (NFA) received 48.1%, taking 39 out of the 80 party-list seats. This was followed by the [[Justice and Construction Party (Libya)|Justice and Construction Party]] (JCP), which received 10.3% and 17 seats and third was the National Front Party with 4.1% and three seats. The [[Politics of Libya|Union for the Homeland]] and the [[National Centrist Party]] also took two seats, as did the [[Politics of Libya|Wadi Al-Hayah Party for Democracy and Development]]. Fifteen other parties won one party list seat each. On 8 August 2012, the [[General National Congress]] replaced NTC.
=== Prosecution of Gaddafi officials === [[Saif al-Islam Gaddafi]], his father's ''heir apparent'', was captured near the town of [[Ubari]] in the [[Idehan Ubari]] by [[Zintan]]i militiamen on 19 November 2011. His capture was confirmed by the [[International Criminal Court]] (ICC), which had issued an arrest warrant for Saif al-Islam Gaddafi and his father during the war. The military council in Zintan said it would hold the Gaddafi son in Zintan until [[Abdurrahim El-Keib]], the incoming Prime Minister of Libya, formed a government it considered capable of taking custody of the high-ranking prisoner.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111119111936535209.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Saif al-Islam Gaddafi arrested in Libya|date=19 November 2011|accessdate=19 November 2011}}</ref>
The chief prosecutor of the ICC, [[Luis Moreno-Ocampo]], said that he was "not competing" with Libyan authorities to prosecute Saif al-Islam Gaddafi and that he was happy for the case to be tried in Libya.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/23/us-libya-icc-saif-idUSTRE7AM13H20111123 | title=ICC prosecutor happy for Libya to try Gaddafi son | date=23 November 2011 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=11 December 2011 | last=Murphy | first=Francois|location=Tripoli}}</ref> The ICC said in a separate statement that it had the "exclusive competence" to decide on the continuation of the case before the court, and that if Libyan authorities wish to conduct the prosecutions against Gaddafi in their own country, they must submit a challenge to the admissibility of the case to the ICC.<ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/exeres/48F6B130-EC14-4A51-BC79-1CCF8633E270.htm |title=Course of action before the ICC following the arrest of the suspect Saif Al Islam Gaddafi in Libya |publisher=International Criminal Court |accessdate=11 December 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111125183824/http://www.icc-cpi.int/NR/exeres/48F6B130-EC14-4A51-BC79-1CCF8633E270.htm |archivedate=25 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 8 November 2011, a Tunisian court ruled that the former Secretary of the [[General People's Committee]] under Gaddafi's government, [[Baghdadi Mahmudi]], should be [[extradite]]d to Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5hcIeEt-8g6odb4lOt3v7yCax5SKw?docId=CNG.e77e4a807cd98d224ecb7444f69b8e62.211|title=Tunis court rejects ex-Libyan PM's release|publisher=Google News|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=9 November 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012}}</ref> In December, Tunisian interim President [[Foued Mebazaa]] said he would not sign a decree to extradite Mahmudi due to fears that he would be subjected to [[torture]] if returned to Libya.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jRFn9kmZYSdCLuCT7BZNUN1_PReA?docId=CNG.f3260876794f954f47081be813ce7522.d81|trans-title=The trial in Tunisia of the former Libyan prime minister postponed to 14 February|publisher=Google News|agency=Agence France-Presse|language=French|date=10 January 2012|accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Tunis|title=Le procès en Tunisie de l'ex-Premier ministre libyen reporté au 14 février}}</ref> One of Mahmudi's lawyers reported that Mahmudi's health was "seriously degraded" following a hunger strike in his prison.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.cri.cn/6966/2011/12/21/2743s672520.htm|title=Former Libyan PM's Health "Seriously Degraded"|work=CRI English|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date=21 December 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012}}</ref> On 6 January 2012, a statement signed by 15 Tunisian and international [[human rights]] groups, including [[Human Rights Watch]], [[Amnesty International]] and the Tunisian League for the Defense of Human Rights, called on Tunisian President [[Moncef Marzouki]] not to sign the extradition decision ordered by the court.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/07/world/africa/libya-risks-to-extradited-officials.html|title=Libya: Risks to Extradited Officials|work=The New York Times|date=6 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2012|agency=Associated Press}}</ref>
On 6 September 2011, Mexican authorities uncovered a plot to smuggle [[Al-Saadi Gaddafi]], one of [[Muammar Gaddafi]]'s sons wanted by the [[National Transitional Council]] on suspicion of war crimes, and some members of his family into the country.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-16075043 | title=Mexico 'stops entry' of Libya's Saadi Gaddafi | publisher=BBC News | date=7 December 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref> On 11 November 2011, Niger's President [[Mahamadou Issoufou]] said his government had decided to grant Al-Saadi Gaddafi asylum "on humanitarian grounds".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/nov/11/saadi-gaddafi-asylum-niger|work=The Guardian|date=11 November 2011|title=Niger grants asylum to Saadi Gaddafi|first=David|last=Smith|location=Pretoria}}</ref>
[[Abdullah al-Senussi]], Gaddafi's intelligence chief, was arrested at [[Nouakchott International Airport]] in [[Mauritania]] upon arrival from [[Mohammed V International Airport]] in [[Casablanca]], [[Morocco]], by Mauritanian police on 17 March 2011. [[France]], [[Libya]], and the [[International Criminal Court]] have all expressed an interest in trying Senussi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2012-03-17/ghadafi-official-arrested/53587184/1|work=[[USA Today]]|title=Abdullah Al Senoussi, Gaddafi Intelligence Chief, Reportedly Arrested In Mauritania|first=Rami|last=Al-Shaheibi|date=17 March 2012}}</ref>
=== 2014 parliamentary crisis and conflict === {{main article|2014 Libyan conflict}} In one interpretation of the 2011 [[Libyan interim Constitutional Declaration]], the mandate of the [[General National Congress]] (GNC) was to expire on 7 February 2014.<ref name="MPs_resign_Feb7">{{cite news | url=http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/02/07/Tensions-high-as-Libyan-mandate-parliament-ends.html | title=Libyan MPs resign amid protests | work=Al Arabiya | date=7 February 2014 | accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://transitions.foreignpolicy.com/posts/2014/02/06/february_is_a_make_or_break_month_for_libya | title=February Is a Make-or-Break Month for Libya | work=Foreign Policy Transitions Blog | date=6 February 2014 | accessdate=28 August 2014 | author=Eljarh, Mohamed}}</ref> However, on 23 December 2013, the GNC had unilaterally decided to extend its mandate through 24 December 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.mei.edu/content/libya-congress-extends-its-mandate-until-end-2014 | title=Libya congress extends its mandate until end-2014 | work=AFP | date=23 December 2013 | accessdate=28 August 2014}}</ref> Public protests erupted as the GNC failed to stand down on 7 February 2014.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/07/us-libya-crisis-idUSBREA161MH20140207 | title=In standoff, Libyans protest over parliament extension | work=Reuters | date=7 February 2014 | agency=Reuters | accessdate=30 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://reliefweb.int/report/libya/libyans-protest-against-protracted-transition | title=Libyans protest against protracted transition | date=7 February 2014 | agency=AFP | accessdate=30 August 2014}}</ref>
On 14 February 2014, General [[Khalifa Haftar]] appeared in a video broadcast on state TV, declaring the dissolution of the GNC and the formation of a [[caretaker government]] committee to oversee new elections.<ref>http://www.cbsnews.com/news/libya-major-general-khalifa-haftar-declares-govt-suspended-in-apparent-coup-bid/</ref> In response, Libyan Prime Minister Ali Zeidan said: "The GNC is doing its work and so is the government. The army is in its headquarters, and Khalifa Haftar has no authority." He also said legal proceedings under military law would be taken against Haftar for his statement.<ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2014/02/libyan-general-wants-parliament-suspended-2014214111452905729.html</ref><ref>https://www.nytimes.com/2014/02/15/world/middleeast/in-libya-a-coup-or-perhaps-not.html?_r=0</ref>
On 16 May 2014, Haftar's militia launched a campaign it dubbed "Operation Dignity", in an offensive against Benghazi bases of [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]].<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jun/04/libyan-renegade-general-khalifa-haftar-suicide-bombing-benghazi</ref><ref>https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/05/16/us-libya-violence-idUSBREA4F0QE20140516</ref>
== Security ==
=== Lawlessness under the interim government === {{main article|Post-civil war violence in Libya}} [[File:Libya rebel checkpoint by VOA.jpg|thumb|280px|A rebel checkpoint in Tripoli, Libya]] During the civil war, brigades of armed volunteers sprang up around the country, reporting to local military councils, which became ''de facto'' local governments. Civilian leaders said that, after the declaration of liberation, the militias shifted from merely delaying the surrender of their weapons to actively asserting a continuing political role as "guardians of the revolution". Some of the largest, and most well-equipped brigades were associated with [[Islamist]] groups then forming political parties.<ref name="nytoutlast">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/02/world/africa/in-libya-the-fighting-may-outlast-the-revolution.html|title=In Libya, Fighting May Outlast the Revolution|date=1 November 2011|work=The New York Times|first=David D.|last=Kirkpatrick|accessdate=16 November 2011|location=Tripoli}}</ref>
Reports suggested sporadic clashes between rival militias, and vigilante revenge killings.<ref name="nytoutlast"/><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8860684/Libya-revolutionaries-turn-on-each-other-as-fears-grow-for-law-and-order.html|title=Libya: revolutionaries turn on each other as fears grow for law and order|work=The Telegraph|first=Nick|last=Meo|location=Tripoli|date=31 October 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref> Civilian residents reported being subjected to looting and robbery by gunmen.<ref>{{cite news|title=Confusion and conflicting loyalties as Libyans struggle with life after Gaddafi|work=The Telegraph|date=29 October 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|first=Nick|last=Meo|location=Tripoli|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8857554/Confusion-and-conflicting-loyalties-as-Libyans-struggle-with-life-after-Gaddafi.html}}</ref><ref name="telegraph">{{cite news|title=Libya dispatch: as lawlessness spreads, are the rebel 'good guys' turning bad?|first=Nick|last=Meo|location=Tripoli|date=5 November 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8871825/Libya-dispatch-as-lawlessness-spreads-are-the-rebel-good-guys-turning-bad.html|work=The Daily Telegraph}}</ref> In December 2011, a group of armed men dragged Libya's attorney general Abdul-Aziz al-Hassady from his car in broad daylight in [[Tripoli]], threatening to kill him if he didn't release one of their friends who had been arrested on suspicion of murder.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/12/07/libyas-attorney-general-says-gunmen-attacked-him/ | title=Libya's Attorney General Says Gunmen Attacked Him | publisher=Fox News Channel | date=7 December 2011 | agency=Associated Press | accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tripoli}}</ref> Days later, a group of [[Zintan]]i gunmen attacked the convoy of a top army officer, Gen. [[Khalifa Haftar]], as it was speeding through a checkpoint set up by the group.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/13/world/africa/libyan-army-clashes-with-militia-near-tripoli-airport.html | work=The New York Times | first=Liam | last=Stack | title=Libyan Army Clashes With Militia Near Tripoli Airport | date=12 December 2011}}</ref> In a separate incident, gunfire broke out between the army and the Zintan brigade at the [[Tripoli International Airport]].<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/dec/11/libya-tripoli-airport-militia | title=Libya: Tripoli airport closed after rogue militia attacks garrison | work=The Guardian | date=11 December 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2011 | last=Stephen | first=Chris | location=Tripoli}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-16128837 | title=Gunfight erupts near Tripoli airport in Libya | publisher=BBC News | date=11 December 2011 | accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref> On 16 December 2011, Haftar said an armed group had abducted his son, Belgassim, and detained him at the airport.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-17/libya-s-top-general-says-son-abducted-by-militia-in-capital.html |title=Libya’s Top General Says Son Abducted by Militia in Capital |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=16 December 2011 |agency=Bloomberg |accessdate=5 January 2012 |first=Chris |last=Stephen |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120109163145/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-17/libya-s-top-general-says-son-abducted-by-militia-in-capital.html |archivedate=9 January 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
While initially unwilling to let foreign private security firms operate in Libya, by December the NTC had allowed Western mercenaries to move in to fill the security vacuum around the country. The main focus of the security contractors were oil industry sites.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2011/12/09/Security-firms-hustle-in-lawless-Libya/UPI-75871323450621/#ixzz1g4GlN0UN | title=Security firms hustle in lawless Libya | date=9 December 2011 | agency=United Press International | accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tripoli}}</ref> Interim interior minister Fawzi Abdelali stated that the authorities were planning to integrate 50,000 former rebels into the security forces of the defence and interior ministries; over the long term, 200,000 fighters would be rehabilitated.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20111201-libya-integrate-50000-anti-kadhafi-fighters |title=Libya 'to integrate 50,000 anti-Kadhafi fighters' |work=France 24 |date=1 December 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2011 |agency=Agence France-Presse }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> $8 billion were allocated to get the program started.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Business/Middle-East/2012/Jan-09/159277-libya-government-$8b-to-reintegrate-fighters.ashx#axzz1kUdyRACN|title=Libya Government: $8b to Reintegrate Fighters|date=9 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2012|location=Tripoli|work=Lebanon Daily Star|agency=Associated Press|first=Rami|last=Al-Shaheibi}}</ref>
On 6 December 2011, Libya's interim government announced that, following consultations with [[Tripoli]]'s local council, it had given militias lingering in the capital until late December to hand over security to the authorities. Officials said residents of Tripoli would convene rallies in support of the initiative to clear the city of weapons and out-of-town fighters. If militias had not withdrawn by 20 December 2011, the authorities and members of the public intended to close the whole city to traffic.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL5E7N64R920111206| title=Libyan government promises to disarm Tripoli | agency=Reuters Africa | date=6 December 2011| accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tripoli|first1=Taha|last1=Zargoun|first2=Ali|last2=Shuaib}}</ref> By January 2012, the former rebels had dismantled most of their checkpoints, while some key bases still remained.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/insidestory/2012/01/2012156215196506.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=8 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2012|title=Can Libya's armed groups be disbanded?}}</ref>
In March 2012, the Secretary-General on the [[United Nations Support Mission in Libya]] reported that: {{quote|Intermittent clashes between the brigades and other incidents continued to pose a challenge to the authorities in their efforts to contain the overall security situation and to manage the risks associated with the continued proliferation of weapons on the streets and the large number of armed brigades whose lines of command and control remained unclear.<ref>S/2012/129 (1 March 2012): Report of the Secretary-General on the United Nations Support Mission in Libya https://undocs.org/S/2012/129</ref>}}
On 11 September 2012, 4 Americans, including visiting [[United States Ambassador to Libya]] [[J. Christopher Stevens]], were killed when the U.S. [[diplomatic mission]] in Benghazi [[2012 Benghazi attack|came under attack]]. U.S. officials said heavily armed extremists had laid siege to the consulate using "military-style tactics".<ref>{{cite news|title=Attack on US Consulate in Libya used military tactics but level of planning remains unclear|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/attack-on-us-consulate-in-libya-used-military-tactics-but-level-of-planning-remains-unclear/2012/09/21/38035acc-0429-11e2-9132-f2750cd65f97_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=21 September 2012}} {{Dead link|date=April 2014|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> On 21 September, thousands of demonstrators, along with government police officers, stormed the bases of several Islamist militias in Benghazi, including [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]], which has been linked to the attack on the U.S. consulate, and forced their members to flee.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/22/world/africa/pro-american-libyans-besiege-militant-group-in-benghazi.html | work=The New York Times | title=Libyan Protesters Besiege Militant Group in Benghazi | date=21 September 2012}}</ref><ref>http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/252b6fd6-049f-11e2-b64f-00144feab7de.html</ref>
On 9 January 2013, the [[Libyan Ministry of the Interior]] reported that the number of murders has risen from 87 in 2010 to 525 in 2012 — a 503% increase —, while thefts over the same period have risen from 143 to 783 — a 448% increase.<ref>[http://www.libyaherald.com/2013/01/09/murder-rate-up-500-in-two-years/ Murder rate up 500% in two years] Libya Herald, 9 January 2013</ref> In September 2013, armed groups were blockading oilfields.<ref name="bbc-20130911"/>
On 10 October 2013, the [[Prime Minister of Libya]], [[Ali Zeidan]], was briefly captured by an armed group. He was released hours later.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24475187 | work=BBC News | title=Libyan PM Ali Zeidan freed from captivity | date=10 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/11/world/africa/libya.html?_r=0 | work=The New York Times | first=Carlotta | last=Gall | title=Show of Power by Libya Militia in Kidnapping | date=10 October 2013}}</ref>
On 23 August 2014, after 10 days of clashes, [[Tripoli International Airport]] fell from government control to fighters from [[Libyan Central Shield]], a coalition of Islamist and Misrata forces.<ref>{{cite news |date=23 August 2014 |title=Tripoli airport 'seized by Islamist militia' |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/08/tripoli-airport-2014823183122249347.html |newspaper=Al Jazeera |accessdate=23 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="guardian-20140824">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/aug/24/libya-capital-under-islamist-control-tripoli-airport-seized-operation-dawn |title=Libyan capital under Islamist control after Tripoli airport seized |author=Chris Stephen and Anne Penketh |newspaper=The Guardian |date=24 August 2014 |accessdate=24 August 2014}}</ref> On 25 August 2014, four senior U.S. officials said that [[Egypt]] and the [[United Arab Emirates]] had "secretly launched airstrikes against Islamist-allied militias battling for control of Tripoli" twice in the preceding seven days without informing their military partner, the U.S.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/26/world/africa/egypt-and-united-arab-emirates-said-to-have-secretly-carried-out-libya-airstrikes.html?_r=0 | title=Arab Nations Strike in Libya, Surprising U.S. | work=[[New York Times]] | date=August 25, 2014 | accessdate=26 August 2014}}</ref>
=== Extralegal imprisonments === Hundreds of suspected Gaddafi supporters have been rounded up by revolutionary brigades, often on the basis of only rumour and accusation.<ref name="telegraph"/> According to a report by the [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]], up to 7,000 people, including women and children, are being held in private jails outside the control of the NTC, "with no access to due process in the absence of a functioning police and judiciary".<ref name="UNleak"/> Many of the prisoners are being subjected to torture and systematic abuse, and there are reports of "women held in detention in the absence of female guards and under male supervision, and of children detained alongside adults."<ref name="UNleak"/> A large number of the detainees are [[sub-Saharan Africa]]ns, in some cases accused or suspected of being pro-Gaddafi mercenaries, and some individuals were "being targeted because of the colour of their skin".<ref name="UNleak">{{cite news|first1=Kim|last1=Sengupta|first2=Solomon|last2=Hughes |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/leaked-un-report-reveals-torture-lynchings-and-abuse-in-postgaddafi-libya-6266636.html |title=Leaked UN report reveals torture, lynchings and abuse in post-Gaddafi Libya|work=The Independent|date=24 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=London}}</ref>
On 26 January 2012, [[Doctors Without Borders]] (MSF) announced that it had suspended its operations in detention centres in [[Misrata]] due to detainees there being tortured and denied urgent medical care.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/26/libya-torture-idAFL5E8CQ27N20120126|title=MSF quits prisons in Libya city over 'torture'|agency=Reuters|date=26 January 2012|accessdate=26 January 2012|location=Tripoli}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release|url=http://www.msf.org/msf/articles/2012/01/libya-detainees-tortured-and-denied-medical-care.cfm |date=26 January 2012 |accessdate=26 January 2012 |publisher=Doctors Without Borders |title=Libya: Detainees tortured and denied medical care |location=Tripoli and Brussels |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120130011402/http://www.msf.org/msf/articles/2012/01/libya-detainees-tortured-and-denied-medical-care.cfm |archivedate=30 January 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Libyan officials acknowledged that prisoners held by revolutionary forces had been abused, but insisted that the mistreatment had been committed by militias not yet under the control of the new government and that the authorities were trying to eliminate it. A law passed by the NTC ordered militias to refer all cases against Gaddafi supporters to government prosecutors by 1 July 2012.<ref name="UN">{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/story/2011-11-29/libya-prisoner-abuse/51468122/1|title=Libya leaders acknowledge abuse of prisoners|work=USA Today|date=29 November 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|agency=Agence France-Presse}}</ref>
According to the UN, about 8,000 people were still being held in Libya's detention centres as of October 2013.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24356037 | work=BBC News | title=Torture 'widespread' in Libyan jails - UN report | date=1 October 2013}}</ref><ref>https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=46151&#.UkyqL9-8038</ref>
=== Proliferation of weapons === On 31 October 2011, the [[United Nations Security Council]] expressed concern over the proliferation of weapons from Gaddafi's stockpiles, worrying they could fall into the hands of [[al-Qaeda]] and other militant groups. Officials of the NTC said it was not clear how many weapons were still in circulation.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15531816|title=UN Security Council concern over Libya arms stockpile|date=1 November 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|publisher=BBC News}}</ref>
A report by the [[United Nations Support Mission in Libya]] said that Gaddafi's government had accumulated a large stockpile of [[MANPAD]]s, and that although thousands were destroyed during the [[2011 military intervention in Libya]], there were "increasing concerns over the looting and likely proliferation of these portable defence systems, as well as munitions and mines, highlighting the potential risk to local and regional stability."<ref name="UNleak"/>
In November, a convoy loaded with heavy weaponry was intercepted when trying to cross from Libya into neighboring Niger, according to Nigerien security officials. The officials said the convoy was composed of loyalists of Muammar Gaddafi.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/libyan-weapons-smugglers-killed-in-border-clash/2011/11/09/gIQAjnAx5M_story.html|title=Libyan weapons smugglers killed in border clash|work=The Washington Post|date=9 November 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|first=Alice|last=Fordham|location=Tripoli}}</ref> [[Mokhtar Belmokhtar]], believed to be one of the leaders of [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]], acknowledged that his Al-Qaeda franchise had acquired weaponry from Gaddafi's arsenal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/al-qaeda-terror-group-benefit-libya-weapons/story?id=14923795|title=Al Qaeda Terror Group: We 'Benefit From' Libyan Weapons|date=10 November 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|publisher=ABC News|first1=Lee|last1=Ferran|first2=Rym|last2=Momtaz}}</ref>
=== Influence of Islamists and foreign powers === In August, [[Abdelhakim Belhadj]] was appointed commander of the Tripoli Military Council, a grouping of several brigades of rebels involved in taking the capital.<ref>{{cite news|title=In Libya, Former Enemy Is Recast in Role of Ally|first=Rod|last=Nordland|location=Tripoli|date=1 September 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|work=The New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/02/world/africa/02islamist.html}}</ref> Belhadj was the [[emir]] of the [[Libyan Islamic Fighting Group]]. In 2004, he was taken into custody by the [[CIA]] and [[Extraordinary rendition by the United States|rendered]] to the Libyan government at the time, who held him in the [[Abu Salim prison]] for seven years, where he claims to have been subjected to torture.<ref>{{cite news|title=UK says inquiry could probe Libya torture reports|agency=Reuters Africa|date=5 September 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/libyaNews/idAFL5E7K51FT20110905|location=London}}</ref> Rival commanders in the uprising complained that Belhadj has close ties to the [[Qatar]]i monarchy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libya's rival military commanders fight war of words |first=Nic |last=Robertson |publisher=CNN |date=13 October 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2011 |url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-10-13/africa/world_africa_libya-rival-commanders_1_qatar-libyan-capital-commanders |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130724024621/http://articles.cnn.com/2011-10-13/africa/world_africa_libya-rival-commanders_1_qatar-libyan-capital-commanders |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 July 2013 }}</ref>
[[Ali al-Sallabi]], an Islamist cleric, who lived in [[Doha]] for four years, was a key conduit for weapons, vehicles and funds from Qatar to the Libyan rebels during the civil war. Rebel commanders outside of Sallabi's circle openly complained that they lacked weapons and medical supplies, leading NTC's head of government, [[Mahmoud Jibril]], to send an envoy to Doha to lobby for weapons and supplies to be sent through him. But of the 18 plane loads from Qatar, only five were sent through this NTC-approved channel. This led NTC and Western officials to raise concerns that the Qatari seemed to be aiding primarily Islamist leaders at the expense of the NTC.<ref>{{cite news|title=Libya’s former PM accuses Qatar of seeking too big a role|agency=Reuters|location=Dubai|date=11 November 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|work=Lebanon Daily Star|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/News/Middle-East/2011/Nov-11/153684-libyas-former-pm-accuses-qatar-of-seeking-too-big-a-role.ashx#axzz1kUdyRACN}}</ref> Sallabi, who is well known as an Islamic scholar and orator in Libya, announced the formation of a party based on Islamic principles.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/09/15/world/africa/in-libya-islamists-growing-sway-raises-questions.html|title=Islamists’ Growing Sway Raises Questions for Libya|work=The New York Times|first1=Rod|last1=Nordland|first2=David D.|last2=Kirkpatrick|location=Tripoli|date=14 September 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://vancouversun.com/news/Libyan+exile+unveils+party+plan+liberal+Islamic+state/5683190/story.html |title=Libyan exile unveils new party's plan for 'liberal' Islamic state |first=Richard |last=Spencer |date=9 November 2011 |accessdate=16 November 2011 |work=The Vancouver Sun |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111110032159/http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Libyan%2Bexile%2Bunveils%2Bparty%2Bplan%2Bliberal%2BIslamic%2Bstate/5683190/story.html |archivedate=10 November 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> The [[Justice and Development Party (Libya)|Freedom and Justice Party]] was also founded on such principles.
Following the end of Gaddafi's rule, there were reports of attacks against sites of [[Sufi Muslim]]s. In late 2011, a Sufi school in Tripoli was stormed by armed men who "burned its library, destroyed office equipment and dug up graves of sages buried there," and "turned the school into a [[Salafi]] mosque."<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/02/01/us-libya-sufis-idUSTRE8101LA20120201 | work=Reuters | title=Freed from Gaddafi, Libyan Sufis face violent Islamists | date=1 February 2012}}</ref> In August 2012, several Sufi sites were heavily damaged or destroyed, including the tomb of [[Abd As-Salam Al-Asmar]] in [[Zliten]] and the mausoleum of [[Abdullah Al-Sha'ab]] in [[Tripoli]].<ref>https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2012/nea/208402.htm</ref> Three [[United Nations Independent Expert]]s condemned the destruction of Sufi religious and historic sites in various parts of the country, and [[Human Rights Watch]] said the Libyan government had "failed both to protect sites sacred to Libyan Muslims who follow Sufi practices and to arrest those who have destroyed the tombs."<ref>https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=42838#.Ue0urN-8039</ref><ref>https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/08/31/libya-stop-attacks-sufi-sites</ref> On 26 August, [[Ministry of Interior (Libya)|Libyan interior minister]] [[Fawzi Abdel A'al]] resigned in protest at criticism from the [[General National Congress]] over his handling of the violence in the country, though the resignation was subsequently withdrawn.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-19386322 | work=BBC News | title=Libya interior minister quits after Sufi shrine attacks | date=26 August 2012}}</ref><ref>https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jIR4TI6x2fXGqH9ikami4qwDihnA?docId=CNG.e223f828e62750350df9154f0a83ad11.d11</ref><ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/08/2012828151119960654.html</ref>
In July 2014, [[Ansar al-Sharia (Libya)|Ansar al-Sharia]] said it had seized complete control of [[Benghazi]] and that the city had now become "an Islamic emirate".<ref>http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2014/07/31/Libya-s-Ansar-al-Sharia-declares-Islamic-state-in-Benghazi.html</ref><ref>http://www.jamestown.org/single/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=42729&tx_ttnews%5BbackPid%5D=7#.VDbP2R_Rfrf</ref> By October 2014, the group had also declared an "Islamic emirate" in the eastern city of [[Derna, Libya|Derna]] and pledged allegiance to [[Islamic State of Iraq and Syria]] (ISIS).<ref>http://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/africa/2014/10/06/Video-Libya-s-Islamist-militants-parade-with-ISIS-flags.html</ref>
=== Neighbouring states === [[File:Tuareg area.png|thumb|left|A map of the Tuareg region.]] In the months following the Libyan uprising, the [[Sahel]] region saw thousands of combatants originating from [[Mali]] and [[Niger]], mostly ethnic [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] who supported either Gaddafi or the NTC, returning from Libya to their respective countries with a wide range of weapons. Mali's [[defence minister]], Natie Plea, said that the risk of organizations such as [[Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb]] (AQIM) seizing the arsenal for terrorist purposes was "a real source of concern" for countries in the desert sub-region. The head of the [[United Nations Office for West Africa]] stated that the UN also was concerned about the impact of the Libyan crisis on countries in the Sahel.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iAVMWcukaAKi6UJdkM3iXu2Wg9HQ?docId=CNG.156c7bd071cf4eb15b665238e235daca.3d1 |title=Sahel army chiefs weigh regional security risks after Libya |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=21 November 2011 |accessdate=13 December 2011|publisher=Google News|location=Bamako}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jhH8BqwJ8NnSUnlViXVxLlqY-GFg?docId=CNG.f2c02c700bcf33947db7403f3c93a92b.51 |title=Kidnappings add to Mali woes after Libyan crisis: UN |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=28 November 2011 |accessdate=13 December 2011|publisher=Google News|location=Dakar}}</ref> Algeria's secret service warned that AQIM had planned a "wave of abductions" of Westerners in the wake of the instability in North Africa following the [[Arab Spring]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,15573516,00.html |title=Growing threat of al Qaeda in North Africa prompts EU action |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=17 November 2011 |accessdate=13 December 2011|first=Nick|last=Amies}}</ref> On 23 November 2011, two French nationals were kidnapped in northern Mali. On 25 November 2011, a Dutchman, a South African and a Swede were abducted and a German citizen killed in a raid in [[Timbuktu]]. AQIM claimed responsibility for both of the incidents.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE7AP0UN20111126|title=Dutchman, South African, Swede confirmed kidnapped in Mali |agency=Reuters Africa |date=26 November 2011 |accessdate=13 December 2011|location=Amsterdam}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE7BB06B20111212 |title=Mali arrests Qaeda subcontractors for abductions |agency=Reuters Africa |date=12 December 2011|accessdate=13 December 2011|location=Bamako}}</ref> British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] acknowledged that the revolution in Libya had affected the security situation of the Sahel.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/11/28/uk-britain-qaeda-idUKTRE7AR29020111128 | agency=Reuters UK| title=EU police, experts to counter al Qaeda in Africa| date=28 November 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|location=London|first=Adrian|last=Croft}}</ref> EU foreign policy chief [[Catherine Ashton]] said the EU had earmarked 150 million [[euro]]s ($200 million) to support security efforts "covering, as a priority, Mauritania, Mali and Niger."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/nigerNews/idAFL5E7N92X520111209|title=EU offers help as Sahel countries step up security |agency=Reuters Africa |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=13 December 2011|location=Bamako}}</ref>
On 28 November 2011, Tunisian customs officers stopped three cars at the [[Ras Ajdir]] border crossing, two of which carried [[contraband]]. Relatives of the smuggler retaliated by burning tires in front of the [[Ben Gardane]] town hall, spreading concern in the city and requiring national and regional officials to intervene. On 30 November 2011, a group of Libyans on the Tunisian side of the border crossing assisted several vehicles loaded with contraband cross into Libya. A Tunisian policeman failed an attempt to stop the vehicles and was attacked and threatened with a firearm, an eyewitness reported. Border police went on strike in protest of the lack of security and the [[Tunisian Armed Forces]] decided to close the border crossing indefinitely.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/04/us-libya-tunisia-border-idUSTRE7B30CC20111204 |title=Libya says will secure Tunisia border after clashes |agency=Reuters|date=4 December 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Tripoli and Tunis}}</ref> The [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Tunisia)|Tunisian foreign ministry]] voiced "deep concern" over the infringements of the country's territorial integrity and urged Libya to increase security at the border post.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-12/02/c_131283034.htm|title=Tunisia urges Libya to increase security at main border post|agency=Xinhua News Agency|date=1 December 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tunis}}</ref> Abdelhakim Belhadj of the Tripoli Military Council expressed deep regret over the disorder at the Ras Ajdir border crossing and strongly condemned "any attack that violates the sanctity of Tunisian soil."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.tunisia-live.net/2011/12/04/abdelhakim-belhaj-apologizes-for-disorder-caused-at-ras-ajdir-border-crossing-with-tunisia/ |title=Abdelhakim Belhaj Apologizes for Disorder Caused at Ras Ajdir Border Crossing With Tunisia |work=Tunisia Live |date=4 December 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2011 |first=Houda |last=Mzioudet |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120309213244/http://www.tunisia-live.net/2011/12/04/abdelhakim-belhaj-apologizes-for-disorder-caused-at-ras-ajdir-border-crossing-with-tunisia/ |archivedate=9 March 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref>
In mid-January 2012, the [[military of Mali|Malian military]] [[Tuareg rebellion (2012)|clashed]] with the [[National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad]] in [[Aguelhok]], [[Ménaka]], and [[Tessalit]] in northern Mali, losing at least one soldier to several Tuareg militants in the process of repulsing the rebels' attack. A statement by the Malian government said the assailants "included forces that returned from Libya".<ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2012/01/20121182151622785.html|date=18 January 2012|accessdate=19 January 2012|title=Mali army repels Tuareg rebel attacks}}</ref> In March, the Malian government of [[Amadou Toumani Touré]] was [[2012 Malian coup d'état|ousted in a coup]] by Malian soldiers over its handling of the insurgency in the country. In June 2013, a [[Northern Mali conflict#Peace deal|peace agreement]] was signed between the government and Tuareg militants, after intervention in the conflict by the [[French Armed Forces]].
== Politics ==
=== Public protests === By December 2011, the NTC were facing protests in [[Benghazi]] over the pace of reforms and lack of transparency in the new Libyan government. Protesters were criticizing the NTC and its chairman [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]] and demanding that former Gaddafi supporters would be excluded from governing posts in the new Libyan state. Jalil called for patience and promised that personal details and official information of all government officials would be published publicly on the Internet in time.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://dw.de/dw/article/0,,15600388,00.html | title=Frustration threatens to unleash second Libyan revolution | publisher=Deutsche Welle | date=16 December 2011 | accessdate=5 January 2012|first=Monika|last=Dittrich}}</ref>
On 19 January 2012, the vice president of the NTC, [[Abdul Hafiz Ghoga]], was surrounded and jostled by a mob of protesters at the [[University of Benghazi]] where he was attending a memorial ceremony for those killed during the civil war. He escaped unharmed. Witnesses said the crowd accused him of opportunism due to his belated defection from Gaddafi's government. The NTC responded to the incident by saying "every attack or aggression against the National Transitional Council represents an attack on the sovereignty of the Libyan people and its glorious revolution."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE80J02T20120120|agency=Reuters Africa|date=20 January 2012|accessdate=21 January 2012|title=Students rough up Libya's NTC vice president|location=Benghazi}}</ref> On 22 January 2012, Ghoga resigned from the NTC, saying he did not want the "atmosphere of hatred" to affect the council and its performance.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/22/libya-benghazi-protests-idUSL5E8CM07X20120122|title=UPDATE 3-Deputy head of Libya's NTC quits after protests|agency=Reuters|date=22 January 2012|accessdate=22 January 2012|first=Oliver|last=Holmes|location=Benghazi}}</ref>
On 21 January 2012, hundreds of protesters, including many young men wounded from the civil war, stormed the NTC's headquarters in Benghazi, protesting the speed of reforms and lack of transparency from the interim government. When the head of the NTC, Mustafa Abdul Jalil, appeared to address the crowd, the protesters began throwing empty plastic bottles at him, prompting security forces to fire tear gas. Before storming the headquarters, protesters threw stones and metal bars at the building, breaking its windows. Jalil is believed to have been pulled to safety after he went back into the building.<ref>{{cite news | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5jQ_rpc6hqvKeygkMvVVhdLcMx5tA?docId=e8c1ed4fc4e8416caf683269c601d159 | title=Libyans storm transitional government headquarters | agency=Associated Press|publisher=Google News|location=Benghazi | date=21 January 2012 | accessdate=21 January 2012|first=Rami|last=Al-Shaheibi}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Al Tommy|first=Mohammad|title=Protesters storm Libyan government HQ in Benghazi|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/01/22/us-libya-ntc-benghazi-idUSTRE80K0OC20120122|accessdate=31 January 2012|date=21 January 2012|agency=Reuters|location=Benghazi}}</ref>
On 1 July 2012, protesters calling for an autonomous [[Cyrenaica|eastern region]] stormed the headquarters of the national election commission in Benghazi.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2012/07/02/libya-elections-benghazi-idINDEE86102S20120702|title=Protesters storm Libya election office in Benghazi|agency=Reuters India|date=2 July 2012|accessdate=2 July 2012|first1=Mohammed|first2=Ahmed |last1=Al-Tommy|last2=Al-Rubaie|location=Benghazi}}</ref>
=== Ethnic and tribal reconciliation === During the civil war, many [[Tuareg people|Tuareg]] nomad tribes in southern Libya supported Gaddafi because of his past support of their people's rebellions in Mali and Niger. This led to tensions between Tuareg and Arab Libyans, and in the aftermath of the war, the NTC sent out delegations to mediate disputes and reconcile the region with the interim government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/09/us-libya-tuareg-idUSTRE7A82S020111109|title=Tense reconciliation begins with Libya's Saharan tribes|first=Oliver|last=Holmes|location=Obari|date=9 November 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|agency=Reuters}}</ref> The tribes, who roam Libya's vast desert expanses, are important to security in the region's remote areas, which are often exploited as a safe haven by drug traffickers and Islamist militants.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/09/30/libya-talks-idUSL5E7KU1SZ20110930|title=Libya officer at Tuareg-Arab talks in desert town|date=30 September 2011|accessdate=16 November 2011|agency=Reuters|first=William|last=Maclean}}</ref>
Fathi Ben Khalifa, president of the [[World Amazigh Congress]], criticized the NTC for not formally recognizing the [[Berber people]], saying that his people is experiencing a "déjà vu feeling", as Libya's rulers also failed to recognize the Berbers when the country [[Libya#Independence and the Kingdom of Libya 1951–1969|gained its independence]] in 1951, making way for Gaddafi's policies of [[Cultural assimilation|assimilation]]. Khalifa claims that the NTC is adhering to "Arab and Islamist" ideologies that caused "much of what has happened in [Libya] for the last decades", and that the council envisions the new Libya being rooted in an exclusively [[Islam]]ic constitution. According to Khalifa, "no [Berber] will accept this situation".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,15515687,00.html|title=Libya's Berbers feel rejected by transitional government|date=8 November 2011|first=Karlos|last=Zurutuza|location=Tripoli|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=16 November 2011}}</ref>
Smaller tribal groups complained they had been neglected in the interim government announced by the NTC on 22 November 2011. Members of the Benghazi-based Awagi and Maghariba tribes protested that their representatives were not selected for key posts. A group calling itself the Libyan Amazigh Congress called for a suspension of relations with the NTC until it "reconciles with the demands of Amazigh Libyans."<ref>{{cite news|last=Lowe|first=Christian|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/11/23/uk-libya-idUKTRE7AM0WU20111123|title=Libyan tribes protest at new government line-up|date=23 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|agency=Reuters UK}}</ref>
On June 23, 2013, the General National Congress elected [[Nouri Abusahmain]], a political independent from the Berber minority, as its new president.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2013/06/25/us-libya-congress-idUSBRE95O0VQ20130625 | work=Reuters | title=Libya assembly votes in first Berber as new chief | date=25 June 2013}}</ref>
=== Islamic movement === [[Ali al-Sallabi]], a well-known Muslim cleric who played a key role in funneling arms from [[Qatar]] to the anti-Gaddafi fighters during the civil war, has announced the formation of a party with the provisional name [[National Gathering for Freedom, Justice and Development]].<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|url=http://articles.cnn.com/2011-11-21/world/world_europe_arab-spring-europe_1_arab-world-arab-spring-arab-protests/3 |title=Many similarities in Arab Spring, European chaos |publisher=CNN |date=21 November 2011 |accessdate=25 January 2012 |first=Tim |last=Lister }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to Sallabi, the party is not [[Islamist]], but respects the general principles of Islam and Libyan culture.<ref name=moderateislam/> Sallabi would not oppose [[Hamas]]' armed struggle against Israel and supports the lifting of laws banning [[polygamy]]. The party has the backing of the head of the Tripoli Military Council, [[Abdelhakim Belhadj]], as well as "tribal leaders and members of the National Transitional Council".<ref name=moderateislam>{{cite news|title=Libyan cleric announces new party on lines of 'moderate' Islamic democracy|date=10 November 2011|accessdate=25 January 2012|location=Doha|first=Richard|last=Spencer|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8879955/Libyan-cleric-announces-new-party-on-lines-of-moderate-Islamic-democracy.html}}</ref>
On 17 November 2011, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] held its first public conference on Libyan soil in [[Benghazi]] after having been banned for decades under Gaddafi's government. Suleiman Abdelkader, leader of the Libyan Muslim Brotherhood, said that rebuilding the country "is not a task for one group or one party but for everyone, based on their ability." He also said his organization would not take part in the interim government.<ref>{{cite news|last=Murphy |first=Francois|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/17/us-libya-muslim-brotherhood-idUSTRE7AG2OY20111117|title=Muslim Brotherhood goes public with Libya summit|agency=Reuters|date=17 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011}}</ref>
On 9 January 2012, a group of Libyan Muslim scholars announced the formation of a new Islamist party by the name [[Party of Reform and Development]]. A statement from the group said the party was an "Islamist party committed to the principles of Islamic [[sharia]]",<ref name=islamistparty/> aiming to work for establishing a state based on institutions. The chairman of the party, Khaled al-Wershefani, said the group aimed "to focus on national unity and build a Libyan state which is modern, civilized and developed and which does not exclude or marginalize anyone."<ref name=islamistparty/> He added that the party would refuse to deal with any group which "contradicts sharia," referring to the secular and liberal factions in Libya.<ref name=islamistparty>{{cite news|url=http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/first-islamist-party-emerges-in-libya.aspx?pageID=238&nID=11203&NewsCatID=357|title=First Islamist party emerges in Libya |work=Hürriyet Daily News|date=11 January 2012|accessdate=25 January 2012|agency=Agence France-Presse|location=Tripoli}}</ref>
=== Legislation === The National Transitional Council adopted laws in early May 2012 granting immunity to former rebel fighters for acts committed during the civil war, confiscating all former regime assets, criminalising "praising or glorifying" [[Muammar Gaddafi]] or his regime, and barring criticism of the revolution or the authority of the Libyan government. It also decreed that detained fighters must be charged and tried by 12 July 2012 or else released. It was not immediately clear whether the laws would govern the transitional period only or would else be permanent.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/05/03/211978.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=Libya grants immunity to ‘revolutionaries’|date=3 May 2012|accessdate=6 May 2012}}</ref> Law 37, which prohibits criticism of the revolution and publication of "propaganda", including vocal support for Gaddafi's family or the ideas of the ''[[The Green Book (Libya)|Green Book]]'', is reportedly based on provisions of the Gaddafi-era penal code banning criticism of the [[History of Libya under Muammar Gaddafi#Coup d.27.C3.A9tat of 1969|1969 coup]] that brought Gaddafi to power. The law has faced criticism from [[Human Rights Watch]] (HRW) and other [[non-governmental organization|NGOs]], and a group of Libyan human rights lawyers has vowed to oppose it before the [[Supreme Court (Libya)|Supreme Court]], HRW said.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/libya-revoke-draconian-new-law |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130416002839/http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/libya-revoke-draconian-new-law |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 April 2013 |agency=Reuters AlertNet |title=Libya: Revoke Draconian New Law |date=5 May 2012 |accessdate=6 May 2012 }}</ref> On 15 June 2012, the Supreme Court nullified the law.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.alarabiya.net/articles/2012/06/14/220628.html|publisher=Al Arabiya|title=Libyan court nullifies law banning Qaddafi ‘glorification’|date=15 June 2012|accessdate=15 June 2012}}</ref>
=== Foreign relations === {{see also|Foreign relations of Libya}} On 19 October 2011, the NTC became the first government in the world to recognize the [[Syrian National Council]] (SNC) as Syria's "legitimate authority." In November, the Libyan authorities met secretly with members of the SNC and offered them money, arms and, potentially, volunteer fighters for the insurgency against the Syrian government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8917265/Libyas-new-rulers-offer-weapons-to-Syrian-rebels.html |title=Libya’s new rulers offer weapons to Syrian rebels|work=The Telegraph|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Misrata|first=Ruth|last=Sherlock}}</ref> [[Abdelhakim Belhadj]], head of the Tripoli Military Council, met with leaders of the [[Free Syrian Army]] to discuss sending Libyan fighters to train the army's troops.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/libya/8919057/Leading-Libyan-Islamist-met-Free-Syrian-Army-opposition-group.html|title=Leading Libyan Islamist met Free Syrian Army opposition group|work=The Telegraph|date=27 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tripoli|first=Ruth|last=Sherlock}}</ref> By December, thousands of refugees fleeing the escalating violence in Syria were seeking shelter in Libya.<ref>{{cite news|last=Sherlock|first=Ruth|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/syria/8947419/Syrian-refugees-seek-shelter-in-Libya.html|title=Syrian refugees seek shelter in Libya|work=The Telegraph|date=9 December 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Benghazi}}</ref>
On 25 November, NTC chairman [[Mustafa Abdul Jalil]] met with the President of [[Sudan]], [[Omar al-Bashir]], thanking the country for its support of the rebels during the civil war. The Sudanese government supplied the Libyan rebels with arms and ammunition during the uprising.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/25/us-sudan-libya-weapons-idUSTRE7AO1R020111125|title=Libya leader, in Khartoum, thanks Sudan for weapons|agency=Reuters|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Khartoum|first=Khalid|last=Abdelaziz}}</ref> Jalil vowed to establish ties with Sudan in all fields and promised "high-level security cooperation" with the country.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2011-11/26/c_122338452.htm|title=Sudanese president says former Libyan regime biggest enemy|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=25 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Khartoum}}</ref>
On 16 January 2012, Egypt's military ruler [[Hussein Tantawi]] arrived on an official visit to [[Tripoli]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Al-Shaheibi|first=Rami|title=Egyptian military ruler visits Libya|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/feedarticle/10044080|accessdate=30 January 2012|date=16 January 2012|agency=Associated Press|location=Tripoli|work=The Guardian}}</ref>
== Economy ==
=== Oil === On 29 December 2011, Libya's [[National Oil Corporation]] (NOC) announced that the country's output of [[crude oil]] had risen to over 1 million [[barrels per day]] (bpd), compared to 1.6 million bpd before the uprising.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=7577 |title=Libya Oil Production Reaches 1m BPD, Expects Full Output by Mid-2012 |work=Tripoli Post |date=29 December 2011 |accessdate=14 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140502020344/http://www.tripolipost.com/articledetail.asp?c=1&i=7577 |archivedate=2 May 2014 |df=dmy }}</ref> Libya's biggest oil terminal, Es Sider, resumed operations as of January 2012<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/libyas-es-sider-oil-port-resumes-exports-2012-01-03|title=Libya's Es-Sider oil port resumes exports|date=3 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2012|work=Market Watch|first=Benoit|last=Faucon|location=London}}</ref> but may take more than a year to be fully repaired.<ref name="oil">{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/10/28/us-timeline-oil-idUSTRE79R33N20111028 |title=Factbox: Libya's oil returns; fields, refineries, companies|agency=Reuters|date=28 October 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|location=Tripoli}}</ref>
NOC has said that local crude and product needs are given priority. Of Libya's total crude distillation capacity of 378,000 bpd, the country's five domestic refineries are refining 160,000 bpd of current production. Libya's largest refinery, [[Ra's Lanuf Refinery]], is expected to remain offline until the end of the year.<ref name="oil"/>
The [[International Energy Agency]] said the bulk of repairs to oil infrastructure had been undertaken by local petroleum industry staff, but many of the repairs would have to be performed by foreign specialists working for the international oil companies. Most oil companies have deployed small teams to restart production. NOC said it had taken over full control of marketing Libyan oil, which split during the civil war, and that all future deals would give preference to actors who had shown early support during the uprising.<ref name="oil"/>
The Libyan interior ministry reported on 3 May 2012 that the oil fields were operating in a normal fashion and the production was good. He added that the production of oil had reached 1.55 million barrels per day the previous week, almost pre-war levels.<ref>http://www.libyaherald.com/libya-seeks-extradition-of-bashir-salah-from-france/</ref> However, by September 2013, armed groups were blockading oilfields, cutting production to about 100,000 barrels per day, leading to some fuel shortages and blackouts. Many in the armed groups were current and former employees of units set up to secure the oilfields, reacting to corruption and low pay.<ref name="bbc-20130911">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-24051371 |title=Why gunmen have turned off Libya's oil taps |author=Rana Jawad |publisher=BBC |date=11 September 2013 |accessdate=11 September 2013}}</ref>
In September 2014 there were armed clashes near the [[El Sharara oil field]] and the [[Zawiya District|Zawiya]] refinery. After armed opposition groups took control of [[Tripoli]], a rival oil minister, Mashallah al-Zawie, gave a speech at the oil ministry.<ref name="reuters-20140921">{{cite news |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2014/09/21/uk-libya-security-idUKKBN0HG0LY20140921 |title=Fighting close to Libyan oilfield and refinery as rival 'oil minister' appears |author=Ayman Al-Warfalli and Feras Bosalum |publisher=Reuters |date=21 September 2014 |accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/news-photo/mashallah-al-zawie-the-new-libyan-minister-of-oil-of-the-news-photo/455900770 |title=The new Libyan minister of oil Mashallah al-Zawie |newspaper=Getty Images |date=21 September 2014 |accessdate=24 September 2014}}</ref>
=== Public funds === At the beginning of the civil war, the [[UN Security Council]] froze an estimated $150 billion in foreign Libyan assets. By late November 2011, $18 billion had been released to the NTC by the council's sanctions committee. $3 billion had been made available to the new Libyan government.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/energyOilNews/idAFN1E7AT16U20111130|title=UN council wants to free more Libyan assets-envoy|agency=Reuters Africa|date=30 November 2011|accessdate=11 December 2011|first=Patrick|last=Worsnip|location=New York City}}</ref>
