Meanwhile, demands for wages, medication and reconstruction were putting a strain on Libya's limited supply of cash, causing prices to rise.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFJOE7A20I120111103| agency=Reuters Africa| title=Libya c.bank looks to IMF amid cash crisis | date=3 November 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|first1=Jessica|last1=Donati|first2=Ali|last2=Shuaib|location=Tripoli}}</ref> On 10 December 2011, senior figures in Libya's new leadership wrote a letter to the United Nations, urging it to release the frozen assets which they said were "essential for the economic stability of Libya".<ref name="cashletter">{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/10/us-libya-assets-un-idUSTRE7B90MV20111210 | agency=Reuters | title=Libya leaders send U.N. new appeal to unfreeze funds | date=10 December 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|location=Tripoli|first=Ali|last=Shuaib}}</ref> Western officials said legal complications prevented the money from being released quickly. A British Foreign Office minister said his administration would release Libyan assets frozen in the [[United Kingdom]] once Libyan authorities demonstrated their ability to manage them effectively.<ref>{{cite news|first=Chris |last=Stephen |url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-09/u-k-says-it-will-release-libya-funds-when-banks-are-accountable.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120723083353/http://www.businessweek.com/news/2011-12-09/u-k-says-it-will-release-libya-funds-when-banks-are-accountable.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=23 July 2012 |title=U.K. Says It Will Release Libya Funds When Banks Are Accountable |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=9 December 2011 |accessdate=11 December 2011 }}</ref>
On 16 December 2011, the UN Security Council lifted sanctions on [[Central Bank of Libya|Libya's central bank]] and its offshore subsidiary, [[Libyan Foreign Bank]]. Later the same day, the [[U.S. Treasury Department]] said it had unblocked more than $30 billion in Libyan government assets.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/12/16/us-libya-assets-un-idUSTRE7BF21N20111216 | agency=Reuters | title=U.N. sanctions lifted on Libya's central bank | date=16 December 2011|accessdate=14 January 2012|first=Patrick|last=Worsnip|location=New York City}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Libya|Politics|War|2010s}} * [[2012 Bani Walid uprising]] * [[2012 Benghazi attack]] (among the [[Reactions to Innocence of Muslims|reactions to ''Innocence of Muslims'']]) * [[Gaddafi loyalism after the Libyan Civil War]] {{clear}}

{{Use British English|date=January 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} {{Infobox civil conflict | title = Belfast City Hall flag protests | partof = | image = [[File:City Hall Belfast Queen Victoria.jpg|250px]] | caption = The Union Flag flying atop Belfast City Hall in 2006 | date = 3 December 2012 – December 2013 | place = [[Northern Ireland]] | coordinates = | causes = [[Belfast City Council]] voting to limit the days that the [[Union Flag]] flies from [[Belfast City Hall|City Hall]]{{cite news|last=Taggart|first=Peter|title=Violent demonstrations injure dozens of police in Northern Ireland|url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/01/06/world/europe/northern-ireland-unrest/|accessdate=6 January 2013|newspaper=[[CNN International]]|date=6 January 2013}} | goals = | methods = [[Street protest]]s, [[riot]]s | status = Ongoing minor protests | result = | side1 = [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] | side2 = [[Ulster loyalism|Ulster loyalists]] (including members of the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] and [[Ulster Defence Association]]) | leadfigures1 = [[David Ford]]
([[Department of Justice (Northern Ireland)|Justice Minister]])
[[Gavin Robinson]]
([[Lord Mayor of Belfast]]) | leadfigures2 = [[Willie Frazer]]
[[Jamie Bryson]]
[[Jim Allister]] | casualties1 = 157 police officers injured{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/the-twelfth-2013/baggott-calls-for-review-of-parade-law-1-4829438|title=Baggott calls for review of parade law|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014}}{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-25167331 | work=BBC News | title=Police injured during loyalist protest march in Belfast | date=30 November 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/community-telegraph/north-belfast/lord-mayor-attacked-by-loyalists-at-woodvale-park-reopening-29478745.html|title=Lord Mayor attacked by loyalists at Woodvale Park re-opening|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|accessdate=25 December 2014}} | casualties2 = 560 charged{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-24986841 | work=BBC News | title=PSNI say 560 charged or reported over flag protests | date=18 November 2013}} | casualties_label = Injuries and arrests | notes = }} On 3 December 2012, [[Belfast City Council]] voted to limit the days that the [[Union Flag]] (the flag of the [[United Kingdom]]) flies from [[Belfast City Hall]].[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/issues/identity/flag-2012.htm A background note on the protests and violence related to the Union Flag at Belfast City Hall]. [[Conflict Archive on the Internet]] (CAIN). Since 1906, the flag had been flown every day of the year. The vote means that it will now be flown no more than 18 days a year, in line with British government guidelines regarding government buildings.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/designated-days-for-union-flag-flying|title=Designated days for Union Flag flying|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014}} The move to limit the number of days was backed by the council's [[Irish nationalism|Irish nationalist]]s and the [[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland|Alliance Party]]; it was opposed by the [[Unionism in Ireland|unionist]] councillors. As a response, [[Ulster loyalism|Ulster loyalists]] held street protests throughout Northern Ireland. They see the Council's decision as part of a wider 'cultural war' against '[[Britishness]]' in Northern Ireland.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-23267038 "Northern Ireland Orange Order leaders warn of cultural war"]. BBC News. 12 July 2013.[https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2013/jan/13/belfast-protest-flag-young-loyalists "Belfast: 'It's not just the flag. They want to take everything British away'"]. ''The Observer''. 12 January 2013. On the night of the vote, protesters tried to storm City Hall. Throughout December and January, protests were held almost daily and most involved the protesters blocking roads while carrying Union Flags and banners. Some of these protests led to clashes between loyalists and the police, sparking [[riot]]s. Rioters attacked police with [[petrol bomb]]s, bricks, stones and fireworks; police responded with [[plastic bullet]]s and [[water cannon]]. Alliance Party offices and the homes of Alliance Party members were attacked, while Belfast City Councillors were sent death threats. According to police, some of the violence was orchestrated by high-ranking members of the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] (UVF) and [[Ulster Defence Association]] (UDA).[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20651159 "Loyalist paramilitaries 'behind some Northern Ireland trouble'"]. BBC News, 8 December 2012 Loyalists also put up thousands of Union flags in public places, which has further heightened tension. After February 2013, the protests have been smaller and less frequent, and have led to greater loyalist protests about related issues, such as restrictions on [[Parades in Northern Ireland|traditional loyalist marches]]. ==Background== {{see also|The Troubles|Timeline of the Northern Ireland Troubles and peace process}} Since the [[Partition of Ireland|formation of Northern Ireland]] in 1921, there has been tension and violence between its two main religious groups. [[Unionism in Ireland|Unionists]]/[[Ulster loyalist]]s (who are mostly [[Ulster Protestant]]) generally want Northern Ireland to remain within the [[United Kingdom]], while [[Irish nationalist]]s/[[Irish republicanism|republican]]s (who are mostly Catholic) generally want it to leave the United Kingdom and join a [[united Ireland]]. The former generally identify with the [[Union Flag]], while the latter generally do not and instead identify with the [[Flag of Ireland|Irish tricolour]]. In Northern Ireland, flags are often used as symbols of political allegiance, cultural identity, and to mark territory. The flying of flags is [[Northern Ireland flags issue|an issue]] in Northern Ireland, and flying certain flags in certain places can be highly controversial. There have been many protests and clashes involving flags and symbols over the years.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20595646 "Raw emotions in Northern Ireland exposed by issues like flags"]. BBC News, 4 December 2012 In 1964 there were riots after a republican election candidate put an Irish tricolour (which was then illegal) in the window of his office on the [[Falls Road, Belfast]]. The unionist [[Minister of Home Affairs (Northern Ireland)|Minister of Home Affairs]], responding to pressure from hardliners, ordered police to remove the flag. This sparked fierce clashes between republicans and the police.[http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/docs/boyd69.htm 1964: THE TRICOLOUR RIOTS]. [[Conflict Archive on the Internet]] (CAIN). Belfast City Council had long been dominated by unionists, mainly the [[Democratic Unionist Party]] (DUP) and [[Ulster Unionist Party]] (UUP). However, in May 2011 Irish nationalists ([[Sinn Féin]] and the [[Social Democratic and Labour Party]]) won more seats than unionists for the first time. The middle-ground [[Alliance Party of Northern Ireland|Alliance Party]] held the balance of power on the council. Nationalist councillors wanted the Union Jack taken down permanently, and unionist councillors wanted it to keep flying all year. Alliance put forward a compromise: that it would fly on 18 designated days, in line with UK government policy on the flying of the union flag from UK government buildings, which is followed by many city and local governments in Britain.[http://www.lbbd.gov.uk/CouncilandDemocracy/Information/Pages/FlagFlyingPolicy.aspx "London Borough of Barking and Dagenham Flag Flying Policy"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019123754/http://www.lbbd.gov.uk/CouncilandDemocracy/Information/Pages/FlagFlyingPolicy.aspx |date=19 October 2013 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.lancaster.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/civic-ceremonial/days-which-flags-flown-lancaster-mor/|title=Lancaster City Council • Flag days|author=, System|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512053911/http://www.lancaster.gov.uk/council-and-democracy/civic-ceremonial/days-which-flags-flown-lancaster-mor/|archivedate=12 May 2015|df=dmy-all}} At [[Parliament Buildings (Northern Ireland)|Parliament Buildings]] (or Stormont), where the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]] meets, the Union Jack is only flown on 15 designated days.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21296119 "Stormont union flag: David Ford hints at movement"]. BBC News, 1 February 2013 The nationalist and Alliance councillors voted in favour of this compromise and it was passed. In the weeks leading up to the vote, the DUP had printed and distributed over 40,000 leaflets in East Belfast, with help from the UUP. The leaflets attacked Alliance and called on people to protest against its proposal. Alliance accused the unionists of trying to raise tensions.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20651163 Q&A: Northern Ireland flag protests]. BBC News, 8 December 2012 In the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|May 2010 general election]], [[Naomi Long]] of Alliance had defeated [[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter Robinson]] of the DUP to win the [[Belfast East (UK Parliament constituency)|East Belfast seat]]. This was the first time that a non-unionist party had won the seat. It is thought that many unionists voted for Alliance as a protest at Robinson's financial misdealings. Some commentators believed that the DUP had been waiting for a chance to weaken the Alliance Party and win back their former voters in East Belfast. During the middle of 2012, particularly in September, heightened tensions led to the [[2012 North Belfast riots]].{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/01/12/world/europe/northern-ireland-unrest|title=Northern Ireland: Draped in Union flags, protesters march in Belfast|author=Nic Robertson and Peter Taggart, CNN|date=12 January 2013|work=CNN|accessdate=25 December 2014}} ==Protests== [[File:Police officers at the 2011 Belfast riots.jpg|thumb|250px|PSNI riot police in Belfast]] The unionist protesters see the change as an "attack on their cultural identity". In December 2012 and early 2013 they held almost daily street protests throughout Northern Ireland. Most involved the protesters blocking roads while carrying Union Flags and banners. Some of these protests led to clashes between protesters and the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]] (PSNI), sparking [[riot]]s. Attacks were made on Alliance Party offices and the homes of Alliance Party members, while Belfast City councillors were sent death threats. Unlike the Irish nationalist parties, Alliance has offices in loyalist areas. According to police, some of the violence has been orchestrated by high-ranking members of the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] (UVF) and [[Ulster Defence Association]] (UDA). These are the two main loyalist [[paramilitary]] groups, who waged armed campaigns during [[the Troubles]] but declared [[ceasefire]]s in 1994. The ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'' claimed that some of the violence has been fuelled by youngsters engaging in "recreational rioting".[https://archive.is/20130420010945/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/kids-are-enjoying-the-riots-too-much-to-stop-says-cleric-16260244.html "Kids are enjoying the riots too much to stop, says cleric"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'', 12 January 2013 There was also a rise in sectarian attacks on Catholic churches by loyalist militants, which some have linked to the flag protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishcentral.com/news/Police-patrols-protect-Catholic-Churches-in-Armagh-after-spate-of-attacks---VIDEO-190176591.html|title=Police patrols protect Catholic Churches in Armagh after spate of attacks - VIDEO|work=IrishCentral.com|accessdate=25 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.breakingnews.ie/ireland/bomb-found-outside-antrim-church-could-be-linked-to-flags-protest-says-priest-586741.html|title=Bomb found outside Antrim church; could be linked to flags protest, says priest|date=3 March 2013|work=Breaking News|accessdate=25 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.belfastdaily.co.uk/2013/02/03/revealed-renegade-loyalists-target-catholic-churches/|title=REVEALED: RENEGADE LOYALISTS TARGET CATHOLIC CHURCHES|author=Belfast Daily|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014}} The cost of policing the protests has been estimated at £20 million (up to 7 March 2013).{{cite news| url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/union-flag-protests-cost-20m-29116278.html | work=Irish Independent | title=Union flag protests cost £20m | date=7 March 2013}} ===December 2012=== On the evening of 3 December, hundreds of protesters gathered outside City Hall as the debate and vote was being held. Minutes after the vote, protesters broke into the back courtyard and tried to force open the doors of the building. Two security staff and a press photographer were injured, and windows of cars in the courtyard were smashed. Protesters then clashed with the police, injuring 15 officers. The Chief Superintendent said: {{quote|Clearly there was a level of orchestration – some people brought bolt cutters, others put on masks immediately after the vote came through.}} On 4 December, Alliance Party councillor Laura McNamee was forced to move from her east Belfast home after receiving threats.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20720406 "Timeline of attacks on Northern Ireland political parties"]. [[BBC News]], 7 January 2013. On 5 December, up to 1,500 protesters gathered in [[Carrickfergus]]. The protest became violent and police responded by firing plastic bullets. The rioters ransacked an Alliance Party office and tried to set it on fire. The home of Michael and Christine Bower, Alliance councillors in [[Bangor, County Down|Bangor]], was attacked.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20619259 "Police injured and Alliance property attacked during NI trouble"]. [[BBC News]], 6 December 2012 There were clashes between protesters and police in Belfast and [[Newtownabbey]] on 7 December; police responded with [[water cannon]]s.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20648109 "Loyalist paramilitaries behind some Northern Ireland trouble"]. BBC News, 8 December 2012 Death threats were sent to Naomi Long, Alliance's [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Belfast East (UK Parliament constituency)|Belfast East]] in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]. She described it as a "wanton attack on the democratic process".{{cite news|last=McDonald|first=Henry|title=Northern Ireland violence to be debated by MPs|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2012/dec/11/northern-ireland-violence-mps-debate|accessdate=6 January 2013|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=11 December 2012|location=London}} Bullets were sent to her, [[David Ford]], local councillor Gerardine Mulvenna, [[Gerry Kelly]] and [[Alex Maskey]].{{cite news |url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/bullets-sent-to-five-politicians-in-north-578418.html |title=Bullets sent to five politicians in North |newspaper=[[Irish Examiner]] |date=19 December 2012 |accessdate=11 January 2013}} The home and car of an Alliance councillor in [[Newtownards]] were attacked, with most of the windows being smashed. Speaking on a radio show that morning, [[Ulster Unionist Party]] (UUP) politician [[Basil McCrea]] went against his party's policy and said he agreed with the flag vote. Other party members demanded the party take action against him.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20640119 "Ulster Unionist trio want Basil McCrea disciplined"]. BBC News, 7 December 2012 Up to 2,000 protesters gathered at Belfast City Hall on 8 December. The crowd was addressed by former [[British National Party]] (BNP) fundraiser [[Jim Dowson]]. Also present were [[Progressive Unionist Party]] (PUP) leader [[Billy Hutchinson]] and [[Ulster Defence Association]] (UDA) commander [[Jackie McDonald]]. Some of the protesters burnt an [[Flag of Ireland|Irish tricolour]]. There were minor clashes with police after the rally.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20652968 "Belfast flag protests: Loyalists clash with police after rally"]. BBC News, 8 December 2012 On 10 December, a gang of men attacked a police car guarding Naomi Long's office in east Belfast. They smashed the window and threw in a petrol bomb while a policewoman was still inside, but she escaped unharmed. There was rioting in east and south Belfast. In [[Armagh]], protesters attacked a pub owned by the husband of a Sinn Féin councillor. The windows were smashed and rocket fireworks thrown inside. Later, three men were hurt in a [[Hit and run (vehicular)|hit-and-run]] at a protest nearby.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20676315 "Police car petrol-bombed near MP Naomi Long's office"]. BBC News, 11 December 2012 There were two large demonstrations at City Hall on 15 December. In response to the violence, several hundred held a "peace vigil" in which they linked arms and encircled the building. Later, up to 1,000 loyalists with Union Flags blocked the roads in front of the building.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20739202 "Hundreds attend Belfast peace vigil"]. BBC News, 15 December 2012 About 80 protests were held in Northern Ireland on 17 December. Police were attacked in south Belfast, where loyalists blocked a road near the City Hospital with a burning barricade and tried to hijack vehicles. At a protest in [[Portadown]], a man was hurt in a road accident. At [[Carrickfergus]] town hall, protesters disrupted a meeting of [[Carrickfergus Borough Council|the council]] and threatened councillors. Alliance councillor Noel Williams called it "a full frontal attack on democracy".[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20763350 "Trouble flares at flag protests in Belfast"]. BBC News, 18 December 2012 ===January 2013=== ====January 1–15==== Each night from 3–8 January, the protests led to clashes between loyalists and police in East Belfast. Rioters threw [[petrol bomb]]s, fireworks, bricks, stones and bottles; police responded with [[plastic bullet]]s and water cannon. According to the ''Belfast Telegraph'', much of the East Belfast violence was being directed by a few high-ranking members of the [[UVF East Belfast Brigade]]. They allegedly ignored orders from the UVF leadership to stop the violence. Police sources said that the East Belfast Brigade leader could have stopped the rioting if he wished.[https://archive.is/20130419222909/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/the-beast-from-east-belfast-could-put-an-end-to-flags-violence-right-now-but-he-wonrsquot-16259762.html "The Beast from East Belfast could put an end to flags violence right now... but he won’t"]. ''[[Belfast Telegraph]]'', 11 January 2013 Ten officers were injured on the first night.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20903960 "Ten police officers hurt in trouble after Belfast union flag protest"]. BBC News, 4 January 2013 On 4 January, attempts were made to hijack cars and buses. In [[Newtownabbey]], masked men broke into commercial premises and stole money.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20917787 "Union flag protests: Nine police officers hurt in fresh flag trouble"]. BBC News, 5 January 2013 On 5 January, shots were fired at police during clashes in east Belfast. Loyalists claimed that trouble began when they came under attack from the [[Short Strand]], an Irish nationalist enclave.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20922038 "Belfast flags trouble: Matt Baggott in warning to rioters"]. BBC News, 6 January 2013 The next night, loyalists protested near the Short Strand and then clashed with police nearby.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20929658 "Belfast flags trouble: PSNI chief says senior UVF members are involved"]. BBC News, 7 January 2013 On 7 January, Belfast City Council met for the first time since the vote was passed. The PSNI closed roads around City Hall while loyalists protested outside. The protesters called for the decision to be reversed. About 400 people had gathered near the city hall for a peaceful protest for the first time since the vote as a result of a call through [[social media]]. As protesters passed the Short Strand on their return to East Belfast, clashes again broke out between the protesters and nationalist residents. When police tried to disperse the crowds, they were attacked with petrol bombs, fireworks, bricks and bottles. Officers and their vehicles were also attacked with hatchets and sledge hammers. They responded with plastic bullets and water cannon.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20940126 "Belfast flags trouble: Plastic bullets fired at protesters"]. BBC News, 8 January 2013{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/UVF-members-behind-flag-trouble/88468242-4c5a-4e07-a3c4-3dba8ad46ed4|title=UVF members 'behind flag trouble'|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129151851/http://www.u.tv/news/UVF-members-behind-flag-trouble/88468242-4c5a-4e07-a3c4-3dba8ad46ed4|archivedate=29 November 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Eight-charged-over-city-violence/d8e2f483-e8aa-476e-b80a-1f3dbf8ca196|title=Eight charged over city violence|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130418202516/http://www.u.tv/News/Eight-charged-over-city-violence/d8e2f483-e8aa-476e-b80a-1f3dbf8ca196|archivedate=18 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 9 January, the Union Jack was raised at the city hall for the first time since the vote in commemoration of [[Catherine Middleton]]'s birthday. The first meeting of the 'Unionist Forum' took place on 10 January. It was set up by the DUP and UUP to address the flag protests and other concerns among unionists.{{Citation needed|date=January 2013}} On 11 January, protesters blocked roads in Belfast, Bangor, Newtownards, [[Dundonald]] and [[Clough]]. There was rioting in Newtownabbey and Carrickfergus. Petrol bombs, fireworks and stones were thrown at police, who responded with plastic bullets and water cannons; four PSNI officers were injured as a result of the rioting. A press photographer who was covering the riot in Newtownabbey was robbed at knifepoint, while a bus was set alight in the same area and a car was hijacked in north Belfast. [[Translink (Northern Ireland)|Translink]] suspended almost all its bus services in Belfast. There were also protests in [[Glasgow]] and [[Liverpool]].[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20985521 "Union flag protests: Police attacked and traffic disrupted"]. [[BBC News]], 12 January 2013.[http://www.u.tv/News/33-petrol-bombs-thrown-in-flag-trouble/54f55be9-0ac7-40e8-b244-481861cec455 "33 petrol bombs thrown in flag trouble"] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20130113150730/http%3A//www.u.tv/news/33%2Dpetrol%2Dbombs%2Dthrown%2Din%2Dflag%2Dtrouble/54f55be9%2D0ac7%2D40e8%2Db244%2D481861cec455 |date=13 January 2013 }}. [[UTV News]], 11 January 2013. On 12 January 1,000 loyalists gathered at City Hall carrying Union Jacks and "No Surrender" banners.{{cite news|last=Mangan|first=Stephen|title=Northern Ireland police injured in sectarian clashes|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/sns-rt-us-irish-protestsbre90b0d3-20130112,0,6734094.story|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=12 January 2013}} As protesters marched back to East Belfast, police tried to divert them away from Short Strand. However, "the vast majority" took an unapproved route and some then donned masks and attacked police. As they passed Short Strand, there were clashes between the loyalists and nationalists and bricks were thrown at houses. Police came under "heavy and sustained" attack after moving in to deal with the rioters; 29 officers were injured. Officers responded with plastic bullets and water cannon.[http://www.u.tv/News/29-PSNI-officers-hurt-in-flag-clashes/e0ac2906-7259-42a2-ad81-64362077b034 "29 PSNI officers hurt in flag clashes"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130419032909/http://www.u.tv/News/29-PSNI-officers-hurt-in-flag-clashes/e0ac2906-7259-42a2-ad81-64362077b034 |date=19 April 2013 }}. UTV News, 12 January 2013[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21003296 "Union flag protests: Peter Robinson says politicians not 'giving up'"]. BBC News, 13 January 2013 Sinn Féin's Short Strand councillor [[Niall Ó Donnghaile]] said that this was the 15th illegal loyalist march past Short Strand that month alone.{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/story/2013/01/13/northern-ireland-belfast-union-flag.html |title=Northern Ireland street battles over Union Jack continue |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=12 January 2010 |accessdate=2013-01-14}} The next day over 1,000 people held another "peace rally" outside City Hall. The protesters clapped, cheered, whistled, and banged drums for five minutes as a show of "anti-silence", saying that it represents "the silent majority" opposed to the violence. Later, about 200 loyalists blocked Albertbridge Road and Castlereagh Street, while a line of riot police separated them from a crowd that had gathered at Short Strand. Some missiles were thrown but there was no serious trouble. The rioting of 14 January began when masked loyalist protesters petrol bombed Catholic homes around St Matthew's Church, at the edge of Short Strand. Jim Wilson, a loyalist community worker, confirmed that youths from his community had started the violence. Niall Ó Donnghaile called it a "blatant, well planned and organised sectarian attack ... It is an attempt by unionists to intimidate a small Catholic community". St Matthew's church hall was hosting a social event for children with special needs, but had to be evacuated. Wilson said a crowd of nationalists arrived after the first missiles were thrown and some attacked Protestant homes in retaliation. When police arrived, the loyalists threw dozens of petrol bombs at police jeeps, three of which caught fire. A bus driver was also hurt when his vehicle was stoned.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21020296 "Union flag dispute: Trouble flares at Short Strand interface after protest"]. BBC News, 15 January 2013[http://www.u.tv/News/Petrol-bombs-thrown-and-bus-driver-hurt/7f2e0bbb-ae9e-4849-b0b9-5f1002ee3a2f "Petrol bombs thrown and bus driver hurt"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130418222057/http://www.u.tv/News/Petrol-bombs-thrown-and-bus-driver-hurt/7f2e0bbb-ae9e-4849-b0b9-5f1002ee3a2f |date=18 April 2013 }}. UTV News, 14 January 2013 ====January 16–31==== On 17 January, leaflets were distributed to homes in East Belfast, where much of the rioting had taken place, calling for the violence to end. The move was backed by church groups, community groups, and loyalist paramilitary groups; including the UVF, UDA, and [[Red Hand Commando]] (RHC).[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21066179 "Loyalist leaders call for end to 'wanton destruction' in east Belfast"]. BBC News, 17 January 2013 On 18 January, protesters pelted police at a protest in [[Ballyclare]], leading to two arrests.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21103048|title=BBC News - Court told snowballs thrown during Ballyclare flag protest|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 December 2014}} On 19 January, several hundred loyalists attended the weekly Saturday protest at Belfast City Hall. There was no trouble as they passed the nationalist Short Strand, but later three people were arrested and two charged with disorderly behaviour following trouble in the Albertbridge Road area.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21097527|title=BBC News - Two charged over east Belfast trouble|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 December 2014}} On 20 January, about 150 loyalists held a protest in [[Derry]] outside a concert featuring Derry singers like [[Nadine Coyle]] and [[Phil Coulter]] to mark the start of Derry's year as the 2013 [[UK City of Culture]]. Police largely contained the protest, but about 30 people got onto the road for a short time and blocked traffic. Two people were arrested, although the concert suffered no disruption.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-foyle-west-21117290|title=BBC News - Loyalist stage flag protest at City of Culture concert|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 December 2014}} The following day, 11 arrests were made during flag protests across Northern Ireland. Three were arrested in Derry's [[Waterside, Derry|Waterside]] area for offences including disorderly behaviour and obstructing a highway. The other eight arrests were in East Belfast on suspicion of blocking a highway.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21135829|title=BBC News - Union flag protests: 11 arrests made in Northern Ireland|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 December 2014}} In Newtownabbey on 25 January, loyalists threw petrol bombs, stones and fireworks at police following a flag protest there. A batch of petrol bombs was seized by police.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21204406|title=BBC News - Flag protests: 12 petrol bombs thrown at police|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 December 2014}} Elsewhere in Northern Ireland, a demonstration which applied to the [[Parades Commission]] took place in [[Castlederg]], where 350 people and six bands attended. In Belfast, several roads were blocked by protesters.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Flag-protesters-block-city-roads/301c0b6f-9836-4cc6-ac4c-7d13abc734f5|title=Flag protesters block city roads|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130418211133/http://www.u.tv/News/Flag-protesters-block-city-roads/301c0b6f-9836-4cc6-ac4c-7d13abc734f5|archivedate=18 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 26 January, several hundred loyalists held a protest outside Belfast City Hall, and a number of protesters later blocked several roads in East Belfast. A man was later arrested and charged with assaulting police, disorderly behaviour, obstructing traffic and resisting arrest.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Man-charged-after-Belfast-protest/4af46a8e-c0da-41fb-b573-8260fc2204b1|title=Man charged after Belfast protest|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130419080320/http://www.u.tv/News/Man-charged-after-Belfast-protest/4af46a8e-c0da-41fb-b573-8260fc2204b1|archivedate=19 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} First Minister Peter Robinson attended a meeting with loyalist leaders as well as local church and community representatives at the Skainos Centre in East Belfast. When leaving, he was heckled by a small crowd of loyalists and his car was struck by a flag pole.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Robinson-in-east-Belfast-flag-talks/e4cd2f53-4e0a-4d1a-a00b-daa8f2b2e162|title=Robinson in east Belfast flag talks|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130128061615/http://www.u.tv/News/Robinson-in-east-Belfast-flag-talks/e4cd2f53-4e0a-4d1a-a00b-daa8f2b2e162|archivedate=28 January 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 27 January, several hundred loyalists held a peaceful protest in Derry's Waterside area, with [[Willie Frazer]] of [[Families Acting for Innocent Relatives]] (FAIR) and Henry Reilly of [[UKIP]] in attendance.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-foyle-west-21223623|title=BBC News - Londonderry loyalist flag protest passes peacefully|work=BBC News|accessdate=25 December 2014}} ===February 2013=== On 16 February, an [[IFA Premiership]] match at [[Seaview (football ground)|Seaview]] between [[Crusaders F.C.]] and [[Cliftonville F.C.]] was called off due to a loyalist protest outside the stadium.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21485713 |title=Irish Premiership: Crusaders-Cliftonville called off|publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-02-16}} On 27 February, prominent loyalist activist Willie Frazer and flag protest organiser [[Jamie Bryson]] were arrested by the PSNI as part of their investigation into the flag protests.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21601341 | work=BBC News | title=Flag protest: Willie Frazer and Jamie Bryson face questions | date=27 February 2013}} On 1 March, Jim Dowson was also arrested for his role in the protests. He was later released on bail.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21630704 | work=BBC News | title=Jim Dowson arrested in union flag protest probe | date=1 March 2013}}{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21645715 | work=BBC News | title=Jamie Bryson remanded in custody over Belfast union flag protests | date=2 March 2013}} ===March 2013=== On 2 March, 150 loyalists turned up for the weekly protest outside Belfast City Hall. However, unlike previous demonstrations, protesters were bussed to City Hall rather than marching. PSNI assistant police constable Will Kerr said this represented a "sea change".{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21641237 | work=BBC News | title=Belfast City Hall protest a sea change, says Will Kerr | date=2 March 2013}} On 4 March, loyalist protesters, angered by the arrest of loyalist activist Willie Frazer, interrupted a meeting of the [[Northern Ireland Assembly]].{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21658461 | work=BBC News | title=Loyalist protesters interrupt Stormont Assembly proceedings | date=4 March 2013}} There was a further riot in Newtownabbey on 8 March, when up to 100 flag protesters attacked police with bricks and bottles. A car was also burnt and the office of Alliance leader [[David Ford]] was attacked. Five police officers were injured.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21720384 | work=BBC News | title=Five police officers hurt during rioting in Newtownabbey | date=9 March 2013}} On 14 March, a small loyalist protest was held outside a new leisure centre in Bangor as it was being visited by Sinn Féin's [[Carál Ní Chuilín]].{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Protest-staged-at-Bangor-pool-preview/6fc85700-8942-4dfd-960e-12573a3a6e3c|title=Protest staged at Bangor pool preview|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130315224159/http://www.u.tv/News/Protest-staged-at-Bangor-pool-preview/6fc85700-8942-4dfd-960e-12573a3a6e3c|archivedate=15 March 2013|df=dmy-all}} The same day, a man was charged with sending three hoax bomb warnings by detectives investigating offences linked to the flag protests.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Man-in-custody-over-hoax-alerts/284a1be6-d01e-425c-be66-68dafdf7f399|title=Man in custody over hoax alerts|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130418193314/http://www.u.tv/News/Man-in-custody-over-hoax-alerts/284a1be6-d01e-425c-be66-68dafdf7f399|archivedate=18 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} On 17 March, [[Saint Patrick's Day]], a PSNI officer was injured during rioting in South Belfast. The riot reportedly started when loyalists tried to hold a protest outside pubs in Shaftesbury Square, but were pushed back to Donegall Road by police. Masked loyalists burnt bins on the road and attacked police with bricks and bottles.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Officer-hurt-amid-Belfast-trouble/b3f64c37-7001-4fd8-8646-a0aae4e2cffa|title=Officer hurt amid Belfast trouble|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130419034713/http://www.u.tv/News/Officer-hurt-amid-Belfast-trouble/b3f64c37-7001-4fd8-8646-a0aae4e2cffa|archivedate=19 April 2013|df=dmy-all}} The following day, a St Patrick's Day parade in [[Omagh]] was re-routed after "a huge number" of Union Flags were put up along part of the planned route. Irish nationalist councillors said the flags undermined the plan for a neutral and inclusive parade.{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Row-over-Omagh-St-Patricks-parade/7ff9f096-670c-40ff-9c09-b76ba1ceac15|title=Row over Omagh St Patrick's parade|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303212102/http://www.u.tv/News/Row-over-Omagh-St-Patricks-parade/7ff9f096-670c-40ff-9c09-b76ba1ceac15|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=dmy-all}} ===April 2013=== On 20 April, Belfast City Council rejected a DUP proposal to fly the Union Flag every day on the [[Belfast Cenotaph]] in the grounds of City Hall. Unionist councillors voted in favour of the proposal but Irish nationalist and Alliance councillors voted against it. The [[Royal British Legion]] was also against the proposal, saying it did not want the cenotaph to become politicized.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-22212783 | work=BBC News | title=Union flag dispute: DUP cenotaph proposal fails | date=19 April 2013}} On 24 April, Willie Frazer and Jim Dowson launched a new unionist party known as the [[Protestant Coalition]] at the La Mon Hotel near Belfast.{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/flag-protesters-launch-new-antipolitics-unionist-party-29220215.html|archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20130425052206/http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/flag-protesters-launch-new-antipolitics-unionist-party-29220215.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=25 April 2013|title=Flag protesters launch new 'anti-politics' unionist party|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|accessdate=25 December 2014|df=dmy-all}} ===May 2013=== On 1 May, the DUP officially abandoned its campaign to have the Union Flag flown every day on the cenotaph of Belfast City Hall. A small group of loyalist protesters gathered outside City Hall but there was no trouble.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-22373437 | work=BBC News | title=DUP abandons cenotaph Union flag campaign at Belfast City Hall | date=1 May 2013}} A few days later, the DUP's Sammy Wilson—Northern Ireland's [[Department of Finance and Personnel|Minister of Finance]]—ordered that the Union Flag be flown from all government buildings run by the Department of Finance. The move could cost up to £10,000 and was criticized by Sinn Féin, the SDLP and the Alliance Party.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-22434914 "Sammy Wilson orders union flag to be flown from five buildings"]. BBC News, 7 May 2013. Retrieved 10 May 2013. ===June 2013=== On 13 June, lawyers of a nationalist resident in East Belfast informed the High Court that the PSNI allowed loyalist protesters to stage illegal marches through Belfast City Centre for up to three months, and that all those involved in the marches should have been arrested.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-22875945 | work=BBC News | title=Union flag protests: 'Police allowed illegal marches' | date=12 June 2013}} On 15 June, around 100 loyalists held the now-weekly loyalist flag protest outside Belfast City Hall, which coincided with a large anti-[[G8]] march taking place in the city centre. According to the PUP's Billy Hutchinson, some loyalist protesters felt that the G8 rally was "anti British". Many loyalists booed and jeered whilst speeches were made during the anti-G8 rally.{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/regional/loyalist-flag-protestors-unhappy-at-how-anti-g8-protest-was-facilitated-1-5190155|title=Loyalist flag protestors unhappy at how anti-G8 protest was facilitated|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/regional/video-billy-hutchinson-joins-loyalist-flag-protestors-amid-anti-g8-rally-1-5190232|title=Video: Billy Hutchinson joins loyalist flag protestors amid anti-G8 rally|publisher=|accessdate=25 December 2014}} On 24 June, Belfast City Council voted to raise the armed forces flag on Belfast City Hall for six days after a request from the [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]]. The Alliance Party and unionist parties voted in favour of the motion, whilst nationalist parties such as Sinn Féin voted against the issue.{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/armed-forces-flag-raised-at-belfast-city-hall-29367208.html|title=Armed Forces flag raised at Belfast City Hall|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|accessdate=25 December 2014}} ===August 2013=== On 6 August, the Lord Mayor of Belfast, Sinn Féin councillor [[Máirtín Ó Muilleoir]] was attacked by a large crowd of loyalists during the reopening of Woodvale Park, forcing the event to be abandoned. The mayor had to be escorted from the park by police and the crowd jostled and heckled him whilst throwing missiles at police. He was taken to the Royal Victoria Hospital for a check-up following the incident. Nine PSNI officers were injured.{{cite web|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/community-telegraph/north-belfast/lord-mayor-attacked-by-loyalists-at-woodvale-park-reopening-29478745.html|title=Lord Mayor attacked by loyalists at Woodvale Park re-opening|work=BelfastTelegraph.co.uk|accessdate=25 December 2014}} ===September 2013=== On 21 September, in one of the largest Union Flag protests seen in Belfast since January, more than 3,000 loyalists took part in a march organised by Loyalist Peaceful Protesters. 1,000 loyalists initially gathered at Belfast City Hall, but the march began later than agreed and was thus in breach of a Parades Commission ruling. The number of loyalists in the march grew from 1,000 to 3,000 as it passed through the strongly loyalist [[Shankill Road]] area of West Belfast before ending in the Woodvale area of North Belfast. The parade passed off with no incidents.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-24186090 | work=BBC News | title=More than 3,000 protesters join loyalist parade in Belfast | date=21 September 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.u.tv/News/Loyalist-parade-passes-off-peacefully/66c08428-a2fa-4177-9692-a87161e9825b|title=Loyalist parade passes off peacefully|work=u.tv|accessdate=25 December 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141111160610/http://www.u.tv/News/Loyalist-parade-passes-off-peacefully/66c08428-a2fa-4177-9692-a87161e9825b|archivedate=11 November 2014|df=dmy-all}} ===October 2013=== On 12 October, ''[[Irish News]]'' editor Noel Doran addressed the PUP annual conference, telling the conference that loyalists had "got it wrong" over the flag protests, and that what they were opposing was a democratic decision. He also said that loyalists could learn from organisations like the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] when it came to issues like community pride and reaching out.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-24506398 | work=BBC News | title=Loyalists 'got it wrong' over union flag protests | date=12 October 2013}} On 14 October, First Minister Peter Robinson urged loyalists planning large demonstrations leading up to the Christmas period to think about the possible consequences protests would have on business and jobs.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-24526486 | work=BBC News | title=Robinson urges Christmas union flag protest caution | date=14 October 2013}} ===November 2013=== On 17 November, an Alliance Party office in East Belfast was petrol bombed by loyalists. The Alliance Party's East Belfast MP Naomi Long condemned the attack as "an attack on democracy".{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-24978113 | work=BBC News | title=East Belfast Alliance Party offices petrol bombed | date=17 November 2013}} On 30 November, 1,500 loyalists marched in the city centre to mark one year since Belfast City Council's vote on the Union Flag. The march broke a Parades Commission ruling that it had to leave the city centre by 12:30pm. The march was mostly peaceful, but two PSNI officers were hurt and a man was arrested during scuffles at Crumlin Road.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-25167331 | work=BBC News | title=Police injured during loyalist protest march in Belfast | date=30 November 2013}}http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/video-parade-loyalists-in-belfast-union-flag-protest-breach-parades-commission-ruling-29798279.html{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Reactions== {{expand section|date=January 2013}} [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom]] [[David Cameron]] condemned the protests, saying "violence is absolutely unjustified in those and in other circumstances."{{cite news|title=PM condemns loyalist city rioters|url=http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/local-national/northern-ireland/pm-condemns-loyalist-city-rioters-16249587.html|accessdate=10 January 2013|newspaper=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|date=12 December 2012}} MP Naomi Long said that Northern Ireland is facing "an incredibly volatile and extremely serious situation".{{cite news|title=Naomi Long: 'Death threat' against Alliance party MP|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-20640116|accessdate=10 January 2013|newspaper=BBC News|date=7 December 2012}}{{cite news|last=Johnston|first=Ian|title=Flag fury ignites some of Northern Ireland's worst violence in 15 years|url=http://worldnews.nbcnews.com/_news/2013/01/08/16396021-flag-fury-ignites-some-of-northern-irelands-worst-violence-in-15-years?lite|accessdate=10 January 2013|newspaper=[[NBC News]]}} She also called on Cameron to intervene after a police car outside her office was firebombed with a policewoman escaping injury in early December.{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/12/11/world/europe/northern-ireland-unrest/index.html|title=Policewoman targeted as Northern Ireland tensions rise|author=Laura Smith-Spark and Peter Taggart, CNN|date=11 December 2012|work=CNN|accessdate=25 December 2014}} On 13 January, she said that the party had no regrets in its decision to limit the days the Union Jack would fly over the city hall. First Minister [[Peter Robinson (Northern Ireland politician)|Peter Robinson]] said on 13 January that the political process was the only way forward in developing cordial relations. "We took some difficult decisions, some might say historic decisions to build a shared society in Northern Ireland. I think it is important to tell the wider community in Northern Ireland and our friends in the rest of the United Kingdom that we are not giving up on that. We are very much of the view that we are determined that we build the kind of society where everybody can have a peaceful and stable existence." He and Deputy First Minister [[Martin McGuinness]] were due to meet the British and Irish governments the following week and that Robinson would make it "very clear" about the condemnation of the wider Northern Ireland community for the violence.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-21003296 |title=Union flag protests: Peter Robinson says politicians not 'giving up' |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 13 January 2013|accessdate=2013-01-14}} Robinson added that Northern Ireland's international image was getting damaged by the violence.{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/northern_ireland/newsid_9784000/9784805.stm | work=BBC News | title=Matter of the Day | date=14 January 2013}} In early January 2013, [[Willie Frazer]] said that he and a group of loyalists planned to hold a protest outside the [[Oireachtas|Irish parliament]] building, [[Leinster House]], in [[Dublin]] and "sarcastically" ask for the Irish flag to be taken down. Frazer said "it's a tongue-in-cheek gesture. It's to give Irish people a sense of how we feel. I would be very offended if I was living in Ireland and someone came and asked me to take the flag down. That’s exactly how we feel in Belfast. People keep telling us we're still part of the UK, yet here we are without a flag". In 2006, a march in Dublin, organised by [[Love Ulster]], had [[2006 Dublin riots|sparked riots]].{{cite news |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2013/0105/1224328461481.html |title=Loyalists to request lowering of Tricolour |last=Bradley |first=Una |date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=5 January 2013 |publisher=[[The Irish Times]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/04/ulster-loyalists-dublin-demonstration-flag |title=Ulster loyalists plan Dublin demonstration over union flag |last=McDonald |first=Henry |date=4 January 2013 |accessdate=6 January 2013 |publisher=The Guardian |location=London}} The [[Progressive Unionist Party]]'s [[Billy Hutchinson]] condemned the clashes,{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/01/201311303934796910.html |title=Belfast police injured during rallies |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2013-01-14}} while his colleague, Phil Hamilton, criticised the PSNI for not deploying enough officers to the Short Strand area on 12 January to prevent violence.{{cite news|first=Danielle |last=Moyles |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/sectarian-clashes-in-belfast-follow-latest-flag-protest-3350352.html |title=Sectarian clashes in Belfast follow latest flag protest |publisher=Independent.ie |date=18 November 2010 |accessdate=2013-01-14}} The UDA's [[Jimmy Birch]] told the ''[[BBC]]'''s ''[[Radio Ulster]]'': "Every time they call a tune, we take to the streets. We are wrecking our own areas, we fight with the police, we are burning our own cars and we stop our own people going to work and disrupt our own people's way of life. It is wrong, we need to step back and we need to stop being predictable." The PSNI's Chief Constable [[Matt Baggott]] blamed the violence on the UVF for "orchestrating violence for their own selfish motives. Everyone involved needs to step back. The lack of control is very worrying. The only answer is a political solution. [Otherwise this] will eat into our ability to deal with drugs, into our ability to deal with alcohol issues, and deal with what is a very severe dissident threat."{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/01/07/world/europe/northern-ireland-unrest/index.html|title=Police: Extremist group 'orchestrating violence' in Belfast over Union Jack|author=Peter Taggart and Nic Robertson, for CNN|date=7 January 2013|work=CNN|accessdate=25 December 2014}} [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] called for an end to the protests during a trip to Belfast on 7 December,{{cite news|last=Morris|first=Harvey|title=Flag Protest Reignites Northern Ireland Strife|url=http://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/08/flag-protest-reignites-northern-ireland-strife/|accessdate=10 January 2013|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 January 2013}} In September 2013, business representatives in Belfast revealed that the flag protests had resulted in losses totaling £50 million in the year to July 2013.{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-24144378 | work=BBC News | title=Loyalist flag protests 'factor' in £50m economic losses | date=19 September 2013}} ==See also== ;Other major loyalist protests *[[Ulster Workers' Council strike]] (1974) *[[Ulster Says No]] (1980s) *[[Holy Cross dispute]] (2001) *[[2005 Belfast riots]] *[[2013 Belfast riots]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} revision.text:
'''Community Resources for Justice''' is a Massachusetts-based organization that has worked for over 130 years in social justice in issues like ex-offender re-entry, prison conditions, public safety, and crime prevention. CRJ was formed through the merger of several older organizations in the Boston and New England area, and while most of its work today is focused in the northeastern United States, CRJ is also engaged in work in other states around the nation.
== History == Community Resources for Justice, CRJ, represents the long evolution of criminal justice organizations in Massachusetts. The oldest organization in CRJ's history, the [[New England Society for the Suppression of Vice]] (NESSV), began in 1878 and worked to create legislation that influence public morality and dissuade crime. The NESSV went through a number of name changes as it took on more goals: in 1891 it was renamed the New England [[Watch and Ward Society]] following its new focus on organized crime in the Boston area. In 1957, that became the New England Citizens Crime Commission, focusing further on specific organized crimes groups In 1967 the NECCC turned back to crime prevention under the name Massachusetts Council on Crime and Correction.
Shortly after the NESSV began, a parallel organization, the Massachusetts Prison Association, was founded in 1889. It focused on providing temporary amenities for recently released criminals. In 1937, it broadened scope to provide emergency services to the previously incarcerated. The Massachusetts Prison Association continued to merge with other corrections societies such as the John Howard Society and the Friends of Prisoners in 1940.
Following a loss of funding in 1975, these two larger organizations, the Massachusetts Council on Crime and Correction and the Massachusetts Correctional Association, merged to become the Crime and Justice Foundation. The group’s current name, Community Resources for Justice (CRJ), was created in 1999 after merging with MHHI.
Today, the organization provides services to ex–offenders to re–integrate them into society, and reforming the criminal justice system through public policy development while simultaneously pushing for legislation aiding adults with intellectual disabilities and troubled youth.<ref>Medal, Dominique. [http://www.lib.neu.edu/archives/collect/findaids/m182findbioghist.htm "Historical Note."] Archives and Special Collections Finding Aids: Community Resources for Justice Records. Northeastern University Libraries, Archives and Special Collections, July 2013. Web. Accessed 03 March 2014.</ref>
==Activities== Community Resources for Justice provides services to ex–offenders to re–integrate them into society while also working to reform the criminal justice system through public policy development. CRJ also provides services to adults with intellectual disabilities. CRJ operates group homes, halfway houses, and youth residential facilities in three states.
CRJ's policy work is partially accomplished through its research arm, The Crime and Justice Institute. The Institute collaborates with both regional and national organizations to conduct research and write policy briefs to further inform both scholarly research and public policy.<ref>{{Cite conference| publisher = Bureau of Justice Assistance. US Dept of Justice. Office of Justice Programs. United States of America| last = Pierce-Danford| first = Kristy|author2=Meghan Guevara |author3=Crime and Justice Institute | title = Commonwealth of Virginia: Roadmap for Evidence-Based Practices in Community Corrections| accessdate = 2014-04-10| date = 2010| url = http://www.ncjrs.gov/App/Publications/abstract.aspx?ID=257341}}</ref><ref>{{Cite conference| publisher = National Institute of Corrections| last = Serin| first = Ralph C.|author2=Crime and Justice Institute| title = Evidence-Based Practice: Principles for Enhancing Correctional Results in Prisons| location = Washington, D.C.| date = 2005 |url = http://www.ncjrs.gov/App/Publications/abstract.aspx?ID=248729}}</ref><ref>{{Cite conference| publisher = National Institute of Corrections| last = Fahey| first = Jennifer|author2=Crime and Justice Institute| title = Using Research to Promote Public Safety: A Prosecutor's Primer on Evidence-Based Practice| location = Washington, D.C.; Boston, Ma.| date = 2008 |url = http://www.ncjrs.gov/App/Publications/abstract.aspx?ID=248726}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Publications|url=http://www.crj.org/cji/publications|publisher=Crime and Justice Institute|accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref>
==Recent Work== In 2001, CRJ released a study that showed that corrections overhauls from the late 1980s stripped the focus on rehabilitation from prison life, leaving prisoners unfit to be released. The study states that 62 percent of former state prison inmates will be rearrested within three years of release.<ref>Klein, Rick. (2001-01-15) "Tough Justice is Found Failing Released Convicts Likely to Reoffend: [Third Edition]" Boston Globe. Accessed 2014-03-25</ref> Reporting on the study highlighted the increasing likelihood of recidivism, due to the decline in reintegration programs, and discussed law enforcement's challenge in not just putting criminals in prison, but finding methods to help them stop reoffending.<ref>Bellotti, Michael G. (2001-01-27) "How Norfolk County Aims to Curb Recidivism: [Third Edition]" Boston Globe. Accessed 2014-03-25 2012</ref>
CRJ, along with [[The Boston Foundation]], conducted research with employers, advocates, criminal records officials, landlords, and legislators to give "a first look at the real-world effects of changes to the Criminal Offender Record Information system, widely known by the acronym CORI, which had been lauded by activists as a game-changer for people with criminal records looking to reintegrate into society." CRJ's work helped put the “Ban the Box” provision into place, which prevents employers from asking about criminal records on initial job applications, but their subsequent study showed that while this has allowed more former convicts to get job interviews, it has seldom translated into jobs.<ref>Powers, Martine. (2012-05-24) "Ex-convicts in Massachusetts still face tough sell in job market: Change in records law has not been a panacea." Boston Globe. Accessed 2014-03-25</ref>
