{{Infobox settlement |name = Cummins |official_name = |settlement_type = [[Unincorporated area|Unincorporated community]] |nickname = |motto = |image_skyline = CumminsUnitSignArk.jpg |imagesize = |image_caption = Cummins Unit |image_flag = |image_seal = |pushpin_map = USA Arkansas |pushpin_label_position = |pushpin_map_caption = Location within the state of Arkansas |pushpin_mapsize = |image_map = |map_caption = Location within Lincoln county |subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] |subdivision_name = United States |subdivision_type1 = [[U.S. state|State]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Arkansas]] |subdivision_type2 = [[List of counties in Arkansas|County]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Lincoln County, Arkansas|Lincoln]] |subdivision_type3 = Township |subdivision_name3 = Auburn Township |government_footnotes = |government_type = |leader_title = |leader_name = |leader_title1 = |leader_name1 = |established_title = |established_date = |unit_pref = Imperial |area_footnotes = |area_magnitude = |area_total_km2 = |area_land_km2 = |area_water_km2 = |population_as_of = [[United States Census, 2000|2000]] |population_footnotes = |population_total = |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = [[Central Time Zone (Americas)|Central (CST)]] |utc_offset = -6 |timezone_DST = CDT |utc_offset_DST = -5 |elevation_footnotes = |elevation_ft = 177 |coordinates = {{coord|34|03|05|N|91|35|02|W|scale:10000|display=inline,title}} |postal_code_type = [[ZIP code]]s |postal_code = 71644 |area_code = [[Area code 870|870]] |blank_name = [[Federal Information Processing Standard|FIPS code]] |blank_info = |blank1_name = [[Geographic Names Information System|GNIS]] feature ID |blank1_info = 64050{{cite gnis|id=64050|name=Cummins, Arkansas}}
GNIS for prison building: 82008{{cite gnis|id=82008|name=Cummins State Prison}} |website = |footnotes = }} [[File:CumminsVarnerAerialView.PNG|thumb|Aerial view of the Cummins and [[Varner Unit|Varner]] units, [[U.S. Geological Survey]], February 28, 2001]] [[File:CumminsUnitMap.tiff|thumb|Topographic map of the Cummins Unit, U.S. Geological Survey, July 1, 1984]] The '''Cummins Unit''' (formerly known as ''Cummins State Farm'') is an [[Arkansas Department of Correction]] prison in [[unincorporated area|unincorporated]] [[Lincoln County, Arkansas]], United States,"[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/facilities/facilities2.html#cummins Cummins Unit]." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. Retrieved on August 15, 2010. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100726132908/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/facilities/facilities2.html#cummins |date=July 26, 2010 }} in the [[Arkansas Delta]] region.Nelson, Melissa. "[http://thecabin.net/stories/120901/sta_1209010063.shtml http://thecabin.net/stories/120901/sta_1209010063.shtml Inmates recall prison life before reforms at harsh Cummins Unit]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/6H6iCDLxy?url=http://thecabin.net/stories/120901/sta_1209010063.shtml Archive]) ''[[Associated Press]]'' at the ''[[Log Cabin Democrat]]''. Sunday December 9, 2001. Retrieved on June 3, 2013. It is located along [[U.S. Route 65]], near [[Grady, Arkansas|Grady]], [[Gould, Arkansas|Gould]],Barnes, Royl S. ''Facts, Figures, and Functions of Arkansas State and Local Government''. Hurley Co., 1957. [https://books.google.com/books?id=4GzRAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Women%27s+Reformatory+at+Cummins%22&dq=%22Women%27s+Reformatory+at+Cummins%22&hl=en&ei=u_pzTcyaHoP58Aalv7XsDQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CEUQ6AEwAw 182]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 6, 2011. "Arkansas maintains three penitentiary units: the Women's Reformatory at Cummins near Gould; one near Tucker for white men, known as the Tucker Farm; and the other near Gould, for Negro men and women, known as the Cummins Farm." and [[Varner, Arkansas|Varner]],"[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DM&p_theme=dm&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0ED3D5BC90C67787&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Arkansas killer plans no more appeals He is to die Wednesday in '84 death of trooper]." ''[[Associated Press]]'' at ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]''. April 18, 1995. Retrieved on March 5, 2011. "[...] and he was transferred to the death watch cell at the Cummins Unit near Varner." {{convert|28|mi|km}} south of [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas|Pine Bluff]], and {{convert|60|mi|km}} southeast of [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Little Rock]]."[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PPwgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k3UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4056,2159983&dq=cummins-ark&hl=en Over 20 Convicts Flee State Farm]." ''[[The Day (New London)|The Day]]''. Thursday Afternoon January 20, 1916 (35th Year). 1. Retrieved from [[Google News]] (1 of 14) on March 5, 2011.Feeley, Malcolm M. and Edward L. Rubin. ''Judicial Policy Making and the Modern State: How the Courts Reformed America's Prisons''. [[Cambridge University Press]], 2000. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0S9IQTXjrpQC&pg=PA53&dq=%22Free+Line%22+Cummins&hl=en&ei=dO9yTduIFMyL0QHusoDFAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Free%20Line%22%20Cummins&f=false 53]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 5, 2011. {{ISBN|0-521-77734-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-77734-6}} This [[prison farm]] is a {{convert|16500|acre|ha|adj=on}} correctional facility. The prison first opened in 1902 and has a capacity of 1,725 inmates. Cummins housed Arkansas's male [[Death Row|death row]] until 1986, when it was transferred first to the [[Tucker Maximum Security Unit]]. The State of Arkansas execution chamber is located in the Cummins Unit, adjacent to the location of the male death row, the [[Varner Unit]]."[http://www.arkansas.gov/senate/newsroom/files/junethirteen.doc State Capitol Week in Review]." State of Arkansas. June 13, 2008. Retrieved on August 15, 2010. "Executions are carried out in the Cummins Unit, which is adjacent to Varner." The female death row is located at the [[McPherson Unit]].Haddigan, Michael. "[https://web.archive.org/web/19990508130907/http://www.arktimes.com/990409coverstory.html They Kill Women, Don't They?]" ''[[Arkansas Times]]''. April 9, 1999. Retrieved on August 15, 2010. Cummins is one of the state of Arkansas's "parent units" for male prisoners; it serves as one of several units of initial assignment for processed male prisoners."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/handbook.pdf Guide for Family and Friends] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819032000/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/handbook.pdf |date=August 19, 2010 }}." Arkansas Department of Correction. 2 (4/27). Retrieved on July 18, 2010. ==History== In 1902 the State of Arkansas purchased about {{convert|10000|acre|ha}} of land for $140,000 (${{inflation|USD|140000|1902|r=2}} when adjusted for inflation) to build the Cummins Unit."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/history_gallery.html Prison History and Gallery] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310123329/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/history_gallery.html |date=2011-03-10 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. Retrieved on September 7, 2010. The prison was established during that year,"[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 14 (14/28). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. and prisoners began occupying the site in December."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 23 (23/28). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. The prison occupied the former Cummins and Maple Grove plantations.''[[The Southwestern Reporter]]''. West Publishing Company, 1911. Volume 136. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on September 23, 2011. [https://books.google.com/books?id=24c7AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA663&dq=%22Cummins%22+Farm+%22Maple+Grove%22&hl=en&ei=YBp9TsuZJc3PgAehkdxf&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Cummins%22%20Farm%20%22Maple%20Grove%22&f=false 663]. Then-[[Governor of Arkansas]] [[Jeff Davis (Arkansas governor)|Jeff Davis]] wanted the state to buy a farm in [[Jefferson County, Arkansas|Jefferson County]] owned by Louis Altheimer, a Republican Party leader who was Davis's friend. When the legislature instead purchased the land for Cummins, Davis put up political opposition, trying to force the state to cancel the purchase.Donovan, Timothy Paul and Willard B. Gatewood. ''The Governors of Arkansas: Essays in Political Biography''. [[University of Arkansas Press]], 1995. [https://books.google.com/books?id=--4x2g_9YFsC&pg=PA125&dq=cummins+farm&hl=en&ei=oAZzTdZIx4O2B9Xl8OUO&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=cummins%20farm&f=false 125]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 5, 2011. {{ISBN|1-55728-331-1}}, {{ISBN|978-1-55728-331-3}}. In 1933 Governor [[Junius Marion Futrell]] closed the [[Arkansas State Penitentiary]] ("The Walls"), and some prisoners moved to Cummins from the former penitentiary. Since the establishment of the prison, it had housed African-American men and women. Beginning in 1936, White male prisoners with disciplinary problems were housed at Cummins. As of 1958, most prisoners worked in farming, producing cotton, livestock, and vegetables. The prison, during that year, housed clothing and lumber manufacturing facilities.[[Federal Writers' Project]]. ''Arkansas: A Guide to the State''. US History Publishers, 1958. [https://books.google.com/books?id=CTWMqJNNy5AC&pg=PA277&dq=Varner+Arkansas+School&hl=en&ei=SuJyTbbsF8SctwfnksieCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDUQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=Varner%20Arkansas%20School&f=false 277]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 5, 2011. {{ISBN|1-60354-004-0}}, {{ISBN|978-1-60354-004-9}} In 1951 White female prisoners were moved from the Arkansas State Farm for Women to Cummins."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/history_gallery.html Prison History and Gallery] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110310123329/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/history_gallery.html |date=2011-03-10 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Corrections]]. Retrieved on March 5, 2011. On September 5, 1966, riots occurred at Cummins. 144 prisoners attempted a strike, and [[Arkansas State Police]] ended the strike with [[tear gas]]."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 24 (24/28). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. In 1970 some prisoners asking for segregated housing started a riot, leading to the intervention of state police."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 25 (25/28). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. In 1969 [[Johnny Cash]] performed at a concert in Cummins Unit. He donated his own money so a chapel could be built there."[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p012nt77 Johnny Cash and the Forgotten Prison Blues]." ''[[BBC]]''. Monday January 7, 2013. In 1972 Arkansas's first prison rodeo was held at the Cummins Unit. In 1974 death row inmates, previously at the [[Tucker Unit]], were moved to the Cummins Unit."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Facts Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. July 1, 2005-June 30, 2006. 25 (25/38). Retrieved on August 15, 2010. In 1976 female inmates were moved from the Cummins Unit to the [[Pine Bluff Unit]]. In 1978 a new execution chamber opened at Cummins Unit. In 1983 the Cummins Modular Unit opened."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 26 (26/28). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. In 1986 death row inmates were moved to the [[Maximum Security Unit]]. In 1991 the vocational technology program moved from the Cummins Unit to the [[Varner Unit]]."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 27 (27/28). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. In 2000 Arkansas's first lethal electrified fence, built with inmate labor, opened at the Cummins Unit. A tornado affected the Cummins Unit facility in May 2011. It damaged the dairy facility, the chicken and swine houses, and the employee housing in the Free Line area. The tornado destroyed the prison's three green houses. It also turned over a center pivot irrigation system."[http://adc.arkansas.gov/resources/Documents/December_2012_Advocate_Newsletter.pdf 2012 Billy Max Moore Award Winner: David L. Allen]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/6Fw5vz7E7?url=http://adc.arkansas.gov/resources/Documents/December_2012_Advocate_Newsletter.pdf Archive]) ''The Advocate''. [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. December 2012. p. 9. Retrieved on April 16, 2013. "In May 2011, a tornado hit the Cummins Farm, devastating the employees‘ free line housing, dairy facility, swine and chicken houses; turning over a center pivot irrigation system; and completely destroying three green houses." ===Torture=== In 1968, [[Tom Murton]] alleged that three human skeletons found on the farm were the remains of inmates who had been subjected to torture, prompting a publicized investigation which found "a prison hospital served as torture chamber and a doctor as chief tormentor."von Zielbauer, Paul and Joseph Plambeck. "As Health Care in Jails Goes Private, 10 Days Can Be a Death Sentence." ''[[The New York Times]]''. February 27, 2005. [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/02/27/nyregion/as-health-care-in-jails-goes-private-10-days-can-be-a-death.html?sec=health&pagewanted=4 4]. Retrieved on July 11, 2010. The revelations included allegations of electrical devices connected to the genitalia of inmates. The [[Arkansas Department of Correction|Arkansas State Penitentiary System]] at that time had already been found to have held inmates at the Cummins Unit under conditions rising to the level of unconstitutionally cruel and unusual punishment, in cases tried by the US District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas, among others.
"Certain characteristics of the Arkansas prison system serve to distinguish it from most other penal institutions in this country. First, it has very few paid employees; armed [[Trusty system (prison)|trusties]] ["trusted" inmates, according to the source] guard rank and file inmates and trusties perform other tasks usually and more properly performed by civilian or "free world" personnel. Second, convicts not in isolation are confined when not working, and are required to sleep at night in open dormitory type barracks in which rows of beds are arranged side by side; there are large numbers of men in each barracks. Third, there is no meaningful program of rehabilitation whatever at Cummins; while there is a promising and helpful program at [[Tucker Unit|Tucker]], it is still minimal."{{cite web |url=http://maxpages.com/arklaw/Holt_v_Sarver_II_Part_1 |title=Holt v. Sarver |work=U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas |publisher=Max Pages |year=1970 |accessdate=July 11, 2010}}
==Composition== Cummins has about {{convert|16500|acre|ha}} of land. A white building is and has been referred to the past as the prison's "barracks." The "telephone-pole" style structure serves as a housing unit for prisoners. The building had eight units. In the past, one was reserved for White trustees, one for Black trustees, and others for other prisoners. The housing units were [[racial segregation|racially segregated]].Feeley, Malcolm M. and Edward L. Rubin. ''Judicial Policy Making and the Modern State: How the Courts Reformed America's Prisons''. [[Cambridge University Press]], 2000. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0S9IQTXjrpQC&pg=PA54&dq=%22They+did+not+have+fixed+production+quotas%22&hl=en&ei=y_JyTY76CIiutwfg-p2KDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22They%20did%20not%20have%20fixed%20production%20quotas%22&f=false 54]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 5, 2011. {{ISBN|0-521-77734-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-77734-6}} The prison includes the "Free Line," the prison residences for free world employees, including the warden, several prison officials, and their families; prisoners work as house servants in the Free Line. Children living on the prison property are zoned to the [[Dumas School District]]."[http://dpsd.k12.ar.us/Information/DocketSCAN-1.pdf Maintenance & Transportation Department] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110815054056/http://dpsd.k12.ar.us/Information/DocketSCAN-1.pdf |date=August 15, 2011 }}." [[Dumas School District]]. Retrieved on March 6, 2011."[http://arkansased.org/about/pdf/RevisedSDJuly1_2010.pdf ARKANSAS SCHOOL DISTRICTS AND EDUCATION COOPERATIVES EFFECTIVE JULY 1, 2010]." ([https://www.webcitation.org/5x079ejTq?url=http://arkansased.org/about/pdf/RevisedSDJuly1_2010.pdf Archive]) [[Arkansas Department of Education]]. Retrieved on March 7, 2011. In the past the main entrance to the prison was at the terminus of a road off of the main highway. The main gate consisted of a wooden structure behind a chicken wire fence, which had [[barbed wire]] on top. A [[trusty shooter]] manned the main entrance. In past eras, the prison housed a commissary and did not house educational facilities, prison factories, or medical and dental clinics. The Cummins Unit has an [[electric fence]]."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/newsletters/feb_advocate.pdf Third Electric Fence Installed With Inmate Labor]." ''ADC Advocate''. [[Arkansas Department of Correction]], February 2005. 3 (3/25). Retrieved on March 6, 2011. The Cummins/Varner Volunteer Fire Department provides fire services to the Cummins Unit property."[http://www.fox16.com/content/news/firestations.aspx Fire Department Ratings]." Fox 16. Retrieved on March 5, 2011. The station is inside the Cummins Unit property,"[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/reports/Annual_Report_FY2010.pdf Annual Report Financial Year 2010]." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 3/6. Retrieved on March 8, 2011. along [[Arkansas Highway 388]]."[http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/f?p=154:3:4201127096041160::NO:3:P3_FID,P3_TITLE:2116333%2CCummings%20Volunteer%20Fire%20Station Cummings Volunteer Fire Station]."{{sic}} [[United States Geological Survey]]. Retrieved on May 5, 2011. "State Highway 388, Grady, Ar 71644" In the financial year 2010 the Arkansas Department of Correction spent $81,691 on the fire station. ==Operations== As of 2006, the Cummins Unit has the largest farming operation in the Arkansas Department of Correction system. At Cummins, over {{convert|16000|acre|ha}} of land is devoted to production of crops and farm goods, including [[cash crop]]s, hay, livestock, and vegetables."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 8 (8/38). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. As of 2001 prisoners harvest corn, cotton, and rice from the fields and are supervised by [[prison guards]] mounted on horses. Cummins previously housed the Special Management Barracks, a unit for prisoners with counseling and mental health requirements."[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf 2006 Fact Brochure] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806120702/http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/facts_brochure2006.pdf |date=August 6, 2009 }}." [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. 36 (36/38). Retrieved on March 8, 2011. In 2008 it moved to the [[Randall L. Williams Correctional Facility]]."ADC Acquires Jefferson County Jail." ''[http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/reports/2008_annual_report.pdf Financial Year 2008 Annual Report]''. ([https://www.webcitation.org/5x2de7xFp?url=http://www.adc.arkansas.gov/pdf/reports/2008_annual_report.pdf Archive]) [[Arkansas Department of Correction]]. Retrieved on March 8, 2011. Prisoners at Cummins attend the correctional school system."[http://arkansased.org/about/pdf/directory/11-12_school_dist.pdf SCHOOL/DISTRICT]." [[Arkansas Department of Education]]. Retrieved on September 23, 2011. ==Prisoner life== In the past{{when|date=March 2017}}, each prisoner worked for 10 hours per day, six days per week in the fields. Prisoners were only excused if the outside temperature was below freezing. Some prisoners who were sent to the fields lacked shoes.Feeley, Malcolm M. and Edward L. Rubin. ''Judicial Policy Making and the Modern State: How the Courts Reformed America's Prisons''. [[Cambridge University Press]], 2000. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0S9IQTXjrpQC&pg=PA53&dq=%22Free+Line%22+Cummins&hl=en&ei=dO9yTduIFMyL0QHusoDFAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Free%20Line%22%20Cummins&f=false 53]-[https://books.google.com/books?id=0S9IQTXjrpQC&pg=PA54&dq=%22They+did+not+have+fixed+production+quotas%22&hl=en&ei=y_JyTY76CIiutwfg-p2KDw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22They%20did%20not%20have%20fixed%20production%20quotas%22&f=false 54]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 5, 2011. {{ISBN|0-521-77734-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-77734-6}} Prisoners did not have fixed quotas. Instead they were told to do as much work as possible. Prisoners deemed to be not doing enough work were beaten. Trustee prisoners had authority over other prisoners. At night, all except for two of the free world prison guards left, so trustees kept the order during the night. Prisoners who were not trustees were sub-ranked as "do-pops" and "rankers." In past eras, trustee prisoners were responsible for the institution's perimeter security. During the day, the prison barracks were empty since most prisoners worked on the fields. At night, the two free world employees patrolled the central corridor but did not venture into the barrack units. The trustees, armed with knives, kept the order at night. Some inmates, referred to as "crawlers" and "creepers," stabbed sleeping prisoners. [[Rape by gender#Rape of males by males|Male on male rape]] frequently occurred in the housing units. The prison did not ask trustees to intervene in case of rape, and prison guards rarely intervened. Prisoners did not receive payment for working in the fields. In order to buy items from the commissary, some prisoners worked there. Other prisoners sold their blood; a healthy prisoner was permitted to sell his blood once weekly.Feeley, Malcolm M. and Edward L. Rubin. ''Judicial Policy Making and the Modern State: How the Courts Reformed America's Prisons''. [[Cambridge University Press]], 2000. [https://books.google.com/books?id=0S9IQTXjrpQC&pg=PA55&dq=%22one%27s+blood+at+the+store%22&hl=en&ei=Y_lyTbKfN8TG0QGa-vjEAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22one%27s%20blood%20at%20the%20store%22&f=false 55]. Retrieved from [[Google Books]] on March 5, 2011. {{ISBN|0-521-77734-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-77734-6}} Trustees were allowed to leave and re-enter the prison without undergoing searches, so trustees smuggled in alcohol, illegal drugs, and weapons; they then sold those items within the prison. Trustees usually bought these items from one another, since they had large amounts of money. Non-trustees, including "do-pops" and "rankers," had to pay trustees in order to get food, medicine, access to medical staff, access to outsiders, and protection from arbitrary prison punishments. Therefore non-trustees did not have large reserves of extra money. Education in the Cummins Unit began in 1968, when the [[Gould School District]] started a night program."[http://arkcs.arkansas.gov/aboutus/history.html History And Description Of The Arkansas Correctional School]." [[Arkansas Correctional School]]. Retrieved on March 7, 2011. ==Wardens== *[[T. Don Hutto|Terrell Don Hutto]] (1967-?) ''T. Don Hutto''{{cite web |url=https://lithub.com/the-straight-line-from-slavery-to-private-prisons/ |title=The Straight Line From Slavery to Private Prisons: How Texas Turned Plantations into Prisons |first=Shane |last=Bauer |publisher=[[Literary Hub]] |date=2018 |access-date=October 14, 2018}}{{cite book |title=American Prison: a Reporter's Undercover Journey into the Business of Punishment|pages=368 |first=Shane |last=Bauer |publisher=[[Penguin Publishing Group]] |date=September 18, 2018 |isbn=0735223580}}{{cite web |url=https://www.motherjones.com/crime-justice/2018/09/cummins-prison-farm-photo-essay/ |title=Shockingly Candid Photos Of Life on a 1970s Arkansas Prison Farm: "Just about everyone carrying a gun was a convict" |work=Mother Jones|access-date=October 15, 2018 |date=August 9, 2017 }} Photography by [[Bruce Jackson (scholar)|Bruce Jackson]]{{cite web |url=https://lens.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/05/27/showcase-a-wide-view-of-a-hellish-world/ |title=Showcase: A Wide View of a Hellish World |first=James |last=Estrin |date=May 27, 2009 |access-date=October 15, 2018 |publisher=[[The New York Times]]}} ==Bruce Jackson's prison photography== {{main|Bruce Jackson (scholar)}} In the 1960s, ethnographer [[Bruce Jackson (scholar)|Bruce Jackson]] began taking photographs of prisoners for his research on African American work songs in prison. Jackson had become friends with the assistant warden at the time, T. Don Hutto, and their friendship provided Jackson with access to prisoners resulting in numerous publications. In 2010, Jackson's photo collection from the Cummins Unit was exhibited at the [[Albright-Knox Art Gallery]] and at the Center for Documentary Studies at [[Duke University]].{{cite news |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2010/09/04/bruce-jackson-on-how-he-became-the-dean-of-prison-folklore/ |title=Speakeasy: Bruce Jackson on how he became the dean of prison folklore |publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=September 4, 2010 |first=Steven |last=Kurutz}} ==See also== {{Portal|Arkansas|Prisons}} * [[Trusty system (prison)|Trusty system]] * [[Gates v.
