revision.text: {{Use Indian English|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox organization | logo = [[Image:SAVE Logo.JPG|centre|200px]] |motto=To make academic institutions safe, where students can learn with fun and not with fear.|predecessor=| type = [[Non-governmental organization]] [[Non-profit organization]] |services=Victim Supports , Awareness Campaigns, Consultation to institutions, etc.|formerly=No Ragging Foundation| founder = [[Kushal Banerjee]] | location = [[Kolkata]], [[Delhi]], [[Mumbai]], [[Raipur]], [[Kanpur]], [[Jabalpur]] in [[India]] | Field = [[Human Rights]] [[Education]] [[Non Violence]] | Purpose = Eradication of [[ragging]], and providing support to the victims. | Non-profit_slogan = Learn with Fun! Not with Fear. | homepage = [http://www.no2ragging.org/ no2ragging.org] |abbreviation=SAVE|region=serving entire [[India]]}} '''Society Against Violence in Education (SAVE''') is a non profit organization working for the eradication of [[ragging]] and [[Bullying]] from educational institutions in [[India]].{{cite news | url = http://www.propoor.org/search/details.php?type=npo&npo_id=19206 | title = Organisation Details | publisher = Pro Poor}}{{cite news | url = http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/ml.asp?Ref=VE9JS00vMjAwOC8wNy8xOCNBcjAwNTA1&Mode=Gif&Locale=english-skin-custom | title = Society launches fight against college bullies | publisher = The [[Times of India]]}}{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/Anti-bullying-guidelines-New-orders-mere-replica-of-earlier-ones/articleshow/46547879.cms|title=Anti-bullying guidelines: New orders mere replica of earlier ones - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2016-12-11}} Major field(s) : * [[Human rights]], * [[Non violence]] * [[Education]] SAVE is possibly the first-registered Anti Ragging [[NGO]] in India.{{cite news | url = http://www.wecaretoo.com/Organizations/IND/save.html | title = Society Against Violence in Education (SAVE) | publisher = WeCareToo India}}{{Cite web|url=http://news.fullhyderabad.com/hyderabad-news/anti-ragging-ngo-save-to-help-city-police-1170.html|title=Anti-Ragging NGO 'SAVE' To Help City Police - Hyderabad News on fullhyd.com|website=news.fullhyderabad.com|access-date=2016-12-11}} It is mainly composed of professionals and students from various fieldsTimes of India who volunteer for the cause over and above their regular jobs/studies.{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/difference.html|title=SAVE {{!}} About {{!}} Who we are|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} == Formation == Ragging has been taking a huge toll of innocent lives and careers for long. But there had been no single civil movement against the evil of ragging. There were websites and online groups, from where some conscientious youths gave birth to a non profit organisation, which later came to fame in the name of the "No Ragging Foundation". Later, the No Ragging Foundation was registered as the Society Against Violence in Education (SAVE).{{cite news | url = http://www.karmayog.org/nonprofits/profiles/profiledis.asp?r=240&id=17937 | title = Brief History | publisher =Karmayog }} Amit Sahai Gangwar, a first year student of NIT-Jalandhar lost his life in October 2005. The news was covered by various media - news channels and dailies. This event had a great impact in the formation of this organization.{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/beginning.html|title=SAVE {{!}} About Us {{!}} Why We Started This|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chandigarh/We-were-told-to-do-bad-things/articleshow/1261982.cms|title='We were told to do bad things' - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.tribuneindia.com/2005/20051018/jal.htm|title=The Tribune, Chandigarh, India - JALANDHAR PLUS|website=www.tribuneindia.com|access-date=2016-12-11}} == Mission == '''T'''he Society Against Violence in Education (SAVE) is an impartial, neutral and independent, non-profit organization whose exclusively humanitarian mission is to protect the lives and dignity of students in educational institutions and to provide the victims of 'ragging' with assistance and also to facilitate the eradication of ragging from educational institutions through awareness, advocacy, research and such other avenues. '''I'''t works towards the creation of an environment where students can learn with fun and not with fear. It directs its efforts towards elimination of violence and abuses on innocent freshers while promoting peace and harmony among the senior and the juniors students in academic institutions. == Objectives == Create a strong public mandate against ragging. Device alternative but healthy and humane modes of interaction between seniors & juniors. Unite the isolated protests against ragging under the umbrella of a strong, united movement. Involve the authorities, faculties, students and others in the anti ragging drives. {{cite web | url = http://www.no2ragging.org/aboutus.html | title = Objectives | publisher =Society Against Violence in Education}} == Activities == * Awareness - Encouraging healthy interactions and friendly campuses * Supporting & Empowering the victims and their families * Consultation to educational institutions in implementing anti-ragging measures. * Research and training * Activism, advocacy, etc.{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/awareness.html|title=SAVE{{!}}About Us{{!}}What we do{{!}}Awareness|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/supports.html|title=SAVE{{!}}About Us{{!}}What we do{{!}}Supports & Empowerment|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/otheractivities.html|title=SAVE{{!}}About Us{{!}}What we do{{!}}Other Activities|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} === Awareness - Encouraging healthy interactions and friendly campuses === They spread the awareness against ragging and provide support to the victims. They also promote healthy and humane modes of interactions between the seniors and the juniors. They promote anti-ragging campus units, involving students, class and faculty members.{{cite news | url = http://www.karmayog.org/nonprofits/profiles/profiledis.asp?r=240&id=17937 | title = Services offered | publisher =Karmayog }} SAVE has been arranging awareness events, mainly in educational institutions in different parts of [[India]], involving students, faculty members and other stakeholders.{{Cite news|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/seniors-or-foes-how-ragging-in-our-colleges-is-pushing-students-to-the-edge/story-yC1ouQzfKQslHkJ7DrUsLN.html|title=Seniors or foes? How ragging in our colleges is pushing students to the edge|date=2016-07-04|newspaper=The Hindustan Times|access-date=2016-12-11}} Such events serve to empower and encourage the freshers (potential victims) as well as to promote healthy modes of interactions. The events are used to guide institutional authorities, if required, on effectively implementing anti ragging measures in the campus. Faculties and students have admired such events to be very useful for the cause.{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/testimonials.html|title=SAVE {{!}} About Us {{!}} Testimonials|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} SAVE has arranged events in different parts of the country, for example : [[Kolkata]], [[Delhi]], [[Mumbai]], [[Chennai]], [[Kanpur]], [[Varanasi]], [[Ajmer]], [[Hyderabad]], [[Dehradun]], [[Surat]], [[Pune]], [[Haldia]], [[Durgapur]], [[Howrah]], etc.{{Cite web|url=http://gimt-india.in/news.php?sl=10|title=Global Institute of Management and Technology|website=gimt-india.in|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.vcsdata.com/website.html?webinfo=Haldia-Institute-of-Technology|title=Haldia Institute of Technology Website www.hithaldia.in - Haldia Institute of Technology deals in Institutes - Management|website=www.vcsdata.com|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.dsec.ac.in/sensitization-program.php|title=Dr. Sudhir Chandra Sur Degree Engineering College|website=www.dsec.ac.in|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.jiscollege.ac.in/pdf/JISCE_Event.pdf|title=Event Details|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=JIS College of Engineering|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.aecwb.edu.in/arsp2016/arsp2016.pdf|title=Asansol Engineering College Organizes Anti-Ragging Sensitization Programme|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Asansol Engineering College|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.hetc.ac.in/site/assets/files/1187/hetc2016.pdf|title=Campus News|last=HETC Chronicle|first=|date=|website=|publisher=Hooghly Engineering & Technology College|access-date=2016-12-11}} SAVE has sent thousands of communications to colleges as well. === Supporting & Empowering the victims and their families === For about a decade, SAVE has been supporting the victims of ragging and/or their families in various ways. SAVE volunteers have supported victims in getting their grievances heard. They have played active roles in creating pressure on colleges to take actions and have provided legal and other guidance and assistance to the victims and their families. SAVE keeps in touch with the National (UGC) Anti Ragging Helpline and with its monitoring agency.{{Cite web|url=http://www.behappy.org.in/index.php/site/Ragging|title=beHappy|website=www.behappy.org.in|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kolkata/Two-IIHM-students-arrested-for-ragging/articleshow/23768057.cms|title=Two IIHM students arrested for ragging - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/lucknow/UP-ranks-first-in-ragging-cases/articleshow/29872418.cms|title=UP ranks first in ragging cases - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2016-12-11}} SAVE has filed numerous applications under the [[Right to Information Act, 2005]] with institutions as well as statutory bodies. SAVE legal team, led by advocate Mrs. [[Meera Kaura Patel]] , has even represented victims in the court and before the [[National Human Rights Commission of India]]. In a case involving the [[School of Planning and Architecture, Delhi]], following the directions from the hon'ble court, the police had booked the Dean, Director and Registrar were charged charged under IPC Sections 336, 337, 338 (negligence), 120B (conspiracy), 201 (tampering with evidence), 202, 176 (failing to inform a public authority) and 511 (attempting to commit offence).{{Cite web|url=http://archive.indianexpress.com/news/naveen-kujur-ragging-case-against-spa-for-negligence-and-tampering-with-evidence/1094641/0|title=Naveen Kujur ragging: Case against SPA for negligence and tampering with evidence - Indian Express|website=archive.indianexpress.com|access-date=2016-12-11}} In another case, from [[Thanjavur]], SAVE Legal Team had requested the hon'ble Chief Justice of [[Tamil Nadu]] to take suo motu cognizance of the matter.{{Cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/Juniors-stripped-abused-at-Thanjavur-engineering-college/articleshow/18457252.cms|title=Juniors 'stripped, abused' at Thanjavur engineering college - Times of India|newspaper=The Times of India|access-date=2016-12-11}} 5 engineering students were arrested later.{{Cite web|url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Repository/getFiles.asp?Style=OliveXLib:LowLevelEntityToPrint_TOINEW&Type=text/html&Locale=english-skin-custom&Path=TOICH/2013/02/13&ID=Ar00902|title=Five engg students arrested for ragging|website=epaper.timesofindia.com|access-date=2016-12-11}} In some cases, SAVE has collaborated with the friends and family members of 'victims', who had lost their lives in 'ragging', to arrange memorial events and to demand proper investigation into the cases.The events were clubbed with signature campaigns seeking a comprehensive national anti ragging legislation.{{Cite web|url=http://epaperbeta.timesofindia.com/Article.aspx?eid=31812&articlexml=Ragging-death-Kin-friends-of-student-go-on-24112014006049#|title=The Times Group|website=epaperbeta.timesofindia.com|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite news|url=https://cricket.yahoo.com/photos/kolkata-activists-society-violence-education-save-participate-candle-photo-144746441.html|title=Kolkata: The activists of Society Against Violence in Education (SAVE) participate in candle light march to protest against ragging in Kolkata, on Nov 23, 2014. (Photo: IANS)|newspaper=Yahoo Cricket India|access-date=2016-12-11}} In many cases, the colleges have taken actions based on SAVE's recommendations.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ksrmce.ac.in/Anti_Ragging2013.pdf|title=CIRCULAR|last=KSRMCE/Anti-Ragging/2013-14/2|first=|date=2013-08-19|website=|publisher=K.S.R.M. COLLEGE OF ENGINEERING, KADAPA|page=3|language=English|format=PDF|access-date=2016-12-11}} Some Colleges have been proactively invited SAVE to address their students and faculties. Several colleges have invited SAVE to be part of their anti ragging committee,{{Cite web|url=http://www.nujs.edu/downloads/antiragging-committee-2015.pdf|title=OFFICE ORDER|last=Office Order No. : 591/Reg/15|first=|date=|website=|publisher=The West Bengal National University of Juridical Sciences|access-date=2016-12-11}} however it was not possible for SAVE to accept all such offers, considering its limitations, e.g., financial limitations. === Other Activities === * Guidance : SAVE extends technical guidance to academic institutions and others on curbing the menace of ragging. * Research & Training == Recognition == * Apart from wide acceptance by academic institutions, students, teachers and other stakeholders, SAVE has featured in several news reports by the national print media,{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/printmedia.html|title=SAVE {{!}} About Us {{!}} Who We Are|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} electronic media {{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/electronicmedia.html|title=SAVE {{!}} About Us {{!}} Who We Are|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} as well as by the international media.{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/internationalmedia.html|title=SAVE {{!}} About Us {{!}} Who We Are|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} * SAVE was invited to the famous Indian [[Television]] show [[Satyamev Jayate (TV series)]] season 3, Episode 6 - which is anchored by Indian superstar [[Aamir Khan]] . SAVE's national co-ordinator [[Gaurav Singhal]] (an alumnus of the IIT-Kanpur) represented SAVE on the show.{{Cite web|url=http://www.satyamevjayate.in/when-masculinity-harms-men/episode-6watchvideo.aspx?uid=s3e6-ev-v1&lang=hindi|title=Satyamev Jayate Season 3 {{!}} Episode 6 {{!}} When Masculinity Harms Men|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.pinkvilla.com/tvtags/deepika-padukone/satyamev-jayate-3-big-b-aamir-parineeti-deepika-kangana-get-bashful-about-ob|title=Satyamev Jayate 3: Big B, Aamir, Parineeti, Deepika, Kangana get bashful about objectification of women in cinema!|website=www.pinkvilla.com|access-date=2016-12-11}} Some past victims, who were in contact with SAVE and the father of [[Amit Gangwar]] (the death of whom led to the birth of SAVE) took part in the show. Satyamev Jayate published an article on their website recommending SAVE.{{Cite web|url=http://www.satyamevjayate.in/when-masculinity-harms-men/episode-6article.aspx?uid=s3e6-ar-a4|title=Stop ragging NOW! – When Masculinity harms men {{!}} satyamevjayate.in|access-date=2016-12-11}} * SAVE's honorary legal head, advocate [[Meera Kaura Patel]] has been a key speaker at a national [[Seminar]] organized by the [[National Human Rights Commission of India]] .{{Cite web|url=http://nhrc.nic.in/dispArchive.asp?fno=13563|title=National Human Rights Commission - New Delhi|website=nhrc.nic.in|access-date=2016-12-11}} * Several [[Bollywood]] celebrities, like Mr. [[Salman Khan]], [[Amole Gupte]] , [[Amrita Rao]] and [[Suniel Shetty]] have supported the movement as well.{{Citation|last=no2ragging|title=Celebs Supporting Anti Ragging Movement by SAVE|date=2009-12-19|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rTxYTGOfja4|accessdate=2016-12-11}} * SAVE members have been invited to speak at various institutions as well as at international events.{{Cite web|url=http://sriramanujamissiontrust.info/old%20files/images/events.pdf|title=13th Anniversary Celebrations|last=|first=|date=|year=2013|website=|publisher=Sri Ramanuja Mission Trust, 48, Bazulla Road, T.Nagar, Chennai-17|page=5|format=PDF|access-date=2016-12-11}}{{Cite web|url=http://i-p-o.org/Sri_Ramanuja_Mission_Trust-12Oct2013.htm|title=I.P.O. President Hans Köchler delivers presidential address|website=i-p-o.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} == Tax exemption status == SAVE is registered with the department of [[Income tax in India]] u/s 12AA . Donations to the Society Against Violence in Education qualify for [[Tax exemption]] u/s 80G(5)(vi) .{{Cite web|url=http://www.no2ragging.org/en/donate.html|title=SAVE {{!}} Donate|website=www.no2ragging.org|access-date=2016-12-11}} == See also == *[[Ragging]] *[[Ragging in India]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.no2ragging.org Society Against Violence in Education (SAVE) Website] * [http://www.no2ragging.org/en/reportragging.html Reporting a case of Ragging to SAVE] [[Category:Human rights organisations based in India‎]] [[Category:Anti-bullying campaigns]] [[Category:Educational organisations in India]] [[Category:Ragging]]

{{Infobox U.S. legislation | shorttitle = Tea Importation Act of 1897 | othershorttitles = | longtitle = An Act to prevent the importation of impure and unwholesome tea. | colloquialacronym = | nickname = | enacted by = 54th | effective date = May 1, 1897 | public law url = http://legisworks.org/congress/54/session-2/chap-358.pdf | cite public law = 54-358 | cite statutes at large = {{usstat|29|604}} | acts amended = | acts repealed = | title amended = [[Title 21 of the United States Code|21 U.S.C.: Food and Drugs]] | sections created = {{Usc-title-chap|21|2}} § 41 et seq. | sections amended = | leghisturl = | introducedin = Senate | introducedbill = {{USBill|54|S.|3725}} | introducedby = [[David B. Hill]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]–[[New York (state)|NY]]) | introduceddate = | committees = [[United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation|Senate Commerce]], [[United States House Committee on Ways and Means|House Ways and Means]] | signedpresident = [[Grover Cleveland]] | signeddate = March 2, 1897 }} '''Tea Importation Act of 1897''' was a United States [[public law]] forbidding the [[import]] of [[tea]] into the United States with excessive levels of [[Fluoride toxicity|fluoride]], [[Toxic heavy metal|heavy metals]], [[oxalate]], and [[pesticide]]s. The [[Act of Congress]] established a uniform standard of purity and quality while attempting to achieve the optimal [[health effects of tea]] and [[phenolic content in tea]].{{cn|date=January 2017}} The statute declared it unlawful to import into the United States "any merchandise as tea which is inferior in purity, quality, and fitness for consumption to the standards kept at customhouses..."<ref name = "21 U.S.C. §§ 301">21 U.S.C. §§ 301 et seq</ref> For nearly a century, Congress provided that no imported tea could enter the United States unless federal tea-tasters decided that it measured up to preselected standard samples. The law restricted the [[International trade]] of [[camellia sinensis]].{{cn|date=January 2017}}
The 1897 [[statute]] superseded the Spurious Tea Importation Act of 1883.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://legisworks.org/congress/47/session-2/chap-64.pdf |title=Spurious Tea Importation Act of 1883 ~ P.L. 47-64 |date=March 2, 1883 |series=22 Stat. 451 ~ House Bill 7486 |publisher= Legis★Works}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://research.archives.gov/id/5716295 |title=Spurious Tea Importation Act of 1883 ~ House Bill 7486 |date=March 2, 1883 |series=P.L. 47-64 ~ 22 Stat. 451 |publisher= National Archives and Records Administration}}</ref>
The act was on the books for 99 years before its repeal in 1996.<ref>Act of March 2, 1897, ch. 358, 29 Stat. 604 (codified as amended at 21 U.S.C. Sec. 41-50 (1994))</ref> After repeal, the [[Food and Drug Administration]] still regulates the quality of tea imported to the United States under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of 1938.<ref name = "21 U.S.C. §§ 301" />
==Provisions of the Act== The United States statute had twelve sections and authorized the [[United States Secretary of the Treasury]] to implement the law.
As codified just before its repeal, the Act instructed the [[Secretary of Health and Human Services]] each year "to appoint a board, to consist of seven members, each of whom shall be an expert in teas, and who shall prepare and submit to him standard samples of tea."<ref>21 U.S.C. Sec. 42</ref> In accordance with the board of experts' recommendations, the Secretary was instructed to "fix and establish uniform standards of purity, quality, and fitness for consumption of all kinds of teas imported unto the United States" and to deposit samples of these standards in the [[customhouse]]s of various ports of entry. Tea importers were required to submit samples of their product for comparison with the standard samples kept at the customhouses. The imported samples were then tested "by a duly qualified examiner," who would test "the purity, quality, and fitness for consumption of the... [imported tea samples] according to the usages and customs of the tea trade, including the testing of an [[infusion]] of the same in boiling water and, if necessary, chemical analysis."
==Board of Tea Appeals== '''The Board of Tea Appeals''' was a [[United States]] [[Government agency|federal agency]] under the jurisdiction of the Food and Drug Administration. From its establishment in 1897 until its abolishment in 1996, it adjudicated the claims of [[tea]] importers whose products were denied entry into the United States by federal tea-tasters. The Board was authorized to permit delivery or order destruction or exportation of substandard teas.<ref>[http://uscode.house.gov/download/pls/21C2.txt Office of the Law Revision Counsel Ch 2 Tea] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060911112021/http://uscode.house.gov/download/pls/21C2.txt |date=September 11, 2006 }}</ref>
==Amendment and Repeal of 1897 Act== The Tea Importation Act of 1908 amended the 1897 public law permitting the import of tea siftings, tea sweepings, or tea waste for the [[Extraction (chemistry)|extraction]] of [[caffeine]] or theine, and other [[Phenolic content in tea|chemical products]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://legisworks.org/congress/60/publaw-117.pdf |title=Tea Importation Act of 1908 ~ P.L. 60-117 |date=May 16, 1908 |series=35 Stat. 163 ~ Senate Bill 514 |publisher= Legis★Works}}</ref> The 1897 Act was repealed with the United States 104th Congressional session enactment of the Federal Tea Tasters Repeal Act of 1996.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-104publ128/pdf/PLAW-104publ128.pdf |title=Federal Tea Tasters Repeal Act of 1996 ~ P.L. 104-128 |date=April 9, 1996 |series=110 Stat. 1198 ~ House Bill 2969 |publisher=U.S. Government Printing Office}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/104th-congress/house-bill/2969 |title=H.R. 2969 ~ Federal Tea Tasters Repeal Act of 1996 |date=February 23, 1996 |series=P.L. 104-128 ~ 110 Stat. 1198 |publisher=Congress.gov}}</ref>
==Sections of the act== The twelve sections of the original act:
:''21 U.S.C. § 1'' ~ Prohibit the unlawful importation of substandard tea :''21 U.S.C. § 2'' ~ Establishment of a board of experts on tea :''21 U.S.C. § 3'' ~ Establishment of tea purity standards :''21 U.S.C. § 4'' ~ Bonds of exporters, examination of imported tea, and importation at ports without examiners :''21 U.S.C. § 5'' ~ Delivery permits, reexamination, retention of substandard tea :''21 U.S.C. § 6'' ~ Referral of disputes to [[Board of Tea Appeals]] to permit delivery, order destruction, or exportation of substandard tea :''21 U.S.C. § 7'' ~ Examiners and examination according to useage of trade :''21 U.S.C. § 8'' ~ Reexaminations including findings by examiner and assistance of experts :''21 U.S.C. § 9'' ~ Reimporting rejected tea and forfeitures for violation of provisions :''21 U.S.C. § 10'' ~ Issuance of regulations :''21 U.S.C. § 11'' ~ Tea on shipboard subject to former 1883 law :''21 U.S.C. § 12'' ~ Repeal of 1883 Act

{{Infobox book | name = The Imperial Cruise | image = File:The imperial cruise cover.jpg | caption = Front cover | author = [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]] | country = United States | language = English | genre = history
non-fiction
[[historical revisionism]] | publisher = [[Back Bay Books]] / [[Little, Brown and Company]] | release_date = November 24, 2009{{cite web|url=http://www.tower.com/imperial-cruise-secret-history-empire-war-james-bradley-hardcover/wapi/113427028 |title=Books: The Imperial Cruise: A Secret History of Empire and War (Hardcover) by James Bradley (Author) |publisher=Tower.com |date=2009-11-24 |accessdate=2011-05-31}} | media_type = print (hardback & paperback) | pages = 400 pp (paperback) | isbn = 978-0-316-00895-2 |isbn_note= (hardback) / {{ISBN|978-0-316-01400-7}} (paperback) }} '''''The Imperial Cruise''''' is a non-fiction book authored by [[James Bradley (author)|James Bradley]]. In the book Bradley examines American policy in the Pacific during the [[presidency of Theodore Roosevelt]], and a surrounding a secret diplomatic/Congressional mission to Asia conceived by Roosevelt which would affect United States involvement in Asia. The material also covers a wide array of other cultural factors that loosely relate to this, the largest diplomatic delegation ever sent to Asia in U.S. history.{{cite book | title = The Imperial Cruise | last = Bradley | first = James | date = November 2010 | publisher = Back Bay Books | isbn = 978-0-316-01400-7 | page = 388 }} The book asserts that Roosevelt's diplomatic mistakes constituted the original encouragement for the Japanese imperialism that ultimately backfired on the United States and led to the [[Pacific War|war in the Pacific]],{{cite web|last=Maslin |first=Janet |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/19/books/19book.html |title=Books of The Times - James Bradley’s ‘Imperial Cruise’ - Queasy Side of Roosevelt’s Diplomacy - Review |location=Japan |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2009-11-18 |accessdate=2011-05-31}} and acted as a catalyst in the fomentation of many subsequent events in Asia, including the [[Chinese Communist Revolution]], the [[Korean War]], and even the current state of U.S.-Asia affairs today in the 21st century.Bradley, James. ''The Imperial Cruise''. In support of the book's themes, Bradley presents evidence in the form of Roosevelt's personal letters and pictures. Nevertheless, the book's historical accuracy has proved controversial, with some historians, specialists and reviewers pointing out Bradley's methods as faulty. ==Synopsis== The book centers on the diplomatic mission of the {{SS|Manchuria|1903|6}} sent by President Theodore Roosevelt in the summer of 1905. On board was the largest diplomatic mission delegation in U.S. history, including some of the highest profile political figures of the time. They included Secretary of War (and future President) [[William Howard Taft]]; Roosevelt's daughter, [[Alice Roosevelt Longworth|Alice Roosevelt]]; her future husband, Congressman (and later Speaker of the House) [[Nicholas Longworth]]; along with 29 other members of the House and Senate, and their wives; and an array of additional high-ranking military and civilian officials.''The Imperial Cruise'' - p. 2. After his initial description and introduction of the ''SS Manchuria's'' voyage, the author explores brief excerpts of the history behind the period's American domestic and foreign policy, elaborating on its influence, motivation, and consequences, specifically in regard to [[Japan–United States relations|American-Japanese]], [[Sino-Japanese relations|Sino-Japanese]], and [[Japan–Russia relations|Russo-Japanese]] relations. More broadly, Bradley explores his contention relating to how deep-set [[W.A.S.P. (band)|WASP]]"White Anglo-Saxon Protestant" - In 1906, Roosevelt wrote: "The world would have halted had it not been for the Teutonic conquests of alien lands." - Bradley, James. ''The Imperial Cruise'' - p. 25. . biases and racially deterministic philosophiesDyer, Thomas G. "Theodore Roosevelt and the Idea of Race" Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University, 1960. fueled and undergirded virtually all U.S. foreign and domestic policy-making in that era pertaining to U.S. relations with other nations and to populations of other racial, cultural or religious heritages. This included virtually all peoples of non-[[Teutons|Teutonic]] [[Anglo-Saxon]] descent, and resulted, for example, in the slaughter of more than 250,000 [[Filipinos]] during the U.S. colonial take-over of the [[Philippines]].''The Imperial Cruise'' - p.22. It is Bradley's contention that the actions of one Roosevelt, and the diplomatic cruise in the summer of 1905, lit that fuse that would doom more than 100,000 U.S. military to die in the Pacific theater decades later under another Roosevelt in the 1940s.''The Imperial Cruise'' - p.168. Through what Bradley describes as their "bumbling diplomacy", he describes how Teddy Roosevelt and his emissary Taft turned previously friendly Japanese sentiment, against the United States.''The Imperial Cruise'' - p.322. ==Critical reception== ''The Imperial Cruise'' has received mixed reviews. Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'' Review of Books, Janet Maslin noted that "''The Imperial Cruise'' is startling enough to reshape conventional wisdom about Roosevelt's presidency". At the same time, she criticized the author, which favors "broad strokes and may at times be overly eager to connect historical dots,but he also produces graphic, shocking evidence of the attitudes that his book describes."name="newyorktimesreview" ''[[USA Today]]'' was neutral, calling it useful for readers who think that history "is the story of good guys and bad guys", and expressing disappointment with the "relentlessly sarcastic" tone and lack of ambiguity. Chiefly, ''USA Today'' noted an unresolved historical issue at the heart of Bradley's thesis, which argues that Japan was inspired by the visit of the U.S. delegation to pursue imperialistic expansion in 1905, when Japan had no such ambitions. Bradley's book argues that it was the American delegation's seminal influence that both inspired Japanese imperialistic adventurism, including eventually and ironically, their [[attack on Pearl Harbor]], and also continuing tensions between the United States and Asian nations.''The Imperial Cruise'' - p.5. While Bradley argues that "The U.S. Army had brought the Aryan to the Pacific coast", ''USA Today'' cited his failure to explain how "in the 1930s, imperial Japan would act on the secret words of a man dead for more than a decade and out of office since 1909."{{cite web|last=Hampson |first=Rick |url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/books/reviews/2009-11-25-imperialcruise25_ST_N.htm |title='Imperial Cruise' hits rough waters in attack of Roosevelt |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date=2009-11-24 |accessdate=2011-05-31}} Scholars such as M. Patrick Cullinane of Northumbria University rejects Bradley's main themes as extreme exaggerations based on misinterpretations. He says the treatment of Roosevelt is "grossly unfair" and Bradley ignores the Asian role in the multiple catastrophes blamed on Roosevelt.M. Patrick Cullinane, "James Bradley, The Imperial Cruise...." ''Journal of American Studies'' 45.#1 (2011): E5. [http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8195765&fileId=S0021875810002264 online] Professor William N. Tilchin of Boston University attacks "Bradley's stupendously faulty analysis, ''The Imperial Cruise'' is a profoundly ignorant book even on the basic level of undisputed objective facts." He writes: :The pomposity and the utter absurdity of ''The Imperial Cruise'' are starkly previewed in a single sentence in the book's sixth paragraph: "This book reveals that behind [Roosevelt's] Asian whispers that critical summer of 1905 was a very big stick—the bruises from which would catalyze World War II in the Pacific, the Chinese Communist Revolution, the Korean War, and an array of tensions that inform our lives today." (24) This grandiose, ridiculous assertion is made without even the remotest understanding of Theodore Roosevelt's diplomacy or of either U.S. foreign policy or internal Japanese developments between 1905 and 1941. The central notion that TR "gave" Korea to Japan—when Japan actually had previously secured control of Korea—is preposterous and, moreover, completely fails to explore the president's main alternative to endorsing Japanese rule: TR could have gratuitously antagonized Japan over this matter, thereby endangering the U.S. position in the Philippines and, more generally, signaling the Japanese that they should view the United States as a hostile rival.William N. Tilchin, "James Bradley's ''The Imperial Cruise'' is an Outrage, Pure and Simple," ''Theodore Roosevelt Association Journal'' (2010) 31#4 pp. 39-45 [http://hnn.us/article/140862#sthash.mKgLbR7F.dpuf online] Currently, ''The Imperial Cruise'' holds a 3.55/5{{cite web|url=http://www.librarything.com/work/9048949 |title=The Imperial Cruise: A Secret History of Empire and War by James Bradley |publisher=LibraryThing |date= |accessdate=2011-05-31}} rating on [[LibraryThing]]. ==Other works by James Bradley== *''[[Flags of Our Fathers]]'' (with Ron Powers). New York: Bantam, 2000. {{ISBN|0-553-11133-7}} *''[[Flyboys: A True Story of Courage]]''. Boston: Little, Brown & Co., 2003. {{ISBN|0-316-10584-8}} ==See also== * [[Alice Roosevelt Longworth|Alice Roosevelt]] * [[Japan–United States relations]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Imperial Cruise}} [[Category:2009 books]] [[Category:21st-century history books]] [[Category:History books about the United States]] [[Category:History books about the Empire of Japan]] [[Category:History books about politics]] [[Category:History books about World War II]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} [[File:Turkish courts-martial-Memleket-April-8-1919-Courtroom.png|thumb|A court session of the Turkish courts-martial of 1919–20. CUP's leaders, Enver, Djemal, Talaat, among others, were ultimately sentenced to death under charges of wartime profiteering, and massacres of both Armenians and Greeks.<ref name="Herzig 2005"/><ref name="Andreopoulos 1997"/><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Heller|editor1-first=Kevin Jon|editor2-last=Simpson|editor2-first=Gerry|title=The hidden histories of war crimes trials|date=2013|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0199671141|pages=296–300|edition=First edition.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MXysAQAAQBAJ}}</ref>]] '''Turkish courts-martial of 1919–20''' were [[courts-martial]] of the [[Ottoman Empire]] that occurred soon after the [[Armistice of Mudros]], in the [[aftermath of World War I]]. The leadership of the [[Committee of Union and Progress]] and selected former officials were charged with several charges including [[Subversion (politics)|subversion]] of the [[Ottoman constitution of 1876|constitution]], [[War profiteering|wartime profiteering]], and the massacres of both [[Armenian Genocide|Armenians]] and [[Greek genocide|Greeks]].<ref>{{cite book | last = Akçam | first = Taner | authorlink = Taner Akçam | language = German | title = Armenien und der Völkermord: Die Istanbuler Prozesse und die Türkische Nationalbewegung | place = Hamburg | publisher = Hamburger Edition | year = 1996 | page = 185}}</ref> The court reached a verdict which sentenced the organizers of the massacres, Talat, Enver, Cemal and others to death.<ref name="Herzig 2005">{{cite book|last=Herzig|first=edited by Edmund|title=The Armenians past and present in the making of national identity|year=2005|publisher=RoutledgeCurzon|location=Abingdon, Oxon, Oxford|isbn=0203004930|author2=Kurkchiyan, Marina }}</ref><ref name="Andreopoulos 1997">{{cite book|last=Andreopoulos|first=ed. by George J.|title=Genocide : conceptual and historical dimensions|year=1997|publisher=Univ. of Pennsylvania Press|location=Philadelphia, Pa.|isbn=0812216164|edition=1. paperback print.}}</ref>
Since there were no international laws in place under which they could be tried, the men who orchestrated the genocide escaped prosecution and traveled relatively freely throughout [[Germany]], [[Italy]], and [[Central Asia]].<ref name=samantha>[[Samantha Power|Power, Samantha]]. "[[A Problem from Hell]]", p. 16-17. Basic Books, 2002.</ref> This led to the formation of [[Operation Nemesis]], a covert operation conducted by Armenians during which Ottoman political and military figures who fled prosecution were assassinated for their role in the Armenian Genocide.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bartrop|first1=Paul R.|last2=Jacobs|first2=Steven Leonard|title=Modern Genocide|date=2014|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=1610693647|page=89|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JB4UBgAAQBAJ}}</ref>
The Turkish courts-martial were forced to shut down during the resurgence of the [[Turkish National Movement]] under [[Mustafa Kemal]]. Those who remained serving their sentences were ultimately pardoned under the newly established Kemalist government on 31 March 1923.<ref name="huberta">{{cite book|last1=von Voss|first1=Huberta|title=Portraits of hope : Armenians in the contemporary world|date=2007|publisher=Berghahn Books|location=New York|isbn=1845452577|page=320|edition=1st English|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_fW9BAAAQBAJ}}</ref>
==Background==
===World War I=== {{see also|World War I}} Following the reportage by US Ambassador to the Ottoman Empire [[Henry Morgenthau, Sr.]] of the [[Armenian resistance during the Armenian Genocide]] at the city of [[Defense of Van (1915)|Van]], the [[Triple Entente]] formally warned the [[Second Constitutional Era|Ottoman Empire]] on 24 May 1915 that:
{{quote |In view of these new crimes of [[Turkey]] against humanity and civilization, the [[Allies of World War I|Allied Governments]] announce publicly to the [[Sublime Porte]] that they will hold personally responsible for these crimes all members of the [[Imperial Government (Ottoman Empire)|Ottoman Government]], as well as those of their agents who are implicated in such massacres".<ref>{{Citation | url = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/cpquery/T?&report=hr933&dbname=106& | title = Affirmation of the United States Record on the Armenian Genocide Resolution | author = 106th Congress, 2nd Session, House of Representatives | publisher = The Library of Congress | year = 1915}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c109:H.RES.316 | publisher = The Library of Congress | title = Affirmation of the United States Record on the Armenian Genocide Resolution (Introduced in House of Representatives) | author = 109th Congress, 1st Session}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d109:HE00316: | title = H.RES.316 | date = June 14, 2005 | publisher = Library of Congress}}. 15 September 2005 House Committee/Subcommittee:International Relations actions. Status: Ordered to be Reported by the Yeas and Nays: 40–7.</ref><ref>{{Citation | chapter = Crimes Against Humanity | number = 23 | title = British Yearbook of International Law | year = 1946 | page = 181}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.armenian-genocide.org/Affirmation.160/current_category.7/affirmation_detail.html | publisher = Armenian Genocide | title = Original source of the telegram sent by the Department of State, Washington containing the French, British and Russian joint declaration}}.</ref><ref name= "nazi">William S. Allen, ''The Nazi Seizure of Power: The Experience of a Single German Town 1922–1945'', Franklin Watts; Revised edition (1984).</ref><ref>William A. Schabas, ''Genocide in International Law: The Crimes of Crimes'', Cambridge University Press, 2000, pp. 16–17</ref>}} [[File:İkdam, 4 Kasım 1918.jpg|thumbnail|The front page of the Ottoman newspaper İkdam on 4 November 1918 after the Three Pashas fled the country following World War I. It reads: "Their response to eliminate the Armenian problem was to attempt the elimination of the Armenians themselves."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bedrosyan|first1=Raffi|title=The Implications of Turkey’s Renewed War on the Kurds|url=http://armenianweekly.com/2016/01/07/the-implications-of-turkeys-war/|agency=Armenian Weekly|date=7 January 2016}}</ref>]] In the months leading up to the end of [[World War I]], the Ottoman Empire had undergone major restructuring. In July of that 1918, Sultan [[Mehmed V]] died and was succeeded by his half-brother [[Mehmed VI]]. The Ministers of the [[Committee of Union and Progress]], including the [[Three Pashas]] who ran the [[Imperial Government (Ottoman Empire)|Ottoman Government]] between 1913 and 1918, had resigned from office and fled the country soon afterwards. Successful Allied offensives in [[Macedonian Front|Salonika]] posed a direct threat to the Ottoman capital of [[Constantinople]].<ref name=findley>Findley, Carter Vaughn. ''Turkey, Islam, Nationalism, and Modernity''. Yale University Press, 2010, p. 215</ref> Sultan Mehmed VI appointed [[Ahmed Izzet Pasha]] to the position of [[Grand Vizier of the Ottoman Empire|Grand Vizier]] and tasked him with the assignment of seeking an armistice with the Allied Powers and ending Ottoman involvement in the war.<ref name=lewis>Lewis, Bernard. ''The Emergence of Modern Turkey''. Oxford University Press, 1968, p.239</ref>
On 30 October 1918, an [[Armistice of Mudros|armistice]] was signed between the Ottomans, represented by the Minister of the Navy [[Rauf Orbay]], and the Allies, represented by British Admiral Sir [[Somerset Gough-Calthorpe]]. The armistice essentially ended Ottoman participation in the war and required the Empire's forces to stand down although there still remained approximately one million soldiers in the field and small scale fighting continued in the frontier provinces into November 1918.<ref name=findley/>
===Surrender of Constantinople===
{{further|Armistice of Mudros|Occupation of Constantinople}} In November 1918, Britain appointed [[Admiral]] Sir [[Somerset Gough-Calthorpe]] as High Commissioner and [[Rear-Admiral]] [[Richard Webb (Royal Navy officer)|Richard Webb]] as Assistant High Commissioner in [[Constantinople]].<ref name=malta/> A French brigade later entered Constantinople on November 12, 1918, and the British Troops first entered the city on November 13, 1918. Early on December in 1918, Allied troops occupied sections of Constantinople and set up a military administration.
The [[US Secretary of State]] [[Robert Lansing]] summoned the representatives of the Ottoman Empire, Sultan [[Mehmed VI]] and [[Grand Vizier]] [[Damat Ferid Pasha]] (a founding member of the [[Freedom and Accord Party]] or ''Liberal Union Party''). The [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]] established "The Commission on Responsibilities and Sanctions" in January 1919.
On January 2, 1919, Gough-Calthorpe requested from the Foreign Office authority to obtain the arrest and handing over of all those responsible for the incessant breaches of the terms of the Armistice and the continued ill-treatment of Armenians. Calthorpe got together a staff of dedicated assistants, including a notable anti-Turkish Irishman, [[Andrew Ryan (Irish politician)|Andrew Ryan]], later Sir, who in 1951 published his memoirs. In his new role as the chief [[Dragoman]] of the [[British High Commission]] and Second Political Officer, he found himself in charge of the ''Armenian question''. He proved instrumental in the arrest of a large number of the (later to be) Malta deportees. These fell broadly into three categories: Those still breaching the terms of the armistice, those who had allegedly ill-treated Allied prisoners-of-war and those responsible for excesses against Armenians, in Turkey itself and the Caucasus. Calthorpe asked for a personal interview with [[Mustafa Reşit Pasha (1858-1924)|Reshid Pasha]], Ottoman Minister of Foreign Affairs, to impress on him how Britain viewed the Armenian affair and the ill-treatment of POWs as "most important" deserving "the utmost attention". Two days later Calthorpe formally requested the arrest of seven leaders of the Committee of Union and Progress (CUP). While between 160 and 200 people were arrested, another 60 suspected of participating in the massacre of Armenians remained at large.<ref name=malta>[http://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2012-04-19/news/turkeys-eu-minister-judge-giovanni-bonello-and-the-armenian-genocide-claim-about-malta-trials-is-nonsense-308828/ Turkey’s EU Minister, Judge Giovanni Bonello And the Armenian Genocide - ‘Claim about Malta Trials is nonsense’]. [[The Malta Independent]]. 19 April 2012. Retrieved 10 August 2013</ref>
==Courts-martial==
=== Establishment === {{See also|Armenians in the Ottoman Empire}} [[File:Turkish courts-martial Courtroom.jpg|thumb|A session of the Turkish courts-martial on 3 April 1919.]] The courts-martial were established on April 28, 1919 while the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919]] was ongoing. An inquiry commission was established, called the "Mazhar Inquiry Commission", which was invested with extraordinary powers of subpoena, arrest, et cetera, through which the war criminals were summoned to trial. This organization secured Ottoman documents from many provinces of the Ottoman Empire.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} Sultan [[Mehmet VI]] and [[Grand Vizier]] [[Damat Ferid Pasha]], as representatives of the [[Ottoman Empire]] during the [[Second Constitutional Era]] were summoned to the Paris Peace Conference. On 11 July 1919, [[Damat Ferid Pasha]] officially confessed to massacres against the [[Armenians in the Ottoman Empire]] and was a key figure and initiator of the war crime trials held directly after World War I to condemn to death the chief perpetrators of the [[Armenian Genocide|genocide]].<ref>Gunnar Heinsohn: Lexikon der Völkermorde. Reinbek 1998. Rowohlt Verlag. p. 80 (German)</ref><ref>[http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CREC-1996-04-24/html/CREC-1996-04-24-pt1-PgH3791-2.htm RECOGNIZING THE 81ST ANNIVERSARY OF THE ARMENIAN GENOCIDE]. [[United States Government Printing Office]]. Retrieved 21 January 2013</ref><ref>[http://www.qgazette.com/weekinreview/75979 Armenian Genocide Survivors Remember]. Queens Gazette. Retrieved 21 January 2013</ref>
The [[Imperial Government (Ottoman Empire)|Ottoman Government]] in Constantinople (represented by [[Damat Ferid Pasha]]), foisted the blame on a few members of the [[Committee of Union and Progress]] and long-time rivals of his own [[Freedom and Accord Party]], which would ensure that the Ottoman Empire received a more lenient treatment during the [[Paris Peace Conference, 1919|Paris Peace Conference]].<ref>{{Citation | first = Vahakn N | last = Dadrian | contribution = The Documentation of the World War I Armenian Massacres in the Proceedings of the Turkish Military Tribunal | title = International Journal of Middle East Studies | number = 23 | year = 1991 | page = 554}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | first = Vahakn N | last = Dadrian | contribution-url = http://hgs.oxfordjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/11/1/28 | contribution = The Turkish Military Tribunal's Prosecution of the Authors of the Armenian Genocide: Four Major Court-Martial Series | publisher = Oxford Journals | title = [[Holocaust and Genocide Studies]] | number = 11 | year = 1997 | page = 31}}.</ref> The trials helped the party (also called the ''Liberal Union party'') root out the [[Committee of Union and Progress]] from the political arena.<ref name="Grothusen">{{cite book | last = Detlev Grothusen | first = Klaus | authorlink = Klaus Detlev Grothusen | title = Die Türkei in Europa: Beiträge des Südosteuropa-arbeitskreises der… | publisher = Berghahn Books | language = German | year = 197 | page= 35}}</ref> On 23 July 1919, during the [[Erzurum Congress]], General [[Kâzım Karabekir]] was issued a direct order from the Sultanate to place [[Mustafa Kemal Ataturk]] and [[Rauf Orbay]] under arrest and assume Kemal's position as Inspector-General of the [[Six vilayets|Eastern Provinces]]. He defied the [[Imperial Government (Ottoman Empire)|government in Constantinople]] and refused to carry out the arrest.<ref name=lewis/>{{rp|248}}
At that time Turkey had two competing governments in [[Constantinople]] and [[Ankara]]. The [[Imperial Government (Ottoman Empire)|government]] in Constantinople supported the Turkish trials with more or less seriousness depending on the current government. While Grand Vizier [[Damat Ferid Pasha]] (4 March - 2 October 1919 and again 5 April - 21 October 1920) stood behind the prosecuting body, the government of Grand Vizier [[Ali Riza Pasha]] (2 October 1919 – 2 March 1920) barely made a mention of the legal proceedings against the war criminals.<ref>Taner Akçam: ''A Shameful Act: The Armenian Genocide and the Question of Turkish Responsibility'', Metropolitan Books, New York 2006 {{ISBN|978-0-8050-7932-6}}, p. 296</ref> The trials had also blurred the crime of participation in the [[Turkish National Movement]] with the crime of the [[Armenian Genocide]], and ultimately resulted in increasing support for the government in Ankara that would be led later on by Atatürk.<ref>Taner Akçam: ''A Shameful Act: The Armenian Genocide and the Question of Turkish Responsibility'', Metropolitan Books, New York 2006 {{ISBN|978-0-8050-7932-6}}, p. 351</ref>
===Procedure=== The court sat for nearly a year, from April 1919 through March 1920, although it became clear after just a few months that the tribunal was simply going through the motions. The judges had condemned the first set of defendants (Enver, et al.) when they were safely out of the country, but the Tribunal, despite making a great show of its efforts, had no intention of returning convictions. Admiral Sir Somerset Gough-Calthorpe protested to the [[Sublime Porte]], took the trials out of Turkish hands, and removed the proceedings to Malta. There an attempt was made to seat an international tribunal, but the Turks bungled the investigations and mishandled the documentary evidence so that nothing of their work could be used by the international court.<ref name=butler>Shadow of the Sultan's Realm: The Destruction of the Ottoman Empire and the Creation of the Modern Middle East, Daniel Allen Butler, Potomac Books Inc, 2011, {{ISBN|978-1597974967}}, p.211-212</ref>
According to [[European Court of Human Rights]] judge [[Giovanni Bonello]], 'quite likely the British found the continental [[inquisitorial system]] of penal procedure used in Turkey ''repugnant'' to its own paths to criminal justice and doubted the propriety of relying on it'. Or, possibly, the Turkish government never came round to hand over the incriminating documents used by the military courts. Whatever the reason, with the advent of power of Ataturk, all the documents on which the Turkish military courts had based their trials and convictions, were ‘lost’.<ref name=malta/> Admiral [[John de Robeck]] replaced Admiral Gough-Calthorpe on August 5, 1919 as "Commander in Chief, Mediterranean, and High Commissioner, at Constantinople".<ref name=butler/> In August 1920, the proceedings were halted, and Admiral [[John de Robeck]] informed London of the futility of continuing the tribunal with the remark: "Its findings cannot be held of any account at all." <ref name="doc136069">Public Record Office, Foreign Office, 371/4174/136069 in {{cite book | last = Dadrian | first = Vahakn | authorlink = Vahakn N. Dadrian | title = The History of the Armenian Genocide | publisher = Berghahn Books | year = 2003 | isbn = 1-57181-666-6 | page = 342}}</ref>
An investigative committee started by Hasan Mazhar was immediately tasked to gather evidence and testimonies, with a special effort to obtain inquiries on civil servants implicated in massacres committed against Armenians.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kieser|first=Hans-Lukas|title=Turkey Beyond Nationalism Towards Post-Nationalist Identities.|year=2006|publisher=I.B. Tauris & Co.|location=London|isbn=978-0-85771-757-3|page=119|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VKVSHjjUT2UC&}}</ref> According to genocide scholar [[Vahakn Dadrian]], the Commission worked in accordance with sections 47, 75 and 87 of the Ottoman Code of Criminal Procedure. It had extensive investigative powers, because it was not only limited to conduct legal proceedings and search for and seize documents, but also to arrest and imprison suspects with assistance from the Criminal Investigation Department, and other State services.<ref name=dadrian>{{cite book|last=Dadrian|first=Vahakn N.|title=The history of the Armenian genocide : ethnic conflict from the Balkans to Anatolia to the Caucasus|year=2004|publisher=Berghahn Books|location=New York|isbn=1-57181-666-6|page=384|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZCVJMAVoMM0C&dq|edition=6th rev.}}</ref> In a course of three months, the committee managed to gather 130 documents and files pertaining to the massacres, and had them transferred to the courts-martial.<ref name=agbu>{{cite journal|last1=Kevorkian|first1=Raymond|title=The Origins and Evolution of the Armenian Genocide|journal=Armenian General Benevolent Union Magazine|date=2015|volume=25|issue=1|page=15}}</ref>
===Verdict=== On July 5, 1919, the court reached a verdict which sentenced the organizers of the massacres, Talat, Enver, Cemal and others to death.<ref name="Herzig 2005" /><ref name="Andreopoulos 1997" /> The military court found that it was the intent of the CUP to eliminate the Armenians physically, via its [[Special Organization (Ottoman Empire)|Special Organization]]. The pronouncement reads as follows:<ref>{{cite book|last1=Libaridian|first1=Gerald J.|title=Modern Armenia people, nation, state|date=2007|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=New Brunswick, N.J.|isbn=1412813514|pages=134–5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZNyKALLaiJoC}}</ref>
<blockquote>[[Turkish Courts-Martial of 1919–20|The Court Martial]] taking into consideration the above-named crimes declares, unanimously, the culpability as principal factors of these crimes the fugitives Talaat Pasha, former Grand Vizir, Enver Efendi, former War Minister, struck off the register of the Imperial Army, Cemal Efendi, former Navy Minister, struck off too from the Imperial Army, and Dr. Nazim Efendi, former Minister of Education, members of the General Council of the Union & Progress, representing the moral person of that party; ... the Court Martial pronounces, in accordance with said stipulations of the Law the death penalty against Talaat, Enver, Cemal, and Dr. Nazim.</blockquote>
The courts-martial officially disbanded the CUP and confiscated its assets and the assets of those found guilty. Two of the three Pashas who fled were later assassinated by Armenian vigilantes during [[Operation Nemesis]].
==Detention in Malta and aftermath== {{further|Malta exiles|Effort to prosecute Ottoman war criminals}}
Ottoman military members and high-ranking politicians convicted by the Turkish courts-martial were transferred from Constantinople prisons to the [[Crown Colony of Malta]] on board of the SS ''Princess Ena'' and the SS HMS ''Benbow'' by the British forces, starting in 1919. Admiral Sir [[Somerset Gough-Calthorpe]] was in charge of the operation, together with Lord Curzon; they did so owing to the lack of transparency of the Turkish courts-martial. They were held there for three years, while searches were made of archives in Constantinople, London, Paris and Washington to find a way to put them in trial.<ref>Türkei By Klaus-Detlev. Grothusen.</ref> However, the war criminals were eventually released without trial and returned to Constantinople in 1921, in exchange for 22 British [[POW|prisoners of war]] held by the government in Ankara, including a relative of Lord Curzon. The government in Ankara was opposed to political power of the [[Imperial Government (Ottoman Empire)|government in Constantinople]]. They are often mentioned as the ''Malta exiles'' in some sources.{{sfn|Bonello|2008}}
According to [[European Court of Human Rights]] judge [[Giovanni Bonello]] the suspension of prosecutions, the repatriation and release of Turkish detainees was amongst others a result of the lack of an appropriate legal framework with [[Jurisdiction|supranational jurisdiction]], because following World War I no international norms for regulating war crimes existed, due to a legal vacuum in international law; therefore contrary to Turkish sources, no trials were ever held in Malta. He mentions that the release of the Turkish detainees was accomplished in exchange for 22 British prisoners held by Mustafa Kemal Atatürk.{{sfn|Bonello|2008}}<ref name=malta/>
=== Punishment === [[File:Operation Nemesis exhibition Tsitsernakaberd.jpg|thumbnail|An exhibition dedicated to Operation Nemesis at the [[Tsitsernakaberd|genocide museum]] in [[Yerevan]], [[Armenia]]]] At the [[Armenian Revolutionary Federation]]'s 9th General Congress, which convened in [[Yerevan]] from September 27, to the end of October 1919, the issue of retribution against those personally responsible for organizing the [[Armenian Genocide|Genocide]] was on the agenda. A task force, led by [[Shahan Natalie]], working with Grigor Merjanov, was established to assassinate [[Talaat Pasha]], [[Behbud Khan Javanshir|Javanshir Khan]], [[Said Halim Pasha]], [[Behaeddin Shakir|Behaeddin Shakir Bey]], [[Cemal Azmi|Jemal Azmi]], [[Djemal Pasha|Cemal Pasha]], [[Enver Pasha]], as well as several Armenian collaborationists, in an secret operation codenamed [[Operation Nemesis]].
==Purging of evidence== A [[WikiLeaks]] [[Diplomatic cable|cable]] [[classified information|classified]] and signed by David Arnett on July 4, 2004<ref name=wikileaks>https://wikileaks.org/cable/2004/07/04ISTANBUL1074.html WIKILEAKS. 04ISTANBUL1074, ARMENIAN "GENOCIDE" AND THE OTTOMAN ARCHIVES</ref> at the [[Consulate]] General of the [[United States of America|US]] in Istanbul states the following: <blockquote> ''According to [[Sabanci University]] Professor [[Halil Berktay]], there were two serious efforts to purge the archives of any incriminating documents on the Armenian question. The first took place in 1918, presumably before the Allied forces occupied [[Constantinople|Istanbul]]. Berktay and others point to testimony in the 1919 Turkish Military Tribunals indicating that important documents had been "stolen" from the archives. Berktay believes a second purge was executed in conjunction with Ozal's efforts to open the archives by a group of retired diplomats and generals led by former Ambassador Muharrem Nuri Birgi.'' </blockquote>
According to the cable, ambassador Muharrem Nuri Birgi was effectively in charge of destroying evidence during the 1980s.<ref name="barsoumian">{{cite news|last1=Barsoumian|first1=Nanore|title=WikiLeaks: Stepping Out of Ottoman Archives, Diplomat Says ‘We Really Slaughtered Them!’|url=http://armenianweekly.com/2011/09/10/wikileaks-stepping-out/|agency=The Armenian Weekly|date=10 September 2011}}</ref> During the process of eliminating the evidence, ambassador Birgi stated in reference to the Armenians: "We really slaughtered them."<ref name=wikileaks /><ref name="barsoumian" /> Others, such as Tony Greenwood, the Director of the American Research Institute in Turkey, confirmed that a select group of retired military personnel were "going through" the archives. However, it was noted by a certain Turkish scholar that the examination was merely an effort to purge documents found in the archives.<ref name=wikileaks />
== Controversy == {{See also|Denial of the Armenian Genocide}} There is a controversy by revisionist sources about the translations into Western language (mostly English and German) of the verdicts and accounts published in newspapers. Gilles Veinstein, a professor of Ottoman and Turkish history at [[Collège de France]] estimates that the translation made by former Armenian historian Haigazn Kazarian is "highly tendentious, in several locations".<ref>{{Citation | contribution = Trois questions sur un massacre | title = L’Histoire | language = French | date = April 1995}}.</ref> Turkish historians Erman Şahin and Ferudun Ata accuse Taner Akçam of mistranslations and inaccurate summaries, including the rewriting of important sentences and the addition of things not included in the original version.<ref>{{Citation | first = Erman | last = Şahin | format = [[PDF]] | url = http://www.tc-america.org/Erman%20Sahin-Review%20Article.pdf | contribution = A Scrutiny of Akçam's Version of History and the Armenian Genocide | title = Journal of Muslim Minority Affairs | number = 28:2 | page = 308}}.</ref><ref>{{Citation | url = http://www.mepc.org/create-content/book-review | format = Review Essay | contribution = The Armenian Question | title = Middle East Policy | volume = XVII | number = 1 | date = Spring 2010 | pages = 149–57}}.</ref><ref>Ferudun Ata, "An Evaluation of the Approach of the Researchers Who Advocate Armenian Genocide to the Trials Relocation," in ''The New Approaches to Turkish-Armenian Relations'', Istanbul, Istanbul University Publications, 2008, pp. 560-561.</ref>
==See also==

The '''Uganda Intelligence Department''' (UID) was an organisation mobilised at short notice by the colonial government in the [[Uganda Protectorate]] at the start of World War 1. The National Archives 'British Army medal index cards 1914–1920 records<ref>{{cite web|last1=Archives|first1=The National|title=The Discovery Service|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C14531|website=discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref> list at least 20 people affiliated with the UID; although all those listed below may not have been serving concurrently as mobilisation dates on medal cards do vary.
The officers of the UID came from a number of backgrounds, some were farmers<ref>{{cite web|title=COLONIAL REPORTS—ANNUAL. No. 706. EAST AFRICA PROTECTORATE. REPORT FOR 1910-11.|url=http://libsysdigi.library.illinois.edu/ilharvest/Africana/Books2011-05/5530244/5530244_1910_1911/5530244_1910_1911_ocr.txt|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref>, some army officers from British and colonial regiments, some colonial civil servants<ref>{{cite web|last1=Blue|first1=Book|title=Uganda, 1901-1945 - British Online Archives From Microform Academic Publishers|url=https://www.britishonlinearchives.co.uk/group.php?pid=72740-12|website=British Online Archives|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref> and some were businessmen. The following European officers were affiliated with the unit and their ranks and individual Medal Record numbers are also listed (each Medal Record makes reference to the Uganda Intelligence Department, along with other units associated with the officer):
* Lieutenant C E B Dashwood (WO 372/5/169953) * Captain Harold Chester Croker De La Poer (WO 372/5/144186) * Captain Herbert Richard Harvey (WO 372/9/71351) * Lieutenant George Clanson Ishmael (WO 372/10/165186) * Lieutenant M H King (WO 372/11/172441) * Lieutenant John W Lenon (WO 372/12/62122) * Captain T Maxsted (WO 372/13/181827) * Lieutenant Leopold Henry David McCombie (WO 372/12/196383) - killed in action on 3 July 1915 and buried near Fort Portal in Western Uganda<ref>{{cite web|title=L H D McCombie|url=http://www.cwgc.org/find-war-dead/casualty/905213/McCOMBIE,%20L%20H%20D|website=CWGC|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Bryant|first1=P.|title=167 died on this day: Sat 03/07/1915|url=https://firstworldwaronthisday.blogspot.co.uk/2015/07/167-died-on-this-day-sat-03071915.html|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref> * Honorary Captain Norman Moore (WO 372/14/73405) * Honorary Captain [[James Erasmus Tracey Philipps|James Erasmus Tracy Philipps]] MC (WO 372/15/219820) - whose personal papers contain most information on the Department<ref>{{cite web|last1=Philipps|first1=J E T|title=Lot 933, Orders, Decorations and Medals (13 December 2007) {{!}} Dix Noonan Webb|url=https://www.dnw.co.uk/auction-archive/past-catalogues/lot.php?auction_id=115&lot_id=150244|website=www.dnw.co.uk|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref> * Lieutenant William Burchell Pickard (WO 372/15/234171) * Temporary Captain Charles Eric Eugene Sullivan (WO 372/19/103997) * Honorary Captain George Lawrence Maitland (WO 372/21/12285).
The African soldiers known to be on the Uganda Intelligence Department's establishment were: * Serjeant Kassim Lugwana (WO 372/11/96542) * Lance Corporal Ilera Mwanga Wanga (WO 372/10/145367) * Private Nyansi Lumu (WO 372/15/20166) * Private Phillippo Lwangoga (WO 372/15/220432) it was reported that Phillippo was a chief and trusted associate of Captain Philipps<ref>{{cite web|title=Newcastle Morning Herald And Miners' Advocate (NSW) - Sep 23 1921|url=https://www.myheritage.com/research/record-10450-25765274/newcastle-morning-herald-and-miners-advocate-nsw?trp=&trn=organic_google&trl=#fullscreen|website=www.myheritage.com|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref> * Private Jafali Mitala (WO 372/10/186905) * Private Alikisi Mumanya (WO 372/1/47360).
There is (as yet) no record of the roles of the African soldiers posted to the Department. However, the presence of a tribal chief indicates they were political influencers and collectors of intelligence.
The British Army medal index cards record that the Uganda Intelligence Department personnel were active from 1914 to as late as 1921<ref>{{cite web|last1=Archives|first1=The National|title=The Discovery Service|url=http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/C14531|website=discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref>. The same index cards and medal auction descriptions point to UID personnel being awarded the [[1914–15 Star]], [[British War Medal]] and [[Victory Medal (United Kingdom)|Victory Medal]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Lot 423, 8 September 2015 {{!}} Dix Noonan Webb|url=https://www.dnw.co.uk/auction-archive/lot-archive/lot.php?department=Medals&lot_id=266075|website=www.dnw.co.uk|accessdate=13 June 2017}}</ref>.

{{Refimprove|date=April 2007}} {{Infobox militant organization | name = All-Russian Social-Christian Union for the Liberation of the People | logo = | caption = | native_name = Всероссийский социал-христианский союз освобождения народа | native_name_lang = ru | other_name = VSKhSON | country = [[Soviet Union]] | leader = Igor Ogurtsov | foundation = February 1964 | dates = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}}–{{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | dissolved = 1967 | motives = | area = | headquarters = [[Saint Petersburg|Leningrad]] | ideology = | position = | crimes = | attacks = | status = | size = | revenue = | financing = | flag = }} The '''All-Russian Social-Christian Union for the Liberation of the People''' ({{lang-ru|Всероссийский социал-христианский союз освобождения народа|translit=Vserossiyskiy sotsial-khristianskiy soyuz osvobozhdeniya naroda}}), commonly known by the acronym '''VSKhSON''' (ВСХСОН), was an underground [[anti-Soviet]] organization operated in the [[Soviet Union]] between 1964 and 1967. The Union was founded by [[Saint Petersburg State University|Leningrad State University]] alumni in February 1964, and counted 28 members and 30 candidates.<ref name=sakharov>{{cite web|url=http://www.sakharov-center.ru/museum/expositions/resistance-unfreedom-ussr/|title=Сопротивление несвободе в СССР|publisher=[[Sakharov Center]]|language=ru|accessdate=30 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107133138/http://www.sakharov-center.ru/museum/expositions/resistance-unfreedom-ussr/|archive-date=7 November 2011}}</ref>
VSKhSON ideology was named "Social Christianity" and has its roots in the [[Third Position]], that neither communism nor capitalism. It was aimed to project of [[Christian ethics]] on a reformed social and economical structure of Soviet society. In order to achieve that goal, it was supposed to create the Supreme Council with the right to veto any government initiative, which should consist of one-third of members of the highest [[Russian Orthodox Church|Russian Orthodox]] hierarchy, and two-third of life "outstanding representatives of the nation", while the head of the proposed "Christian state" should be elected by the Supreme Council, then approved by the public vote.<ref name=alexeyeva>{{cite book|last=Alexeyeva|first=Lyudmila|authorlink=Lyudmila Alexeyeva|title=История инакомыслия в СССР: Новейший период|trans-title=The History of Dissident Thought in the USSR: The Latest Period|chapter=Русское национальное движение|trans-chapter=Russian National Movement|chapter-url=http://www.memo.ru/history/diss/books/ALEXEEWA/Chapter19.htm#_VPID_58|location=Vilnius; Moscow|publisher=Vest|date=1992|language=ru}} {{ISBN|9785984400268}}</ref>
VSKhSON members stood for "the abolition of Soviet totalitarianism" and the resurrection of a "healthy balance between the individual, society, and government", and the resurrection of the individual (versus Soviet collectivism). As compared to other secret youth organizations of the 1960s–early 1970s, the bylaws of VSKhSON had stated that every member of the organization "is not only a propagandist and organizer, but a soldier". In many ways the organization can be compared to the white émigré [[National Alliance of Russian Solidarists]].
In February 1967, after being denounced by an informant, the organization was designated as terrorist by the [[KGB]].<ref name=sakharov/> Twenty one of the organization's members were put on trial and received long terms of internment. Co-founder Igor Ogurtsov was sentenced to seven years of imprisonment, eight years of [[labor camp]]s and five years of exile.<ref name=sakharov/> After returning to Russia in 1992 from exile in Germany, Ogurtsov continued a life of political activism.
The organization's founders, Igor Ogurtsov, Yevgeny Vagin, Mikhail Sado and Boris Averichkin, have not been rehabilitated. The Presidium of the [[Supreme Court of Russia]] affirmed the validity of the guilty verdict and sentence of VSKhSON members on 20 November 1996.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vshson.narod.ru/ippvs.html|title=Из Постановления Верховного Суда РФ по делу ВСХСОН, 1996 г.|language=ru|accessdate=30 May 2016}}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=September 2015}} {{Infobox organization |name = Vasile Lupu High School Group |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = Majadahonda |motto = |formation = 1940 |extinction = 1941 |type = anti-[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] group |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |location = [[Orhei]] |region_served = |membership = |language = [[Romanian language|Romanian]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = |website = |remarks = }}
'''Vasile Lupu High School Group''' ([[Romanian language|Romanian]]:''Grupul Liceul "Vasile Lupu"'') was one of the first organized anti-[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] groups in [[Bessarabia]] in the wake of [[Soviet occupation of Bessarabia|its occupation by the Soviet Union]] on June 28, 1940.
==Activity==
It was formed by the students and some teachers of the Vasile Lupu high school in [[Orhei]], which was renamed by the Soviets a ''Pedagogical School''.
After a series of small actions, such as writing anti-Soviets slogans on public walls ("Death to the Stalinist occupiers!", "Go home, barbarians!", "Down with the executioner [[Joseph Stalin|Stalin]]! Bessarabia to Bessarabians!", "Long live [[Romania]]n nation!"), and spread of anti-Soviet manifestos, they did an extrodinary achievement: during the [[Christmas|Christmas night]] 1940, they took down the Soviet red flags, and put up [[Romanian flag]]s on top of several buildings in [[Orhei]], including the city hall, the [[Communist Party of Romania]] building, the [[NKVD]] headquarters. In January 1941, NKVD managed to crack into the organization and arrest most of its members. The sentence was pronounced on June 24, 1941.<ref>[http://istoria.md/articol/818/Grupul_de_rezisten%C5%A3%C4%83_antisovietic%C4%83_din_Orhei___Majadahonda Grupul de rezistenţă antisovietică din Orhei - Majadahonda (1940 - 1941)] istoria.md.</ref>
== Members == [[File:Onisie Cozma.jpg|thumb]]
*Dumitru Avramoglo (born in 1922, in [[Puţintei]]), condemned to death *Victor Brodeţchi (b. 1924), condemned to death *Anatol Cotun, condemned to death *Onisie Cozama (b. 1922), condemned to death *Dumitru Dobândă (b. 1922), condemned to death *Mihail Dobândă, condemned to death *Antol Duca (b. 1922), condemned to death *Vichentie Eprov (b. 1923), condemned to death *Haralambie Grăjdianu, condemned to death *Mihai Grăjdianu (b. 1922), condemned to death *Antol Guma (b. 1922), condemned to death *Gheorghe Mihu (b. 1921), condemned to death *Constantin Sârbu, condemned to death Most of them were executed in [[Chişinău]] on June 27, 1941, according to a report of the [[Odessa]] Military Tribunal, signed Axelrod. Other members: *Vlad Alexeev, condemned, disappeared in Siberia *Ion Bacalu (b. 1924), condemned to 25 years imprisonment, died in detention *Pavel Boguş (b. 1924, in [[Mana]]), condemned to 25 years, died in detention *Eugen Braşoveanu (b. 1924), condemned to 25 years, died in detention *Serghei Buiuc (b. 1924), condemned to 10 years *Vsevolod Ciobanu, condemned to 10 years, disappeared in Siberia *Nicole Cuculescu (b. 1923), condemned to 20 years *Oleg Frunză (b. 1928, only 13 years old), condemned to 10 years *Victor Guma (b. 1923), condemned to 25 years, died in detention *Maria Manjaru, teacher, condemned to 10 years for not denouncing, survived *Gheorghe Martânov (b. 1924), condemned to 25 years, freed in 1954 *Dumitru Munteanu, teacher *Dumitu Stici, condemned to 10 years, disappeared in Siberia
The investigation was led by G. Goldberg, chief of the Orhei County Section of NKVD, and was conducted by Konopekin, chief investigator, Terebilo, deputy, Cherepanov, Malinin, Morev, Nikitovich, Plotnikov, and Toporov, investigators.<ref>Petru Bunacalea si Andrei Calcea, "Osanditi la nemurire", concernul "Presa", Chisinau 1999.</ref>
