{{other uses|WOG (disambiguation)}} {{pp-move-indef|small=yes}} {{multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=January 2013}} {{original research|date=January 2013}} }} '''''Wog''''' is a [[slang]] word in the idiom of [[Australian English]] and [[British English]]. In the UK, it is usually employed as an [[Ethnic slur|ethnic]] or [[racial slur]], and considered [[derogatory]] and offensive. In Australia, it may be used as a slur, but to some extent has been reclaimed and is used as a self-descriptor. In British English, "wog" is an offensive racial slur usually applied to [[Afro-Caribbean]], [[Ethnic groups of Africa|African]], [[Middle East]]ern, [[South Asia]]n or [[Southeast Asia]]n peoples. In Australian English, "wog" is a term used as a racial slur mostly for people from [[Southern Europe]] and the [[Mediterranean region]] in general (Portuguese, Spanish, Italian, Greek), including the Mediterranean region of the [[Middle East]] (i.e., the [[Eastern Mediterranean]] or the [[Levant]] and [[North Africa]]: Jews and Arabs) as well as [[Eastern Europe]]. ==Origin== The origin of the term is unclear. It was first noted by lexicographer F.C. Bowen in 1929, in his ''Sea Slang: a dictionary of the old-timers’ expressions and epithets'', where he defines wogs as "lower class [[Babu (title)|Babu]] shipping clerks on the Indian coast."{{cite news| url=http://blogs.telegraph.co.uk/culture/christopherhowse/8288667/golliwog_is_not_connected_with_wog/ | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | title='Golliwog' is not connected with 'wog' | date=5 February 2009}} Many dictionaries{{which|date=November 2016}} say "wog" derives from the [[golliwogg]], a [[blackface]] [[Minstrel show|minstrel]] doll character from a children's book, ''The Adventures of Two Dutch Dolls and a Golliwogg'' by [[Florence Kate Upton]], published in 1895; or from ''[[pollywog]]'', a dialect term for [[tadpole]] that is used in maritime circles to indicate someone who has not [[Line-crossing ceremony|crossed the equator]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.yourdictionary.com/wog|title=Wog|last=|first=|date=October 24, 2017|website=Your Dictionary|access-date=October 24, 2017}} Suggestions that the word is an [[acronym]] for "wily Oriental gentleman", "working on government service", or similar, are examples of [[false etymology]].{{cite book|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=X5LEWiomDiEC&pg=PT87&lpg=PT87&dq=%22wily+oriental+gentleman%22&source=bl&ots=JKnek4nDP3&sig=q7GPDK0Lotg0XRYLn-yAet0okw4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=WAxCVMGhFvHW7QbbyYGYCA&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22wily%20oriental%20gentleman%22&f=false |author=Wilton, David |title=Word Myths: Debunking Linguistic Urban Legends|publisher= Oxford University Press|date= 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www.wordorigins.org/index.php/site/comments/wog/ |title=Wog" |website=WordOrigins.org|accessdate= 18 October 2014}} ==Use in British English== "Wog", in the UK, is a derogatory and racially offensive slang word referring to a non-white, Jewish, or [[olive skin|darker-skinned]] white person, including people from the [[Middle East]], the [[Indian subcontinent]], other parts of [[Asia]] such as the [[East Indies]], or the [[Mediterranean]] area, including Southern Europeans. The saying, "The wogs begin at [[Calais]]" (implying that everyone who is not British is a wog), appears to date from the [[First World War]] but was popularised by [[George Wigg, Baron Wigg|George Wigg]], [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]] [[Member of Parliament|MP]] for [[Dudley]], in 1949 when in a parliamentary debate concerning the [[Bamar|Burmese]], Wigg shouted at the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]] benches, "The Honourable Gentleman and his friends think they are all 'wogs'. Indeed, the Right Honourable Member for [[Woodford (UK Parliament constituency)|Woodford]] [i.e., [[Winston Churchill]]] thinks that the 'wogs' begin at Calais."{{cite journal|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1949/jul/29/africa#S5CV0467P0-09214|title= Hansard|journal= House of Commons 5th series|volume=467 }} col 2845. As reported by [[British Jews|English-Jewish]] journalist [[Linda Grant]], people in England have referred to [[Jews]] and [[Israelis]] as "wogs", as well.{{cite book|author=Grant, Linda|title=The People on the Street: A Writer's View of Israel|publisher=Hatchette Digital|location= London, England |date=2009|accessdate= August 4, 2016}} "It started at once, [Ophir] said, with the geography teacher, 'who we used to call Bullet, who had a map on the wall where Israel appeared as Palestine and to my face he called Jews and Israelis 'terrorist wogs'... As for calling Jews 'wogs,' Ophir was to understand that there was nothing derogatory in the term, it simply meant Western Oriental Gentleman." In Season 1 Episode 6 - 'The Germans' episode of [[Fawlty Towers]] (a 1975 British TV show), Major Gowen specifically refers to "wog" as meaning any person from India (when speaking about the India vs England cricket game at the Oval to Basil Fawlty). ==Use in Australian English== In Australia, the term "wog" refers to residents of [[Southern Europe]]an, [[Mediterranean region|Mediterranean]], [[Middle East]]ern, and [[Eastern Europe]]an ethnicity or appearance. The slur became widely diffused with an increase in immigration from [[Europe]] and the [[Levant]], mainly [[Albania]], [[Croatia]], [[Bosnia]], [[Greece]], [[Italy]], [[France]], [[Lebanon]], [[Republic of Macedonia|Macedonia]], [[Malta]], [[Serbia]], [[Spain]] and [[Turkey]] after the [[Second World War]]. These new arrivals were perceived by the majority population as contrasting with the larger predominant [[White Anglo Saxon Protestant|Anglo Protestant]]/[[Anglo-Australian]]/[[Anglo-Celtic Australian]] culture. The term expanded to include not just Southern European peoples, but immigrants from the [[Mediterranean region]] of the [[Middle East]] as well. Today, "wog" is used particularly in places in Australia with substantial [[Southern Europe]]an, [[Mediterranean region|Mediterranean]], and [[Middle East]]ern populations, mainly Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide. As with other slang and'' [[prima facie]]'' profanity used in contemporary [[Australian English]],e.g., "bastard" and "cunt" the term "wog" may be employed either aggressively or affectionately within differing contexts. In Australian English, "wog" can also be used as a slang word for an illness such as a [[common cold]] or [[influenza]], as in: "I'm coming down with a wog". Such usage is not perceived as derogatory.{{cite web|url=http://andc.anu.edu.au/australian-words/meanings-origins?field_alphabet_value=281 |website=Australian National University|title=Meanings and origins of Australian words and idioms|accessdate=22 March 2015}} ===In the media=== More recently, Southern European-Australian performing artists have taken ownership of the term "wog", defusing its original pejorative nature. The popular 1980s stage show ''[[Wogs Out of Work]]'', created by [[Nick Giannopoulos]] and [[Simon Palomares]], is an early example. The production was followed on television with ''[[Acropolis Now]]'', starring Giannopoulos, Palomares, George Kapiniaris, and Mary Coustas, and films such as ''[[The Wog Boy]]'' and ''[[Wog Boy 2: Kings of Mykonos]]'', and parodies such as those of [[Santo Cilauro]] (Italian), [[Eric Bana]] (Croatian-German), [[Vince Colosimo]] (Italian), Nick Giannopoulos (Greek), Frank Lotito (Italian), [[Mary Coustas]] (Greek), and [[SBS Television]]'s offbeat ''[[Pizza (TV series)|Pizza]]'' and later [[Here Come the Habibs]]. TV series have continued this change in [[Australian culture|Australian cultural history]]—with some even classifying a genre of "wogsploitation" of pop culture products being created by and for a proudly "wog" market.{{cite news |last=Dale |first=David |date=17 May 2003 |title=Wogsploitation makes its mark in mainstream |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/05/16/1052885398860.html |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |access-date=30 July 2017}} Recent works of the genre have been used by Australians of non-English speaking backgrounds to assert ethnic identity rather than succumb to ethnic stereotypes.{{Cite web |url=http://archimedes.ballarat.edu.au:8080/vital/access/manager/Repository/vital:828;jsessionid=1F4182ECBFF260960D2D5796D1E1BE08 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2011-05-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811165650/http://archimedes.ballarat.edu.au:8080/vital/access/manager/Repository/vital:828;jsessionid=1F4182ECBFF260960D2D5796D1E1BE08 |archive-date=2011-08-11 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Upon the release of ''Wog Boy 2'', Giannopoulos discussed the contemporary use of the term "wog" in the Australian context:
I think by defusing the word 'wog' we've shown our maturity and our great ability to adapt and just laugh things off, you know... When I first came [to Greece] and I started trying to explain to them why we got called 'wog' they'd get really angry about it, you know. They were, "Why? Why they say this about the [[Greeks|Greek]] people?" You know? But then when they see what we've done with it—and this is the twist—that we've turned it into a term of endearment, they actually really get into that...
Thus, in contemporary Australia, the term "wog" may, in certain contexts, be viewed as a "[[nickname]]" rather than a pejorative term{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Andrew |date=12 October 2005 |title=A bad word made good |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2005/oct/13/australia.andrewclark |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |access-date=30 July 2017}}—akin to the nicknames ascribed within Australian English to other historically significant cultural groupings such as the English ("[[Alternative names for the British|Poms]]"), the Americans ("[[Yankee|Yanks]]") and New Zealanders ("[[Kiwi (people)|Kiwis]]"). ==Use in Canada== In Canadian [[:wikt:Appendix:Canadian English military slang|military slang]] used by combat arms units (that is, front line fighting forces), "wog" is a derogatory term for any rear echelon personnel and those who are not members of the combat arms. {{cn|date=May 2017}} ==Use in the United States== [[Duane Clarridge]], a former [[CIA]] officer, explained that the term "wog factor" was used by the CIA "to acknowledge that the motivations that shape decision-making in [[North Africa]], the [[Middle East]], and the [[Indian subcontinent]] are very different from our own."{{cite book|last1=Clarridge|first1=Duane|title=A Spy For All Seasons: My Life in the CIA|date=August 13, 2002|publisher=Scibner|isbn=978-0743245364|page=105}} == Scientology == The word "wog" is used by [[Scientology|Scientologists]] to refer to non-Scientologists. Scientology's founder [[L. Ron Hubbard]] defined wog as a "common, everyday garden-variety humanoid ... He 'is' a body. [He] doesn't know he's there, etc. He isn't there as a spirit at all. He is not operating as a [[thetan]]."Saint Hill Briefing Course-82 6611C29 ==See also== *[[List of ethnic slurs]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wiktionary}} * [http://martinfrost.ws/htmlfiles/oct2008/golliwogs.html Essays looking at the origins of the word and its possible relationship with "golliwog"] {{Ethnic slurs}} [[Category:Anti-Albanian sentiment]] [[Category:Anti-Asian sentiment]] [[Category:Anti-Arabism]] [[Category:Anti-Portuguese sentiment]] [[Category:Anti-Italian sentiment]] [[Category:Anti-Spanish sentiment]] [[Category:Antisemitism]] [[Category:English-language slang]] [[Category:Ethnic and religious slurs]] [[Category:Persecution of Greeks]] [[Category:Xenophobia]] [[Category:Anti-Armenianism]] [[Category:Anti-Slavic sentiment]] [[Category:Francophobia]] [[Category:Anti-Irish sentiment]] [[Category:Anti-Romanian sentiment]] [[Category:Anti-black racism]] [[Category:Anti-Romanyism]] [[Category:Anti-Georgian sentiment]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} {{ Infobox Livery Company | name = Worshipful Company of Fishmongers | image = [[Image:Fishmongers-arms.gif|200px|Arms of the Fishmongers' Company]] | motto = ''All Worship be to God Alone'' | location = [[Fishmongers' Hall]], London EC4 | formation = 1272
([[Royal Charter|Charter]] regranted 1537) | association = [[Fishmonger|Fish]] and seafood [[Merchant|traders]] | precedence = 4th | master = [[Livery Company#Governance|Prime Warden]] : [[Anne, Princess Royal]] | website = [http://www.fishhall.org.uk www.fishhall.org.uk] }} The '''Worshipful Company of Fishmongers''' (or '''Fishmongers' Company''') is one of the 110 [[Livery Company|Livery Companies]] of the [[City of London]], being an incorporated [[guild]] of [[fishmonger|sellers of fish and seafood]] in the City. The Company ranks fourth in the [[order of precedence]] of City Livery Companies, thereby making it one of the [[Great Twelve City Livery Companies]].{{citation|url=https://books.google.com/?id=wbguAAAAMAAJ|title=Walks and talks about London|author=John Timbs|chapter=Curiosities of the Fishmongers' Hall|publisher=Lockwood|year=1865}} ==History== The Company records an unbroken existence for over 700 years – although undoubtedly it existed earlier – having received its first [[Royal Charter]] in 1272. A predecessor guild was fined as ''[[wikt:adulterine|adulterine]]'' in 1154. It took the name Stock Fishmongers' Company under another Royal Charter granted in 1508. Then, in 1537, it merged with the Salt Fishmongers' Company to form the Company with its present name. The most famous City fishmonger is [[William Walworth|Sir William Walworth]], who, as [[Lord Mayor of the City of London|Lord Mayor of London]] in 1381, helped bring the [[Peasants' Revolt]] to an end by stabbing the rebel [[Wat Tyler]] to death at [[Smithfield, London|Smithfield]] in the presence of [[Richard II of England|King Richard II]]. In 1383, [[Lord Mayor]] John Comberton de Northampton (a Draper) persuaded the [[City of London Corporation|City Common Council]] to declare that the Fishmongers should no longer have the power to monopolise trade in fish, and this was reaffirmed by Parliament. However, in a Royal Charter granted to the Fishmongers by Richard II in 1399, all their privileges were restored. The same Charter states they should elect six Wardens annually, the number which continues to the present day. Until the end of the 14th century the Fishmongers convened their own [[court of law]], called ''Leyhalmode'', at which disputes over fish and seafood trade were tried by the Wardens of the Company. From 1555 to the present day, the Company has acted as Trustee of [[Gresham's School]] at [[Holt, Norfolk]]. In the early 17th century, the Company was granted lands at [[Ballykelly, County Londonderry|Ballykelly]] and [[Banagher, County Londonderry|Banagher]] in modern-day [[Northern Ireland]], by the Crown. It remained a major landowner there until the 20th century, and the villages contain some of the most interesting buildings erected in [[Ulster]] by the [[Plantation of Ulster|Plantation companies]]. In 1714, the Irish actor [[Thomas Doggett]] provided money to endow a boat race called [[Doggett's Coat and Badge|Doggett's Coat and Badge Race]] in honour of the new king, [[George I of Great Britain|George I of Hanover]]. The race was originally to be rowed annually on 1 August on the [[River Thames]], by up to six young watermen per boat who were not to be out of their apprenticeship by more than twelve months. The prize for the champion oarsman is a fine red coat embellished with a large silver badge on one arm, depicting the white horse of [[House of Hanover|Hanover]] with the word 'liberty' underneath. Since Doggett's death, the Fishmongers' Company continues to organise this event each year, and it is now believed to be the world's longest continuously-running sporting event as well as being the longest boat race in the world – 4 miles, 5 furlongs (7,400 m). By the 18th century, references to fish were hard to find in the Fishmongers' Company Court minutes, since the Company's main business had evolved into managing its extensive properties and administering its charities and trusts, such as [[Gresham's School]] as well as [[St. Peter's Hospital (Newington)|St. Peter's Hospital]] and [[almshouse]]s at [[Newington, London|Newington]] in Surrey.Earle, Peter, ''[http://www.escholarship.org/editions/view?docId=ft8489p27k&chunk.id=d0e8490&toc.depth=1&toc.id=d0e8490&brand=eschol;query=Holt#1 The Making of the English Middle Class'', p. 258] (University of California Press, 1989) at escholarship.org ==Functions== The Company is governed by its Prime Warden, five other Wardens and its Court of Assistants, comprising 28 appointed Livery members. In its early history, the Company established a monopoly over the sale of fish in the City of London and its environs. Although government legislation over the years has reduced such trade restrictions, the Company is still tasked with the important role overseeing the quality of fish imported into the City mostly via [[Billingsgate Market]], the UK's largest [[fish market]]. This responsibility is undertaken by the Company's [[Quality control|fishmeter]]s (inspectors) under powers established by a Royal Charter of [[James I of England|James I]] in 1604.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/9288325/The-Fish-Market-Inside-Billingsgate-BBC-Two-review.html BBC: ''Inside Billingsgate''] The Company is closely involved with monitoring [[salmon]] and [[fresh water]] fishing as well as the catching of shellfish throughout UK waters. It encourages research through grants and sponsorship and also publishes books on fish, such as ''Fish and Shellfish'' and ''The Fishmongers' Company Cook Book''. Thus, the Company retains many of its ancient trade duties, unlike some other Livery Companies, whose trades having become defunct through technological advances, act for the most part as charitable benefactors or ceremonial institutions. The Fishmongers' Company is also a significant educational charity. As well as Gresham's School, it has also long supported the [[City and Guilds of London Art School]] and the [[City and Guilds of London Institute]]. The Company comprises about 300 members, including a good representation of working [[fishmonger]]s. Liverymen of all City companies are members of [[Guildhall, London|Common Hall]] which entitles them to vote each year in the election of the [[Lord Mayor of the City of London]], held on [[Michaelmas Day]] (29 September) or the closest weekday, and also in the election of the [[Sheriffs of the City of London|Sheriffs of London]] on Midsummer's Day. Voting is by show of hands, but should one [[liveryman]] call for a recount, a ballot is held two weeks later. ==Hall {{anchor|Hall|Fishmongers' Hall}}== [[Image:Fishmongers' Hall.jpg|thumb|right|Fishmongers' Hall overlooking the Thames at London Bridge.]] The Company's [[livery hall]] in the City of London is known as [[Fishmongers' Hall]] (sometimes shortened in common parlance to Fish Hall); its earliest recorded hall was built in 1310. A new hall, on the present site, was bequeathed to the Company in 1434. Together with 43 other Livery halls, this one was destroyed in the [[Great Fire of London]] in 1666 and a replacement hall designed by the architect Edward Jerman opened in 1671. This hall by Jerman was demolished to facilitate the construction of the new [[London Bridge]] in 1827. The Fishmongers' next hall was designed by [[Henry Roberts (architect)|Henry Roberts]] (although his assistant, later the celebrated [[Gilbert Scott|Sir Gilbert Scott]], made the drawings) and built by [[William Cubitt (politician)|William Cubitt & Company]], opening in 1834.{{cite web|url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=202779|title=William Cubitt & Co|publisher=Scottish Architects|accessdate=4 June 2012}} After severe bomb damage during [[the Blitz]], Fishmongers' Hall was restored by Austen Hall (of Whinney, Son & Austen Hall) and reopened in 1951. ==Gresham's School== Since 1555, the Company has acted as the [[Trustee]] of [[Gresham's School]] in [[Holt, Norfolk]], in accordance with the wishes of Lord Mayor [[John Gresham|Sir John Gresham]] (1492–1556). Among other responsibilities, the Company provides more than half of the school's governors, including the chairman of the governing body, which meets at Fishmongers' Hall. In 1729, the Fishmongers' Company presented the school with "...a valuable and useful library, not only of the best editions of the Classics and Lexicographers, but also with some books of Antiquities, Chronology, and Geography, together with a suitable pair of globes".Monroe, Paul, ed. ''A Cyclopedia of Education'' (London, Macmillan, 1926), [https://archive.org/stream/cyclopediaofeduc008784mbp/cyclopediaofeduc008784mbp_djvu.txt online edition] of archive.org In May 1926, in accepting membership of the Company by right of patrimony, the future [[George VI of the United Kingdom|King George VI]] said: "I hope that it may be possible for me, at some future date, to prove my interest by personally visiting Gresham's School, of which I have frequently heard such excellent accounts".''Duke of York and Fishmongers: Admitted To Freedom Of The Company'' in ''The Times'', Friday, 21 May 1926; p. 13; Issue 44277; col D ==List of Prime Wardens== {{Expand list|date=November 2011}} *''c.'' 1370: [[William Walworth|Sir William Walworth]] *1664: Abraham Johnson *1676: William Allington *1721–22: [[Fryer baronets|Sir John Fryer]] *1810–12: [[Richard Sharp (politician)|Richard "Conversation" Sharp, MP]]Knapman, D. – ''Conversation Sharp – The Biography of a London Gentleman, Richard Sharp (1759–1835), in Letters, Prose and Verse'' (Private publication, 2004) British Library. *1834–36: [[Sir Matthew Wood, 1st Baronet|Sir Matthew Wood]]Matthew Wood in 'Chronological List of Aldermen, 1801–1912 | Aldermen of the City of London pp. 141–156', [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=67244] accessed 13 October 2012 *1863–64: [[William Cubitt (politician)|William Cubitt]]William Cubitt in 'Chronological List of Aldermen, 1801–1912 | Aldermen of the City of London pp. 141–156', [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=67244] accessed 13 October 2012 (''et. al.''
